Title: Charging for Rubbish: A Complex Issue

Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems like a good idea for the environment and economy. However, it might not be as effective as it seems. In many developed countries, rubbish collection is a common service. People put their rubbish out, and it gets collected by a truck and taken to a landfill. Although households pay for this service through local taxes, the cost is the same whether a family produces a lot of rubbish or just a little. This is strange to economists because the more rubbish there is, the more it costs to collect and dispose of it.

The simple economic solution is to charge people for the amount of rubbish they throw away. This would encourage them to produce less waste and recycle more. However, American economists Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman found that this approach can have unexpected and sometimes disappointing results.

They studied several American towns that started charging for rubbish. The most common method was to sell stickers or tags for rubbish bags. Only bags with these tags would be collected. In Charlottesville, Virginia, residents were charged 80 cents per tagged bag. While this seemed like a good use of market forces, the costs of running the scheme were high. The number of rubbish bags decreased by 37%, but this was mainly because people packed more rubbish into each bag, a practice known as the 'Seattle stomp'. This method is less efficient than using machines at landfill sites. The actual weight of rubbish collected only fell by 14%.

In other Virginian cities without such a scheme, rubbish weight fell by 3.5% anyway. Some people also resorted to illegal dumping to avoid paying, which might account for 30-40% of the reduction in collected rubbish. On a positive note, recycling increased by 15%, but this might not be due to the fee, as many people were already recycling voluntarily.

In a broader study, Fullerton and Kinnaman found that while pricing does reduce rubbish weight, the effect is small. A 10% increase in sticker prices only reduces rubbish by 0.3%. This is because to significantly reduce rubbish, people would need to buy less of almost everything, and a small fee is unlikely to change that.

Other factors, like income and education, might be just as important as price. In wealthier towns, people produce more rubbish and have less time to recycle. So, should we abandon the idea of charging for rubbish? Not necessarily. Free disposal is too cheap, but simple policies can have complex effects. Detailed economic models are often needed to understand these effects, and sometimes the results are not as pleasant as expected.

Theodore Zeldin explores how our work lives might change. Are you respected and appreciated as you should be? Just having a successful career isn't enough anymore. Many professions feel undervalued, and even famous individuals often feel bitter. Loving your work used to be enough to make you special, but now you need to consider how your job affects you personally—your mind, character, and relationships. This is important because no matter how skilled you are, if your work makes you boring or unable to talk to people outside your field, or if you're too busy to gain wisdom or use your imagination, then status or money won't make up for your shortcomings as a person.

I am exploring how work can prioritize personal fulfillment instead of just shaping us to fit industrial needs. Work should be more than just creating wealth; it should be a fulfilling lifestyle, helping us discover hidden talents and meet diverse people. However, this doesn't mean simply eliminating unemployment. As people become more educated, they want jobs that are enriching, interesting, and useful. A career should be like a work of art, with a fulfilled person at its center.

Even middle-class jobs aren't as appealing as they used to be. Doctors are often more stressed than their patients, accountants worry about ethics, architects rarely get to be creative, and administrators are stuck in bureaucracy. Middle managers, once proud of their status, are losing confidence. Meanwhile, companies and public institutions are downsizing. Efforts like decentralizing decisions, improving skills, and rewarding performance haven't gained employee commitment. In Britain, only 8% of employees strongly feel their values align with their organization's.

I am investigating various jobs to see how they shape or sometimes harm people. I've studied how different cultures expand human potential and how courage can be developed. I've looked at happiness, love, friendship, and respect, and now I'm focusing on finding more satisfying ways to work. Many experts work on extending the life and income of companies, but we also need to evaluate ourselves as people and decide who we want to spend our lives with. How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many are like part-time slaves, theoretically free to leave but actually trapped by our qualifications and careers, working not to improve ourselves but because we see no other choice?

Take hotel workers, for example. They make up 10% of the workforce in the hospitality industry. Many intelligent and lively people endure low prestige, low pay, and long hours because hotels haven't been rethought since the days of the Ritz. A hotel isn't just a place for travelers to sleep; it's like a mini United Nations. People from all over the world meet in hotels but usually don't interact. Many hotel staff are foreigners eager to learn a new language and culture, but they have only superficial interactions with guests. Hotels could be cultural centers, connecting guests with the city and each other. Hoteliers could use the skills of the students they employ instead of giving them only basic tasks. If they focused on their staff's true ambitions, they would see many other services hotels could offer. But accountants often limit them, saying companies should focus on one main activity to maximize profits. It's time to rethink this from a human perspective, not just a financial one, and move beyond traditional categories.

For me, work is about relationships. Now that many people want more than just obedience and see work as a way to express independence, they should have the chance to design their own jobs and choose their colleagues and even customers, within practical and profitable limits. This means they need to communicate beyond professional jargon, with people who might seem very different at first. Everyone knows communication is important, but it's different from conversation. Traditional conversation is different from the new kind of conversation people miss today. This new conversation is more intimate, creating respect and understanding, and can change you. It's more than just relaxing; it's a powerful way to create equality. Every time you have a conversation like this, the world changes a little bit.

Broadcasting originally referred to the act of spreading seeds widely by hand, symbolizing growth and abundance. This metaphor was applied to the new technology of broadcasting, which involved transmitting words and pictures electronically. Despite its potential for two-way communication, like the telephone, television was quickly developed as a centralized mass medium. This approach matched the socio-economic structures and lifestyles of modern societies, where information was sent from a central source to private homes.

There were some early experiments with alternative forms of television, such as two-way communication, but these did not last. In Britain, radio amateurs in the 1930s tried to create a more grassroots, egalitarian form of television. However, the British Radio Manufacturers Association set standards that pushed these amateurs out, favoring a more centralized approach.

In the early 1930s, television was often viewed in public places, similar to how films were shown, and this was common in countries like the USA, Britain, and Germany. Although public viewing posed a potential challenge to the idea of television as a home-based medium, it did not prevail. As technology advanced and prices dropped, manufacturers saw the opportunity for mass sales of home television sets.

The rise of broadcasting was closely linked to social and economic changes. As people moved into cities and became more isolated from traditional communities, centralized broadcasting helped governments efficiently communicate with citizens and foster a sense of national unity. Broadcasting also played a role in promoting democracy by providing equal access to information necessary for informed participation in society.

Today, broadcasting is evolving, and the term itself may become outdated. The metaphor of broadcasting might eventually only describe a specific phase in the history of audio-visual technology during a time of centralized social modernization.

**Clutter**  
Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you own, you never feel safe or satisfied. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes the desire to get more things can become too much. Modern advertising is designed to make us feel insecure. It often suggests that if you don't own certain things, you're not as good as others. To see how much ads affect you, try not to read any billboards next time you're out. These expensive ads influence us in powerful ways without us even noticing. We see them everywhere—on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, T-shirts, and the internet—all telling us to keep buying more.

**Caves**  
Research centers and universities worldwide have spent years studying caves, focusing on how they form, their water systems, and the life inside them. Caves are a small but intriguing part of nature that spark our curiosity and drive for knowledge. This has led to a lot of research. In places where caves have impacted human life, studies have been even more intense. However, exploring caves often requires physical skill, so cave research is not just for academics. There is a unique overlap between professional scientists and amateur enthusiasts who explore caves for fun.

**Weather Watch**  
Many observant people, using only their senses, laid the groundwork for meteorology, which has evolved into a complex science since the 17th century. Today, satellites and electronic tools provide us with constant weather updates quickly, and computers solve complex calculations faster than humans can. Meteorological theory is full of long, technical words that can be confusing to non-experts. However, simple weather wisdom is still important. Human experience is crucial in turning computer data into weather forecasts. Observations from people can offer unique insights that help professionals understand the atmosphere better.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**

Until recently, I believed opera was mainly about theatre. Now, I see that music is the most important part of opera, with theatre coming second. This makes sense, but my background is in theatre, where the spoken word and the actor are central. In theatre, once the performance starts, there's no one directing the action, and the audience usually understands the language spoken on stage.

In music performances, whether in a concert hall or opera house, many people, like me, don't have a deep understanding of music. Some might feel embarrassed about this, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. A brilliant singer or a perfect orchestra is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows the results of years of hard work. Watching top-level music is like watching a sports event; we see athletes doing something similar to running for a bus, but much better.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often don't understand an actor's skill and aren't as impressed by something that seems like what they could do themselves. They don't usually applaud when an actor finishes a long speech, though they often ask, "How do you remember all those lines?" This doesn't mean theatre audiences are more or less demanding than music audiences; many are the same people. But in theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms, no matter how challenging the play is.

Should music learn from theatre about this relationship? I think so. I've seen how a different approach can change the concert experience. Live music is naturally theatrical, full of emotion and drama, and it can go wrong, engaging the audience's imagination as a group. However, music presentations often feel hierarchical, with strict dress codes and too much respect for conductors and soloists. On the other hand, modern audiences sometimes interrupt performances by clapping at the wrong times, which can disrupt the flow of the music.

Can anything be done? Yes, a lot is being done. There are efforts to attract new audiences to concerts and operas and to make 'serious' music more accessible. I remember a special event, Jonathan Dove's community opera "In Search of Angels," which moved from place to place in a cathedral and then into the town. It was a top-quality musical experience, and it changed the lives of many in the audience, who were not just watching but also participating.

I wish music had more of the risk and boldness that theatre can have. Sometimes this comes from using unusual locations, which can surprise both performers and audiences. It might be uncomfortable, with poor acoustics or cold temperatures, but theatre audiences have learned to be adventurous in such spaces. I know most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts. However, I believe music conventions can and should change. I speak as an enthusiast: I love theatre and spend a lot of time and money on music. I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**  
While I admire how sand can be turned into useful things like glass and concrete, I don't really like it in its natural form. To me, sand is mostly an annoying obstacle between a car park by the sea and the water. It blows into your face, gets into your food, and hides important things like car keys and coins. When you're wet, it sticks to you like plaster and is hard to remove, even with a strong water spray. But strangely, as soon as you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, it falls off you. For days, you keep finding sand on the floor every time you take off your shoes, and more comes off when you remove your socks. Sand stays with you longer than many illnesses. No, I don't like sand at all.

**Lock and Key**  
The need for a safe home, privacy, and security has been around since humans first built permanent homes. The simple wooden bar behind the door has been replaced by electronic locks that use a plastic card with countless combinations, but the desire to keep out intruders remains. The attraction of a lock and key is partly psychological. Recently, some companies have tried computerized locking systems, where smart cards control electronic locks. But people don't like them much. You might accept them at work, but at home, everyone wants the comfort of turning a real key in a lock. So, when one locksmith company created a new electronic system, they made sure to include a real metal key in the design.

**Modern Art**  
I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because, like many people, I find modern art confusing. I know I like some of it, especially furry things, neon light sculptures, and large photographs. Maybe if I knew more about it, I'd have opinions on more pieces. But you're not supposed to analyze it like a school essay. The idea is to let art speak to you. This is a great idea, but it never worked for me. However, this new gallery tries to help visitors understand the reasons behind the artworks. The first thing I noticed were the labels, real labels that explained the context of a piece and what it was trying to say. Instead of just staring at the pictures without understanding, these bits of information helped me get it.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

When adapting novels into films, the process often involves cutting down, condensing, and removing parts of the story. This can be frustrating for writers but also enlightening. While working on a script, I realized that much of the dialogue and narrative in a novel scene could be left out, yet the main point would still be clear. This doesn't mean the original dialogue and description were unnecessary. It's about the different ways stories are told in books and films, and how each uses repetition. In novels, repetition helps readers remember character traits and who is speaking, even if it's not strictly necessary. In stage plays, which are mostly dialogue, real speech is imitated with some style. Some modern plays use so much redundant language that it becomes hard to understand what is being communicated.

**Watching Movies**

Watching movies can be an immersive experience, making you feel part of the film's world. For the duration of the movie, you escape from reality. However, once the film ends and the lights come on, you're back in the real world. This temporary escape makes it hard to take movies seriously as an art form. In the past, many people, including our parents and teachers, saw movies as mere entertainment, not art.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios were a mix of different buildings, with a confusing layout. There were a few permanent landmarks like the Script Department, but many small, similar rooms were used for meetings. These rooms were hard to tell apart, and finding your way around was difficult. The studio had no clear main entrance, which added to the confusion. However, strangers were rare because the studio didn't encourage visitors. Employees knew their way around, and together they created films that offered audiences a temporary escape from everyday life.

**Film-makers**

Many people dream of making movies. Bookshops are filled with guides on scriptwriting and film production, and universities offer courses. Competitions offer cameras like the one Robert Rodriguez used to make El Mariachi, a film that cost $7,000 and launched his career. Rodriguez's success story is a dream come true. He recalls his 23rd birthday, thinking he had only a few years to make his breakthrough film, comparing himself to Orson Welles and Steven Spielberg. In the past, filmmakers took time to mature, working behind the scenes before directing. John Huston was 35 when he made his first film, and Fred Zinnemann found success in his forties. Today, without studio support, aspiring filmmakers often have to be independent and resourceful.

In those days, council houses covered the western side of the city. They were rows of cramped, dull homes made of orange half-brick or pale white stucco. In the summer, chemicals from the May and Baker factory, two miles away, would fill the air with a strong sulfur smell. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he walked up to someone's front door. 

Most of my early life is a blur, but I do remember sitting, or maybe balancing, near an upstairs window, watching the houses fade into the distance. Later, I have vague memories of faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that might not have been ours, and snow falling over the turrets of a mansion at Earlham. 

My mother often appears in these early memories. I remember her as a small, precise, and often angry woman. I never understood why she was angry, so I couldn't do anything to make her happy. Even as a child, when I went with her to the small shops in Bunnett Square or on longer trips into the city, I sensed something unusual about her personality. She was the most solitary person I have ever known, as alone in a crowded room as she would be on a deserted moor. She also had a strict sense of propriety, which was rare on the West Earlham estate. This sometimes led to intense cleaning sessions or instructions to 'behave properly.' As a child, I didn't understand this moral code, and even now, I'm not sure I do. It meant not walking into neighbors' gardens or damaging their rose bushes, sitting quietly for long periods in the dining room with hands folded, listening to radio programs my mother liked, and following many other rules and restrictions.

Despite her solitude, my mother had a few friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who was obsessed with the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who rarely spoke, and Mrs. Laband, who was livelier but not entirely approved of by the others. It was only later that I realized how poor their company was. They formed a sad group, talking about bad legs, cold weather, and ungrateful children, a category I often felt I belonged to. Looking back, it felt like a heavy burden of the West Earlham houses, my mother and her friends, and the need to 'behave properly' weighed on me, and I felt I had to grow up quickly to escape it. 

Growing up in West Earlham followed a set pattern. Until you were five, you stayed at home, often getting in your parents' way. I remember boring days when I was about four, playing on a rug while my mother sat coldly in an armchair. After your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school, half a mile towards the city. Some lucky children had mothers with old bikes and child seats, but I think my mother let other children in the street take me to school. 

If I remember anything from those early years, it's the summer holidays. Those were the days when you got glimpses of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next door to Mrs. Buddery who told stories about his time in the Merchant Navy, and once, there was a charity fete at a house far away on Christchurch Road. A kind woman gave out lemonade and tried to interest me in something called the League of Pity, a junior charity, I think. But my mother dismissed it, saying the organizers were 'only after your money.' My mother often talked about people having selfish motives, and she had a deep distrust of politicians. If she thought about the House of Commons, she probably imagined it as a place where rich people took money from the public. 

I might be exaggerating, and I might be ignoring her good qualities while focusing on her flaws. But my mother didn't have much kindness; it seemed to have been drained from her. To be fair, she did care about my education. Sometimes on Sundays, she would take me, dressed in my 'good clothes,' on the 85 bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. We would walk through rooms of paintings by the Norwich School of Artists. My mother wasn't completely against this activity and even started to have opinions about the art. I remember her once stopping in front of a painting of a Roman soldier and joking, 'Well, I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!' This was one of the few times I remember her trying to make a joke.

**Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down the odd-numbered side of Philadelphia Avenue. The evening was getting darker, and the air was thick with a light, prickly drizzle. This made my walk feel secretive and sheltered. I knew this side of the street well since childhood. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. My first playmates, all girls, lived in the Kring's and the Pottses' houses. Each house was as familiar to me as the small grooves in the sidewalk that guided rainwater from the roofs to the street. These grooves marked my path when I skated or rode my scooter. As the street sloped down, the houses seemed to reflect a slight drop in social status: the porches were closer to the ground, and the front yards were smaller. Over time, changes occurred: wooden porch railings and pillars were replaced with wrought iron in a vaguely Southern or Spanish style. In Shillington, some houses I remembered as homes had become stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, had turned back into homes. I wondered how the residents adapted to living in spaces that once held merchandise.

**Bachelor Fads**

Rick Gilbert, a furniture designer, lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has typical loft features like exposed brickwork and large doors, which were once used to bring in curtains from trains on the nearby railway. However, Gilbert didn't want an open-plan space, both for practical and aesthetic reasons. In his previous home, his living and working areas were combined, making it hard to separate work from relaxation. So, he divided the space near the entrance with a large sheet of corrugated plastic. This screen hides the office, creates a hallway, and leads the eye to the kitchen in the middle of the flat. Gilbert wanted the kitchen to be a neutral area where he could either cook for friends or make coffee for clients. To balance the modern look of the plastic screen and stainless steel kitchen, he used light wood for the floors. His flat is filled with futuristic chairs and sofas, but also with sentimental and homely furniture from his parents or bought at markets.

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin's life was full of secrets and mysteries, making his nomadic lifestyle a topic of literary debate. Despite this, he was a brilliant and unique writer. His first book, "In Patagonia," published in 1977, is a remarkable work of imagination. It is a travel book that changed the way travel writing was done, with the excitement of a thriller and the charm of romantic fiction. Even in this book, Chatwin mixed fact with fiction, changing details to make stories more interesting or to highlight the book's theme: that through travel, one could discover entire histories that seemed to exist just to captivate future explorers.

**Swimming**

During a warm summer rain in 1996, I hurried across my lawn and took refuge in the pool. As I swam, I watched raindrops create small fountains that turned into bubbles and burst. The best moments were when the storm grew stronger, silencing the birds, and a mist rose from the water as if the pool was reaching up to the sky. It was then that I thought of a long swim across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain's path to the sea, breaking free from the monotony of swimming laps. In our world, many places and things are marked and explained, turning reality into something visual. Walking, cycling, and swimming allow us to reconnect with the wild and mysterious parts of the world by stepping off the beaten path. A swimming journey would let me explore parts of our world that, like darkness, misty woods, or high mountains, still hold mystery.

Text: 'CRYING Charles Darwin believed that crying had no clear purpose in evolution. He was likely wrong. More recent studies suggest crying has social importance. Psychiatrist John Bowlby noted that crying helps build the bond between a mother and her child. Many think that tears, especially in children, show helplessness. But why adults cry is harder to understand. The sound of crying becomes less important than the visual message it sends. In early human groups, crying might have helped build trust and social connections. Tears can also have other reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for people facing great injustice. Sometimes, we cry without meaning to, which can be embarrassing, like when we hear inspiring music or speeches. We might cry during a sentimental movie, but this happens more often when we are with others than when we are alone. The social role of crying seems clear, but research is ongoing.'

**The Heat is On**

We've all heard about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it affect us? Many people know something about global warming, but no one is sure about its exact consequences. A warmer climate will likely change the weather everywhere. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on our planet, changes in climate will significantly affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans have used these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support six billion people. Any changes to these resources are serious. The challenge is understanding how the world will change and what is causing these changes.

Over the last 100 years, human activities have increased the levels of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are linked to global temperatures. These increased levels are likely affecting the global climate, but our limited understanding of the Earth's heat balance makes the current and future situations uncertain. We know that greenhouse gas levels have changed in line with global temperatures over the past 40,000 years, suggesting a strong connection. Evidence shows that the Earth's surface has warmed by about 0.6°C over the past century. Most scientists believe this warming is not natural and is partly due to human pollution.

A lot of research has been done to predict what will happen with higher global temperatures. Most of this research uses computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs). These programs run on powerful computers and use the laws of physics and chemistry to analyze how temperature, pressure, solar radiation, and other factors interact to predict climate conditions for the past, present, or future. However, these models are simplifications of the real world and have many limitations. Their results are only approximate, and they are slow and expensive to use. Part of the problem is that we do not fully understand all the processes of the climate system, although we know it is complex.

Despite these research challenges, most people agree on one important aspect of climate change: the rate of change will be faster than anything we have experienced before. The predictions from GCMs are used to understand the world we will live in over the next few generations. Currently, they suggest that the average global surface temperature will increase by 1°C to 3.5°C by 2100; the average sea level will rise by 15-95 cm; and there will be changes in rainfall patterns. Scientists also expect extreme weather, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts, to become more common in some areas.

These forecasts show the potential impact of climate change on the environment and humans. Climate changes can affect where ecological systems, like forests and grasslands, are located, the species they contain, and their ability to provide benefits that societies depend on. The resources we rely on, such as food production, water, and human settlements, are sensitive to climate changes. The effects, some of which may be irreversible, are likely to be negative in many areas. However, not all impacts will be bad. Some climate change effects might be beneficial. For example, in Australia, research shows that the average wheat yield has increased by about 0.5 tonnes per hectare since 1952, partly due to climate trends. Warmer temperatures have led to fewer frosts, causing less damage to crops.

However, many predicted effects of future climate warming are not beneficial. Small climate changes can affect water availability, either by long-term drying or more frequent droughts. Problems are likely to arise first in dry regions and areas where demand or pollution has already caused shortages. The Mediterranean Basin is one example, where decreasing rainfall trends have been identified in some parts, along with changes in seasonality. In southern Portugal's Alentejo region, more rain is falling in autumn and winter, reducing spring totals.

Another negative effect is likely to be changes to glacial processes, impacting glacier ice, ground ice, and sea ice, which will affect vegetation, wildlife habitats, and human structures. There is a strong possibility that the Arctic's ice cover will melt completely, making marine transport and oil and gas exploration easier but increasing the danger from icebergs.

The most dramatic effect of global warming in the 21st century will likely be rising sea levels. This will be caused by the thermal expansion of the ocean—warmer water takes up more space than cold water—and melting ice. With about half of the world's population living in coastal areas, rising sea levels could have severe consequences. Increased flooding and inundation are the most obvious results, with cities like London, New York, and Tokyo facing significant disruption. Many people could lose their homes and jobs, creating millions of environmental refugees. The most severe consequences could be for small, low-lying island states, which might disappear if worst-case scenarios happen. This would be devastating for the people and cultures of these islands and for the countries that would need to accommodate those displaced.

Text: 'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong both physically and emotionally. This is the type of person needed for the first mission to Mars if millionaire Dennis Tito's plan to launch a spacecraft on 5 January 2018 succeeds. The spacecraft will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars's gravity to return to Earth without using more fuel, as saving fuel is very important. The 2018 date is set because the next chance to launch, when Mars and Earth are in the right positions, won't be until 2031. It's a big challenge, and the race is on to create systems with completely new technologies. If these can be developed quickly, the spacecraft might succeed. But even if it doesn't launch, the work done to reach these goals will still be valuable for future space missions.'

**Aesthetics**

Ironically, the very existence of art, which is essential for developing aesthetic theory, can sometimes hinder our understanding of it. This is because art is often seen as physical objects like buildings, books, paintings, or statues, separate from human experience. However, the true essence of art lies in what it does to our experiences. This misunderstanding can block our understanding of art.

Moreover, the perfection and long-standing admiration of some art pieces create conventions that prevent new insights. Once an art piece becomes a classic, it often gets disconnected from the human conditions that created it and the effects it has on people's lives. When art is separated from its origins and its impact on experience, it becomes difficult to understand its broader significance, which is what aesthetic theory tries to explain. Art is often placed in a separate realm, disconnected from other human efforts and achievements.

A key task for anyone writing about the philosophy of fine arts is to reconnect art with everyday experiences. Just like mountain peaks are part of the earth, art should be seen as part of human experience. Those who study the earth, like geographers and geologists, show how mountains are connected to the earth. Similarly, those who study art should show how it connects to human life.

To truly understand art, we need to temporarily set aside the art objects themselves and focus on the everyday experiences that we don't usually consider aesthetic. We need to take a detour to understand art. Just as one can enjoy flowers without knowing about botany, understanding flowers requires knowledge of soil, air, water, and sunlight. Similarly, to understand art in its highest forms, we must start with the raw experiences that capture our attention and bring us joy.

Many people might be surprised to learn that they enjoy everyday activities partly because of their aesthetic qualities. The arts that resonate most with people today are often not seen as art, like movies, jazz, comic strips, and sensational news stories. When traditional art is confined to museums and galleries, people seek enjoyable experiences in their daily lives. Even those who criticize the museum view of art often share the misconception that art is separate from ordinary life. The best appreciation of art happens when it is closely connected to everyday activities.

**Observing Lions**

People often imagine lions hunting as a perfect team: in the evening light, a group of silent cats jumps from the shadows like skilled hunters and surrounds their prey. Lions seem to be the perfect social animals, putting aside disagreements to work together for a common goal, like catching their next meal. However, after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have a different view. When we began our research in 1978, we wanted to find out why lions hunt together, raise their young, and scare off rivals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many of its offspring survive, then working together might not always be beneficial: if an animal is too generous, others might benefit at its expense. So, why don't the evolutionary rules of self-interest apply to lions? We thought we could solve this question in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. If there were a list of inactive elements like krypton, argon, and neon, we would add lions to it. Therefore, it has taken many research methods to find clues about their behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to get answers to our questions.

**Pop Music Review**

The release of Bedrock's third album was more than just a big moment for a talented but previously unstable band. "New Life" started a movement that changed rock music in this country for the rest of the decade. Gone were the serious, plain styles and loud guitars of the past; in came a lighter mix of melodic local styles. The album combined social commentary and strong emotions with the sounds of fairground organs and northern brass bands. Humor and irony were prominent, as were voices that didn't hide their origins. The album showed Bedrock as skilled collectors and observers, and a clever team of songwriters. They playfully explored traditional English themes like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. But the album's real strength was in its gentle, sad songs like "So Low," a beautiful tune about weather, and "To the Brink," a serious ballad. The beauty of "New Life" is its consistently high quality - 16 tracks with no filler, which is rare in the era of long CDs.

**Extract from an Autobiography**

As a child, I was always intrigued by stories of "The Sibyl," those wise women who had great influence in ancient times. At first, I only knew of one from a story my mother told me. An old woman from Cumae offered Tarquin, King of Rome, nine books for 300 gold pieces. He refused, and she burned three of them, offering him six for the same price. When he refused again, she burned three more books. He bought the last three for the full 300 gold pieces. Even then, I understood there was a deep truth in the story - a lesson in salesmanship and life. I was sometimes a lonely only child. I would ask to play with other children and be refused. My mother told me to do something so interesting that other kids would want to join me. It worked. It was another lesson I've never forgotten. When I got the chance to write a travel book, I had to find something I was interested in, something relevant to my life. I'm a reluctant traveler - I sent my editor a long list of places I didn't want to go. In the end, I'm only interested in ruins because I like traveling through time in my mind.

**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**

When you submit your manuscript, it will likely join a pile waiting to be sorted. This pile is called the "slush pile." The person sorting it is usually a junior editor or an experienced freelancer who works part-time. Neither has much influence, but they want to find something original - the junior to make a name for themselves and find an author, the freelancer to keep their job. If they think your novel is promising, they will pass it to a more senior editor, and it will eventually be discussed at a meeting. The editor will need to justify accepting your novel based on its quality and potential sales. They will also consider if you, as an author, seem like a long-term prospect, which you will have assured them of in your letter. Another important factor is how promotable you are, as a new novel needs all the help it can get. Publishers often like to meet a potential author before making an offer.

**Advertising on Trial**

If you worked in an advertising agency during the early 1990s, you probably faced one of the hardest times in your career. The economic recession was severe, lasting longer and hitting harder than expected, especially in industrialized countries. In Britain, 1991 was particularly tough: the economy shrank, interest rates were very high, consumer spending dropped, over half a million people lost their jobs, and about 75,000 homes were repossessed. Every business felt the impact, with some industries like vehicle and construction seeing a 30% decline. Many people and companies across different countries suffered.

Advertising professionals were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who remained employed felt significant pressure. They were expected to help boost company profits and were closely watched by their colleagues and bosses. They also had to work with smaller budgets, being told to achieve more with less. Despite these challenges, the importance of marketing grew. Companies started focusing more on creating products and services that customers actually wanted, rather than just what was convenient to produce. This shift meant that marketing activities finally received the attention they deserved, raising the status of marketing professionals but also increasing their responsibilities.

Marketing was increasingly seen as a solution to all problems, even though it wasn't. With about half of marketing budgets spent on advertising, the pressure was on advertising professionals to deliver results. The 1980s were a great time for advertising, but the early 1990s brought the industry's worst downturn in a generation. This was partly due to the economic climate, but also because clients began questioning the value of advertising. They wanted to know exactly what they were getting for their money and what return they were seeing on their investment. Advertising was under scrutiny like never before.

Clients demanded better strategies, targeting, creativity, media placement, and thinking from advertising agencies. They wanted the best people working hard to produce outstanding work. This meant that advertising professionals faced the same challenge as their clients: doing more with less. The recession made it difficult to produce effective advertising, with controversies over production costs and a reluctance to take risks, which are often essential for good advertising.

Other challenges included demographic changes, the growing power of retailers, changing consumer needs, the rise of sponsorship, stricter legal restrictions on advertising, and the challenge of advertising abroad. These factors forced advertisers to reconsider the effectiveness of their work. The pressure to make advertising more effective was greater than ever.

Unfortunately, help for those wanting to improve their advertising was not readily available. Companies and agencies were too busy dealing with the situation to share their insights, and those who succeeded were reluctant to reveal their secrets. Conferences and seminars offered some help, but books on advertising often failed to provide practical guidance. They tended to overestimate the quality and value of advertising work, which didn't help those responsible for making it successful.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was at university, I decided I wanted to become a chef. This was an unusual choice among my peers. Cooking wasn't considered a desirable job. On the surface, being a chef seems unattractive. Chefs are known for having tough lives: the work is long, stressful, and not well-paid. But these factors didn't discourage me. I was unhappy at university. The studies were difficult, and the social life felt closed-off and self-important. Being a chef seemed like the perfect escape from the intellectual and social pretensions of college life. It offered a seriousness and honesty that I felt was missing. However, my desire to cook wasn't just a reaction to being a student. It also represented an artistic ideal for me. I first experienced this ideal when I ate at a famous London restaurant. It was eye-opening. I still remember the starter I had. After that meal, I felt like bowing down in admiration to the chef who made it. I felt uplifted for days. This experience sparked a strong desire in me to learn the secrets of this amazing art. I turned my student life into a preparation for entering the culinary world. My history degree felt like a distraction from my true passion. I educated myself by reading cookbooks, exploring markets and delicatessens, and cooking elaborate meals.

**The Swimming Instructor**

The school's swimming instructor was a former drill sergeant, small and muscular, with tattooed arms. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced this move until the lesson ended. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. The instructor was strict, and every time I surfaced, he criticized me: "Don't look down, look up!" "Keep your legs straight." "Point your toes!" The following week, I went up to the high diving board. It was fixed, and its front edge bent slightly downward. It seemed incredibly high as I stood there, trying to gather my courage. Gradually, the echoing voices faded, and I felt as if I were in a silent bubble. I waved my arms as I had been taught, tried to look up, not down, and launched myself into the air. For a brief moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, I collapsed awkwardly, and my legs went everywhere. The instructor looked at me with disdain and shook his head. But even he couldn't dampen my excitement. "That's what they mean by 'free as a bird'," I thought.

**The Traveller**

For those of us who value a comfortable bed, running water, and the likelihood of living at least until tomorrow, the idea of being a traveler is both puzzling and fascinating. These are people who are drawn to the dangerous allure of the unknown, who choose to risk their lives by climbing steep, icy mountains prone to avalanches; who sail alone in fragile boats through towering waves; who will eat maggots and river insects if nothing better is available, and who can live for months in the shadow and promise of the unknown. It's easy to dismiss such people as oddities, which they are, and to categorize them with the truly eccentric: hermits, freefall divers, or even writers. Their existence is undeniable, but the strange, uncomfortable world they inhabit is far removed from our everyday experience and can be dismissed, we tell ourselves, as irrelevant. We can shrug and return to our world of microwave ovens and answering machines, grateful that the only risks to our health are predictable ones, like dashing across a busy street.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, saying it is not his natural environment, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He doesn't claim to be a top sailor, though he is clearly competent. His main reason for sailing is that, as a writer, he enjoys writing about his sailing experiences. Sailing provides plenty of challenges and achievements for him to write about. Raban's small boat has an electronic device that gives sailors their exact position anywhere on Earth. While he appreciates this tool, Raban has a somewhat old-fashioned view of other sailing aids. He believes the invention of the compass was a mistake, causing a "fundamental rift in the relationship between man and sea." Raban argues that since the compass came into use about a thousand years ago, it has become the main focus for sailors, meaning they no longer need to study the waves and feel the sea. The ocean, once full of activity, is now just a space to cross. Since the helmsman's job is just to keep a steady course, he can be replaced for long periods by an autopilot. This might be why Raban had time to observe the waves so closely.

**Holiday Reading**

Summer gives us two of life's great pleasures: leaving home and reading books. These joys are closely linked. Books help us feel more connected to the world. We can relate our experiences to those in books from long ago or faraway places because there are fewer types of people than there are people themselves. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can describe situations we thought were unique to us, or express our thoughts with clarity and accuracy that we can't. What is unclear in us is clearly expressed in their words, especially if the book is from a different time or place. We feel thankful to these authors for helping us understand ourselves. Through reading and travel, we break free from routine. Our eyes are most open when we first arrive in a new place, or when we read a great book that shows us things we hadn't noticed before. Our mind becomes alert to new ideas and feelings. We notice the colors of the sky, the changes in a person's face, a friend's insincerity, or a hidden sadness we didn't know we had.

**Author's Note**

These travel reflections were published as articles in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I've restored some small cuts made by the editor to fit the page, but added little else. I've corrected a few mistakes, but only if they were details I should have gotten right. Looking back, I could have made more improvements, but that process would never end. For example, in the second article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell a year later. If I rewrote it to predict this, it would seem like I knew the future, which I didn't. Like any traveler, I was there at that moment, unaware of what would happen next, and focused on understanding what had already happened. This is the real story of mass travel: the world opening up to people who only need a ticket to explore it. But I believe my fellow travelers weren't completely unaware. Even a postcard can have a purpose.

**Ecotourism**

If there were awards for tourism phrases that have been overused, 'ecotourism' would win. The term appeared in the early 1980s, as people became more aware of the environment and tour operators realized travelers wanted to avoid harming the places they visited. It quickly became a popular marketing term. Now, 'ecotourism' can mean anything from living with remote tribes for two weeks to a one-hour boat trip in Australia. Any tour involving culture, nature, wildlife, or mild adventure might be called ecotourism. The original idea was to help people make informed choices, but without clear rules, many travelers are confused about what ecotourism really means.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost the notebook from my Transylvanian journey for 50 years, but found it again by luck. It helped me remember that time and write about it, but it wasn't as helpful as it could have been. In Transylvania, I had an easier time than expected, moving from one welcoming house to another, often staying for weeks. When I stopped traveling, I stopped writing, thinking there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again when I moved on, and sometimes only made brief notes instead of detailed stories. Worried that I might have mixed up details when writing this book, I added some warnings and uncertainties. But then I realized this wasn't a guidebook, so I let the story unfold naturally without too many explanations.

**Fashion**

Fashion is often thought of as a modern idea, linked to the growth of capitalism in the 1800s and 1900s. However, many fashion historians argue that fashion, in terms of style and design, has a long history. They often start with the rise of markets and trade in the 1500s and 1600s. As societies have become more complex, populations have grown, and new ways to make different types of clothing and accessories have been invented, the meanings of clothing have also become more complex. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing or accessory means. For example, a man's suit, which seems to be a symbol of uniformity, can have very different meanings depending on the context and the people involved.

**Writer**

Stories about publishers fighting over new manuscripts have given a false impression of what life is like for most novelists. For those of us not at the top of the best-seller lists, there are two ways to make a living. The smartest among us write in the evenings and have other full-time jobs that are secure even if the book doesn't sell well or become a movie. Others, like me, do various literary jobs, such as teaching, running workshops, and writing articles like this one. I've heard of a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I've never gotten anything like that. Somehow, by juggling part-time jobs, using credit cards, and often relying on the generosity of people mentioned in Acknowledgements, the novel gets written.

**Sudden Fame**

The small venues we were playing at across the country started selling out, and extra security was needed to manage the growing number of screaming fans. We had to use secret entrances to the places we performed to avoid being mobbed. On the few nights we weren't working, it was hard to leave the house without being chased by fans. In just a few days, we became celebrities. Our fans watched our every move, and our management and others took care of all our needs. Even though I was always shy, this was replaced by a strange over-confidence that only naturally shy people in similar situations can understand. In short, I was emotionally overwhelmed.

**Music - The Future Challenges**

Technology keeps changing how we live, work, and enjoy our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, we had more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. However, live music performances and full-time jobs for musicians have decreased. It's clear that more people will have access to music because it meets many human needs. Music is part of every major national event and offers many activities for individuals. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn musical instruments.

I believe people will continue to learn instruments. The music industry is a big source of income in Britain, and musical skills will remain important for jobs, especially in media. Besides job opportunities, playing an instrument can help develop skills early on. Research in the USA shows that listening to or making music can improve spatial reasoning, a part of intelligence. Although these findings need more support, studies in Europe show that group music lessons can improve social skills and concentration in children, including those with behavioral issues. Further research is looking into whether playing an instrument can help develop skills that can be used in other areas, like good study habits and organization.

In the short term, there will still be a demand for music lessons. But what about the long term? Will there be changes, and what might they be? I think two things are likely. First, people will listen to a wider variety of music, with new genres mixing different styles. Second, technology will be used more in composing and performing music, making it easier for people to create music without needing as much technical skill. This might reduce the need for live performances and musicians focused only on performing live. At the same time, more people of all ages will want to make music, often in community settings that reflect local musical traditions.

To prepare for this future, the music profession needs to change. Instrumental teaching should adapt to help more people learn different instruments throughout their lives. This will affect the music curriculum and how progress is measured, requiring them to stay relevant for a wider audience. They will need to include a broader range of musical skills. Musicians will need training to inspire and teach people of all ages, work with large and diverse groups, and develop communication, social, entrepreneurial, and management skills for community work. This is a big change from traditional methods and will require accountability to the public. Positively, this is a chance for music educators to show the quality of music teaching available.

Finally, we need to raise the importance of music. Music is vital in our lives, but it's often overlooked. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**

Actors sometimes face criticism and mockery. This often happens when they talk about their work in interviews, as required by their film or theatre companies. Instead of using simple, meaningful responses like dancer Pavlova's famous reply, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it," actors often fall into using clichés or get caught up in gossip. Paul Scofield, a respected actor, once wrote to a friend that an actor's work is only alive and interesting when performed. Discussing it makes it seem theoretical and empty. Acting has no strict rules, except perhaps being audible. With each new play, actors start fresh, learning and growing with the characters and the writer's insights. Once a play ends, actors feel empty until the next project. This emptiness is evident in any discussion about theatre work.

**A Review of Hamlet**

Adrian Lester's portrayal of Hamlet is a delicate balance between youth and adulthood. His performance is simple yet confident, showing great skill and control. Lester's interpretation of Hamlet is of a tense, edgy young man, full of controlled anger, wit, and humor, making him both intimidating and endearing. His performance is subtle but clearly skilled. Notice how his body language, like his stiff arms, suggests a character ready to come to life. Similarly, Handy's portrayal of Horatio gives the impression of being moved by an inner force. This raises questions about acting and behavior: Is acting an imitation or a creation of real behavior? What drives these characters, both morally and physically? This is a key question in theatre.

**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**

This director's rehearsal process begins with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager projects the script onto a screen. Actors sit quietly, absorbing the words. When it's their turn, they look at the screen, understand the first phrase, think about its meaning, and wait for the impulse to speak. For example, with the line "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" actors breathe, let the thought settle, and visualize a scene, like waiting in line for a concert. They find the impulse to speak, which the director calls "The pathway to the line." Impulses can come from external or internal sources. Actors should look into the eyes of their scene partner and consider their character's situation. The director encourages actors to approach this with an open mind, without pre-planning or judgment, trusting that something will naturally happen.

**The Perfect Theatre**

The perfect theatre should make you feel that your presence matters. Attending a live performance is an event, and the staff should recognize this. It's disheartening if the staff treats it as just another job. The theatre should create a connection between the performer and the audience. No audience member should feel they have a poor view of the actor. It's important that they are close enough to see, hear, and feel connected to the performance. The design of the auditorium is crucial; it should complement the human voice and body. If the space overwhelms the actors, it fails to honor the human form central to drama. Many theatres from the late 19th century got this right, creating spaces that embrace the stage. Theatres with a sense of history, like worn stone steps in a church, convey layers of human presence. Regarding plays, you can't cater to everyone. Audiences don't always know what they want to see. When you go to the theatre, you want to experience something unexpected, something you couldn't imagine at home.

**Paul Simon**

In the 1950s, rock and roll was mainly popular among young people, but its real significance was how it affected the middle class and older generations. It also set the stage for future rock stars, who listened to it with amazement, knowing it would be a big part of their lives. For Paul Simon and other young people in the US, the main way to hear this exciting new music was through Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. Freed's show was essential listening for many future rock stars. Like young John Lennon in Liverpool, who listened to Radio Luxembourg to hear rock and roll, Paul Simon was captivated by the music on Freed's show. He was ready to move from just listening to music to creating his own.

**Snow**

There was no clear path, but I thought I would be safe if I walked carefully. The wind was strong, pushing me down as I slipped on the icy surface. Suddenly, the snow beneath me collapsed. I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had formed a thin layer over a gap between two rocks, which melted and left a fragile crust that I broke through. I pulled myself out, feeling shaken and worried, thinking about what I would have done if the hole had been much deeper. I leaned against a pine tree sticking out of the snow to assess my situation. In an hour, I had only covered about half a mile. It was clear I needed to change my plan.

**Qualitative Research**

There are many books now that try to guide researchers on qualitative research. While a lot is written about collecting data, these books often don't explain how to analyze it. There is a lot of mystery around how researchers analyze their data. So, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to talk about their methods. The goal was to share insights into the process of analyzing qualitative data, not to create a guidebook. This involves making hidden methods more clear. Although this seems simple, it is quite challenging. We allowed our contributors to present their work in various styles, including personal stories and more formal approaches.

**Screen Learning**

Recently, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a strange way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look fierce, saying, "I'm a little dinosaur." He was acting out a scene from a TV show he had watched. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, and he didn't recall much. Many people are eager to use the internet and computers for learning, but is learning from a screen effective? One writer shared his experience with an interactive program he tried with his son. The father read the words carefully, but his son was more interested in playing with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned something. Television, as shown by my son and his noodles, is a medium that suggests ideas rather than teaches them directly. Research shows that learning happens best in an environment where there is dialogue with teachers or parents. It needs guidance. While new technology can be useful for teaching, formal education still plays a crucial role.

**Hollywood**

By 1918, most of the world's film-making had moved to Hollywood. Local people in Los Angeles didn't like this change, seeing it as a negative influence. However, they eventually accepted it because of the success it brought. In Hollywood, success is measured by how much money a film makes. Hollywood can recognize a good film, one that might make someone a star but will definitely make money. In less than a century, Hollywood transformed from a small village to a town as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. Physically, it has changed a lot; a hundred years ago, you would walk through orange groves to get to the village store. Yet, in some ways, it remains like a village, with a narrow focus on films. People there talk about how much money films make, who is dating whom, and who is involved in which project. Successful people often try to leave, working there but living elsewhere. Still, Hollywood is the place where almost everyone in show business eventually goes.

**Photography**

Photography was created by 19th-century artists as a new form of art. These artists wanted a lasting and accurate record of what they saw around them, and they found it in photography. The combination of light, lenses, shutters, and chemically treated surfaces produced images that were more lasting and detailed than what painters could create in weeks or months. This caused concern among other artists, and art critics argued that photography wasn't true art because it relied too much on mechanical processes. Despite this criticism, photographers believed they had discovered a new art form. They used photography to interpret the world and present their vision of nature and people, just as other artists used brushes and pencils.

**Book Illustration**

In the past, it was common for every children's book to have illustrations, even novels for older readers. However, as time went on, fewer books were illustrated because print runs became shorter. Children's publishing was still active, but it was often done on a low budget, leading to a lot of routine and average work. However, the best artists always did their best work. The collection of black-and-white illustrations from this time is a mix of ordinary and exceptional work, a great resource for research or browsing. The best works are likely to be shown to the public again, either through reissues of books or exhibitions of original illustrations. There are signs that interest in this period is returning, and publishers might see the potential for reprinting classic children's book illustrations or creating new editions using the original artwork.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**

A while back, a website warned about the dangers of public check-ins—telling everyone online where you are. The message was clear: you might think you're just saying, "Hey, I'm here," but you're also letting everyone know you're not at home, which might not be safe. This highlighted the potential problems of sharing too much online. The internet offers amazing chances to share our lives with a global audience, promising things like wealth and fame. So, we dive into the online world, sharing confessions, photos, and stories. But soon, we realize it's a crowded and risky place, and we can get lost. 

Feeling down? Maybe, but don't lose hope. There's a guide to this future, created by early internet users. In the early days of the web, they explored these challenges. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the ups and downs of fame—long before social media existed. These early bloggers have already experienced what many of us are now facing. Before we forget their stories, it's worth learning from them. As the saying goes, those who don't learn from history are doomed to repeat it.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the "WWW," as it was called then. The web was mostly used by students, scientists, and a few curious teens like him. It was created at CERN in Switzerland to help researchers share their work. But Hall saw it as a way to share his life. He built a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and people were drawn to his bold use of this new medium. Hall's rule was simple: if you crossed his path, you might end up on his site; no topic was off-limits. While it was certainly the work of someone who liked attention, there was also a discipline and beauty to it that could be considered art.

One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video titled "Dark Night." He shared that he had fallen deeply in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was given an ultimatum: "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He chose to stop blogging, but the issue remains. Sharing online is great, but if you think it will make people like you, you'll be let down.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague anonymously sent her blog to all the vice presidents at her company, including those she had criticized, and she lost her job. Experts call this the "online distribution effect": the feeling that we can say things online that we wouldn't say in person. But our online and real lives are connected. Ignoring this can lead to serious mistakes.

Armstrong's story ended well. Though she was upset and stopped blogging for a while, she got married and restarted her blog, focusing on her family. Now, she's a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. Once an example of online mistakes, she has become skilled at sharing her life carefully. Armstrong learned an important lesson: just because the web lets us say anything, doesn't mean we should.

Text: 'Enough Sleep? Many people today feel tired all the time. In busy and wealthy countries, more people are having trouble sleeping and feeling anxious. In the USA, research shows that 40 million people have long-term sleep problems. In Britain, some popular books have characters who can't sleep or are set in sleep research labs. People are interested in sleep: how it works, why we need it, and what happens when we can't sleep. A main concern is that people need more sleep. A top sleep researcher says, 'People sleep less when they're busy. They wake up early to avoid traffic.' A sleep researcher did an experiment where he let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to settle at about eight hours of sleep. This shows they were catching up on lost sleep. In Europe, a university in the English Midlands studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise affects sleep, and the dangers of driving when tired. They find volunteers through student newspapers, pay them, and ask them to change their sleep habits. Dr. Louise Reyner reassures people who worry about the electrodes on their heads. The lab is more interested in physical effects. They have a driving simulator in a dark room. Volunteers come at 2pm, when people naturally feel sleepy, after a short or no sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road on the screen seems endless, the sun is bright, and the room is warm. Many deny they will fall asleep, but Dr. Reyner has videos showing they do. At first, they sit upright, eyes open. Then they blink more and nod off. Each time, they wake up suddenly, but the car has already veered off the road. Coffee might help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can make you a safe driver for over half an hour, even with no sleep. She suggests alertness products like tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated gum, especially for shift workers. What do we know for sure about sleep? Humans, like other mammals, sleep in a daily cycle. During sleep, we go through four stages, from light to deep sleep. Dreams usually happen in the lightest sleep, and the brain stops the body from moving to prevent injuries. Beyond this, we have theories. Sleep might repair the body, restore muscles, or rest the brain's creative part. But these might also happen when we're awake but relaxed, so it's unclear. Scientists are sure women sleep about half an hour longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but they don't know why. When asked about the purpose of sleep, some researchers say, 'Sleep helps us pass time safely.' Sleep patterns may have been different in the past. A history professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people had different sleep routines. They went to bed at nine or ten, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for an hour, and then slept again. This break was a time for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poorest people benefited most from this quiet time. By the 17th century, with more artificial light, the rich started sleeping in one long stretch, which was more efficient. The industrial revolution made most people work longer hours in lit buildings, changing sleep patterns. Outside Europe and America, the old sleep pattern was common until recently. In some non-western cultures, there are no strict bedtimes. People sleep for a few hours, then get up. A full night's sleep is not common. In some tribal societies, noise and the need to watch for danger make continuous sleep impossible. It seems people everywhere need more sleep.'

Title: A Former Racing Driver's Reflection

I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots, each costing $800, while standing on rocks in the Arizona desert. I had the full cowboy outfit, but I knew I wasn't a real cowboy. As I looked at the Arizona mountains, I realized I didn't belong there. I had flown in from Denver early in the morning, feeling like I might look like a cowboy from the sky. But that feeling disappeared when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He wore a sweaty T-shirt, needed a shave, and carried a dirty bag. He noticed my new boots, raised an eyebrow, and left without a word.

I wished there was an outfit I could wear that would make me feel like I belonged, no matter where I was. I loved being a racing driver, but I don't race anymore. I can't even if I wanted to. So, what do I do now? I thought I had other options, but they vanished when I needed them. I considered becoming a commentator for racing events, but there were already many former drivers doing that. I also tried starting a business selling classic cars, but it didn't work out because nobody was buying.

Being an "ex" anything is tough. People don't want to hear about how I almost became a World Champion. Even if I had won, people would only listen for a short time. Last year's champion is old news. I don't want sympathy, and I don't get any. I had a good career, made money, and saved enough. But I miss the thrill of racing, the fast cars, and the excitement. I miss the attention from fans and reporters. Being famous, even a little, was nice. Businessmen and politicians liked to say they knew me, and kids wanted my autograph.

Now that I don't race, my phone rarely rings. I have a lot of free time. I looked at the blue sky and noticed some small birds in a cactus. They seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I realized I had a lot to learn, just like a fake cowboy in fancy boots.

**Vancouver**

In the past decade, many people from around the world have moved to Vancouver, located in western Canada. In the evenings, locals enjoy walking through the city, and if you join them, you'll likely hear many different languages. People are attracted to Vancouver for its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and mountains, clean and safe environment, and opportunities for education and work. Although some people complain about the rapid construction of new buildings, it's clear that newcomers and the growing tourism industry have contributed to the city's revival. Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. While this name is used less now, Vancouver is more of a gateway than ever before.

**Putting Pen to Paper**

Journalists, like myself, often aren't great at writing letters. Some say it's because we don't like writing for free, but I don't think we're that focused on money. It's more likely because, in our work, we aim to create a strong impact, which makes it hard to write spontaneous letters. True creative artists, who don't consciously focus on the impact (even if they rewrite a passage many times), don't have this issue. I believe that understanding the effect of one's words is the true test of a real artist. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't consciously think about how the mix of long words made them powerful, yet it showed his greatness as a writer.

**Supermarket Opening**

In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A soap opera star, a radio DJ, or a minor royal would often be invited to cut the ribbon. Nowadays, new supermarkets open so frequently that celebrities are no longer needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can do it for free? Last week, elderly shoppers didn't care who opened the new Superbuy store, as long as they were first in line. One customer, who knew an employee, said the first five men would receive a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly among the crowd, making those at the front feel pleased and those who arrived later feel envious.

**Citizen Kane**

When the film *Citizen Kane* was finally released in 1941, it faced a lot of controversy. The release was delayed because the distributors were worried about the reaction of William Randolph Hearst, who was thought to be the inspiration for the film. Despite receiving mostly excellent reviews, the film was not a commercial hit at first. It was television that later made it popular again. *Citizen Kane* is perhaps the most influential film, inspiring many people to become filmmakers. This is especially impressive because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles believed its success came from not knowing what he could or couldn't do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a remarkable team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper tycoon similar to Hearst, Welles saw it as a perfect opportunity for himself as both director and actor, and he took it with great enthusiasm.

**Dermot and Carmel**

Dermot noticed that Carmel seemed a bit strange that morning. He mentioned twice that he might be late and not to worry if he stopped by the golf club on his way home. He needed to chat with someone, and it was the best place for it. Carmel nodded in agreement but seemed distracted, as if she didn't really hear or understand him. "Will you be okay? What are you planning to do today?" he asked. She smiled and said, "It's funny you ask. I was just thinking I have nothing to do today, so I might stroll downtown and look at the shops. It feels almost sinful to just idle away the day." Dermot smiled back, "You deserve to enjoy yourself. And as I said, if I'm late, I won't need anything to eat. So don't go to any trouble." "No, that's fine," she replied.

**Title Race**

Human nature can be quite amusing. A recent study showed that job titles are a major cause of jealousy and tension at work. A survey by a top recruitment firm found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees agree that titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey revealed that 70% of office workers would prefer a more 'motivational' or 'professional' job title over a pay raise. If our desire for impressive titles is so strong that it surpasses even our basic greed, we are in a difficult situation. In today's world, no one wants to be seen as inferior. The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are often just fancy terms.

I was in Vienna to take photographs. At that time, taking photos was not just my job; it was a big part of my life.
