I loved how light could change the look of things and how a single photo could capture the essence of a place or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo, and as long as I had film in my camera, there was a chance I might. My routine was simple: finish one roll of film, load another, and keep looking for that perfect shot. This had been my way for a long time.

I once got lucky with a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well. It became popular, appearing in newspapers and magazines worldwide. That brief success led me to go freelance, which seemed like a smart move. However, life outside photography didn't go as planned, and the mid-nineties weren't as successful as I had hoped, even after my photo made it to the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more newsworthy. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which wasn't bad.

The Vienna assignment came by chance. I had taken photos in London for a picture book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons," which included London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. The Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left the Vienna job, and they offered it to me. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers. I was happy to go because things at home weren't great. A week in snowy Vienna sounded good to me.

They put me up at the Europa Hotel in the heart of the old city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife during a busy summer, but this time, in cold January, it felt different. I knew I would enjoy it and take great photos. On the first day, I didn't take any pictures. Instead, I rode the trams around the city, getting a feel for the place. The weather was cold and set, like the grand old buildings of the city. I hadn't seen Schussner's work from other seasons because I wanted this to be my Vienna. I waited for the right moment to take my photos.

The next morning, I was out at dawn. Fresh snow had made Stephansplatz beautifully white and almost empty. I hadn't figured out how to capture the cathedral in one shot because its spire was tall and its base was massive. I might have to settle for a partial shot, but in that weather, it could still be magical. Photography has always had a magical quality, even for the pioneers in the 19th century. Watching a photo develop in a dark room is mysterious, and that sense of mystery stays with you forever. So, when something unexpected happened at Stephansplatz that morning, it didn't really surprise me.

**Kinetic Art Rejoice**

Something amazing has happened: London's serious Hayward Gallery has become a place of wonder. This change wasn't due to a big-budget, flashy show, but rather a unique look into a nearly forgotten part of the last 60 years. A new exhibition explores the history of kinetic art, which is art focused on movement, in the 20th century. It shows that creating art that moves or explores movement has been an ongoing, though often unnoticed, theme in some of the most interesting creative work of this century. Curator Guy Brett, who has studied this topic for a long time, has gathered a wonderful collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films on kinetic art. These are presented with little text, allowing visitors to enjoy making their own connections and discoveries.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art attracts many people who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his work is figurative and easy to understand, or because it offers an escape from everyday life. Some people might be more interested in Hockney's charming personality and clever words, which make him popular in the media. Some critics think Hockney is overrated, but others argue that his popularity doesn't mean his work lacks depth. Hockney himself knows his limits and believes it's not fair to judge his work by an abstract idea of greatness. He doesn't claim to be a great artist and understands that only time will tell his true place in art history.

**Window-shopping - an art exhibition**

Recently, I've seen many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and some mediocre. What bothers me are shows that push a hidden agenda, suggesting a common attitude among certain artists. Sometimes this works, revealing new trends, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was the opposite of this. With seven artists, I took over a space in an empty warehouse. "Window-shopping" was a collection of individual artworks connected only by their claim to be art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley's video camera experiment flickered on a monitor. These works didn't fit into a themed exhibition but complemented each other through their differences. I didn't make any big statements about contemporary art, but maybe there aren't any to make about an activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**

People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it might ruin their experience. Some say that art historians, who focus on theory, ignore the pleasure of looking and the act of creativity. This idea is like thinking that knowing a recipe's ingredients and cooking method takes away from the taste of a dish. Enjoying something doesn't mean we can't also understand it deeply. In fact, knowing more about what we see might increase our pleasure. Pleasure is complex, and how we experience it can be questioned. It's also influenced by history. Our preferences are shaped by the values of the society we live in. While it's important to appreciate the sensory and instinctive responses to art, the idea that thinking undermines feeling is an outdated view from a time when art was seen as separate from thought.

**Metals**  
Stone Age people might have first been interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, when one of our early ancestors found a shiny yellow pebble. It didn't feel like a regular stone, but it was beautiful. This is how gold might have become important to early humans. Gold is easy to shape, so it quickly became a valuable material. Copper might have been discovered by accident too. Once people realized how useful copper tools were, they eagerly searched for copper ores and learned how to extract the metal. This led to the development of metalworking, which greatly improved their way of life.

**St Ives**  
We walked down the winding, cobbled street into the town, carrying our bags and leaning against the strong wind. The waves crashed over the promenade, and the streets were empty. All the windows in the waterfront cottages were shut tight against the storm. We had seen the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on the small train. The dark grey skies made visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car seem like a bad idea. I had convinced my friend to come with promises of beautiful coastal walks and cozy evenings by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**  
Studying the past is difficult because it is gone. The people who lived through good and bad times are no longer here. The reasons they settled in certain places or formed communities are forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we can't test our ideas with real experiments on past cultures. We can't watch the past like a movie. However, computer modelling helps us recreate ancient landscapes and fill them with virtual communities. These digital people have some needs and abilities like real humans. We can set rules for them and change conditions, like reducing rainfall or increasing population, to see how these virtual societies react.

**Vervet Monkeys**  
Cheney and Seyfarth observed a group of vervet monkeys. One day, the dominant male noticed a strange male monkey nearby. This stranger wanted to join the group, which could mean trouble for the current leader. To keep the stranger away, the dominant male used a clever trick. Whenever the stranger tried to approach, the leader gave an alarm call that vervets use to warn about leopards. This scared the stranger back into the trees. The trick worked well until the leader made a mistake: he gave the alarm call while casually walking in the open, revealing his deception.

**What Cats Catch**  
In the English village of Felmersham, people collected the prey caught by their cats. Over a year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals. An American professor saw these numbers and estimated that cats in Britain might be killing 100 million birds and small mammals each year. However, this calculation is misleading. Most cats live in towns, have smaller territories, and catch fewer prey than the rural cats in the survey. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes. Many people feed birds in winter, and gardens provide nesting sites, keeping bird populations higher than natural levels. The survey showed that cats are significant predators but not destroying Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**  
Buffaloes are very important to marsh people and are well cared for. Every morning, the buffaloes leave their sleeping area slowly and with groans, heading to the reed beds. They stand on the edge of the platform, complaining about the day's work, until the leader finally moves into the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget their purpose and rest there, making low sounds. Eventually, they start swimming, appearing almost submerged, with only their noses above water. They spend the day among the reeds, eating leisurely.

**PICASSO, Pablo - The Soles, 1940**  
In early 1940, Picasso painted several still lifes of fish while staying in the fishing port of Royan. One painting shows a fishmonger's slab with a crab and some soles. The sea creatures look alive despite their situation. The painting is complex, with overlapping and interlocking transparent shapes. The thin, delicately brushed paint and cool colors create a calm, underwater feel. However, there is tension in the painting, with fish showing their teeth and a crab with open claws, suggesting an impending battle. The sharp forms and even a chain around one fish add a sense of danger, giving the painting a symbolic meaning.

Photography has been around for about 150 years and has been used to capture all parts of human life. In this short time, photography has grown in its ability to capture moments in time and space, allowing us to see both fleeting moments and vast or tiny details. It has shown us images from faraway places on Earth, distant parts of the solar system, and the complex social issues of modern life. Photography has become a powerful way to express the human experience.

However, using images to record events has a much longer history. The earliest examples of pictorial recording date back to the Upper Palaeolithic period, about 35,000 years ago. We don't know exactly why early humans created cave paintings—whether they were recording real events, using them for magic to increase animals for hunting, serving as religious symbols, or simply to decorate their living spaces. But images have always been closely linked to human culture.

Throughout history, people have questioned how accurate visual images are and their importance in society. The saying "seeing is believing" has always given special importance to images. When photography was invented in the mid-19th century, it promised to provide a truthful visual record automatically. The camera, working like the human eye, was seen as a machine that could capture a fixed image, very close to what we actually see. This was considered a natural phenomenon and a cultural achievement, producing images that artists had long tried to create by hand.

Because of photography's realistic nature, it was thought that everyone could understand photographs, leading to the idea of photography as a "universal language." For instance, in 1933, photographer August Sander said even an isolated Bushman could understand a photograph of the sky. However, with the rise of global communication in the late 20th century, we must ask if photography can truly cross cultural differences. Is photography as culturally bound as language? Has our familiarity with photos made us overlook the medium's ability to convey reality?

Photography is often seen as providing clear evidence, making it seem transparent and blurring the line between our perception of the world and its photographic representation. It's common for someone to show a photo and say, "this is my grandson." Since its invention in 1839, photography and attitudes towards it have changed significantly. Photography has moved from being a simple record-keeper to becoming part of "mythic time," where photos have become historical documents, revealing much about the people and society that created them.

I aim to show that the camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography does not just reflect culture; it can inspire social and political change. For example, the cultural changes of the Italian Renaissance were influenced by new ways of visual representation, like perspective. Similarly, photography has played a major role in creating the media culture of today, while also showing the harsh realities of the world in a way that is accessible to many.

**How to Write Poetry**

Explaining how to write poetry is tricky. It's like walking through a minefield: you need to be spontaneous, but one wrong move and your ideas can fall apart. Claiming to know everything is risky, so instead, I suggest that beginners focus on reading a lot, writing often, and freeing their imagination in any productive way, without going into chaos. Some people need a stable life to write poetry, while others can write even when they're unhappy. Some follow a schedule, while others wait for inspiration. All methods are valid as long as they aren't just copying someone else's rules. The key is to find your own voice, nurture it, and let it grow until it can stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, there's no space for too many characters or long narratives. Flashbacks should be brief and only used if necessary to clarify something. A good way to do this is through a quick memory in the main character's mind, which can help move the story forward. Dialogue is very useful because it can show different sides of a situation quickly and keeps the reader interested. Overwriting can ruin a short story, but that doesn't mean it should be as short as a summary. Conflict and action should be as strong in a short story as in a novel, but every word must count in the limited space.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is like playing chess. Many chess players make moves without knowing the outcome, seeing only a few moves ahead. Over time, they realize that chess is more about long-term strategy than short-term tactics. They start to see the whole game, not just individual moves, and recognize patterns like openings, middle games, and end games. Similarly, the more you write screenplays, the more you understand their complexities.

**Looking at Writing**

Charles Darwin noted that humans naturally speak, as seen in children's babbling, but writing is not instinctive. Language exists in all societies, past and present, and while languages change, they don't necessarily improve. All healthy children learn to speak without formal lessons. When children lack a common language, they create one. Writing, however, has been invented only a few times in history, in complex societies, and has evolved slowly. Until recently, most children didn't learn to read or write, and even today, many struggle. Children naturally learn to speak, but reading and writing are skills that must be taught. We need to understand how writing works, how children's minds work, and how to connect the two.

I have never started writing a novel with more uncertainty. I call it a novel because I don't know what else to name it. I have a small story to share, and it doesn't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave the reader with an open ending. This book is about my memories of a man I met only occasionally, and I don't know much about what happened to him in between those times. I could make up details to fill the gaps and make the story more complete, but I don't want to do that. I just want to write down what I know. To avoid causing problems for people who are still alive, I have given the characters in this story made-up names, and I've taken care to ensure no one can recognize them. The man I'm writing about isn't famous. He might never be. When he dies, he might leave no more impact on the world than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. If my book is read at all, it will be for its own interest. But maybe the life he chose and his unique character will influence others, and long after his death, people might realize he was a remarkable person. Then, it will be clear who I am writing about, and those interested in his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book, despite its limits, will be a helpful source for my friend's future biographers. I don't claim that the conversations I've included are exact quotes. I never took notes, but I have a good memory for things that matter to me. Although I've written these conversations in my own words, I believe they accurately reflect what was said. I mentioned earlier that I haven't invented anything, but like historians, I've added speeches to make the scenes more lively and realistic. I want my book to be read, and I think it's fair to make it engaging. Intelligent readers will notice where I've used this technique, and they can choose to ignore it if they wish. Another reason I'm nervous about this book is that the people I'm writing about are from a different culture. It's hard to truly know people, and I think you can only really understand your own countrymen. People are shaped by where they were born, the places they grew up, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they went to, the sports they enjoyed, and the poets they read. These experiences make them who they are, and you can't fully understand them just by hearing about them; you have to live them. You can only truly know them if you are one of them. Because you can't fully know people from another country just by observing, it's hard to make them believable in a book. I've never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I've done so in short stories, it's because you can describe characters more briefly there. You give the reader a general idea and let them imagine the rest. In this book, I don't claim that my characters see themselves as I describe them; they are seen through my eyes, just like the main character.

**POETRY RECITALS**

Throughout history, the world of literature often seems confusing to those experiencing it. It's only later that we can see patterns and recognize which works are important. Today, poetry is especially complex, with many different styles and opinions about what poetry should be and how it should be shared. 

Currently, there is a debate in poetry between two groups. One group consists of serious 'literary' poets who write poems to be read on the page. The other group includes 'popular' poets who enjoy performing their poems in front of an audience. This division isn't strict, and many poets do both.

Public poetry readings have become more common over the last twenty years. These events happen in various places, like small town halls, schools, colleges, and arts festivals. Poets are often expected to perform their work publicly, which has mixed results for them.

For 'pop' poets, who write specifically for live performances, public readings are beneficial. Their poems are usually simple and easy to understand in one hearing. However, when these poems are read on the page, their weaknesses in thought and technique can become obvious.

On the other hand, poets who focus on crafting their work with depth and complexity might not be fully appreciated in a live setting. These poets aim to pack a lot of emotion, thought, and rhythm into their work, which can be missed if the audience is hearing it for the first time. The risk is that they might choose to read only their simpler poems to connect quickly with the audience.

Listening to poetry readings is not a replacement for reading poetry on the page, but it can be a fun and educational experience. Hearing poets read their work can help listeners understand the emphasis and rhythm intended by the poet. It's helpful if the audience can follow along with the text or is already familiar with the poems.

The main reason for popular poetry recitals, sometimes mixed with music, is to make poetry enjoyable and accessible to everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**

Historians are increasingly using oral evidence, but this method has challenges. It's unrealistic to think that someone's spoken account is a perfect reflection of past events. During an interview, both the historian and the person being interviewed influence each other. The historian chooses who to interview and what topics to cover. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final account is shaped by the historian's social status compared to the interviewee and the historian's way of understanding history, which might affect the interviewee's responses. Historians must acknowledge their role in shaping new evidence. Even without the historian, the interviewee's memories might be influenced by other sources, like the media, or by nostalgia or later life experiences. Emotions in the testimony can seem convincing but might not be from the time being discussed.

**Animal Science**

Animal science can be studied in two main ways: focusing on the body's functions or looking at the whole animal. Physiologists study how nerves, muscles, and senses work together to create behavior. Those who study the whole animal look at the behavior of the animal as a whole and what influences it. Within this approach, psychologists and ethologists are different. Psychologists usually work in labs, studying how animals like rats and pigeons learn. Ethologists study natural, instinctive behavior, often in wild settings. Although these fields are merging, physiologists often claim their methods are more basic. However, understanding nerve cells alone isn't enough; we also need to study behavior as a whole. Describing a bird's nest-building by nerve cell actions is like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**

New social science students face a challenge: they must learn both the content and the methods of their subject. They need to understand the knowledge in textbooks and how this knowledge is gathered and organized. These two parts are closely linked. We might think social sciences are just common sense because we all experience social life. However, each social science goes beyond common sense, focusing on specific aspects of social life, using particular study methods, and employing unique concepts. These concepts form the 'logical basis' of the subject, helping social scientists go beyond everyday understanding and distinguishing one discipline from another.

**Classical Architecture**

In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He used Greek terms for some of these ideas, likely from an earlier Greek source. Utility and function aren't part of his initial definition, though he later discusses the best designs for different purposes. Initially, the focus is on architecture as an art. Classical architecture has complex origins, with a long history of simple constructions in Greece and Italy that didn't meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. These early forms contributed to later architectural ideas. Despite its elaborate appearance, a classical temple is essentially a simple, single-room structure.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the allotments, near the railway line and gasworks, even jumping a small bridge with all four wheels off the ground, which was her only mistake. She would finish her drive near the gasworks, surrounded by the smell of sulphur. Surprisingly, Chen found out and was amused by Lily's secret driving. He praised her, saying, "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" Mui thought men were strange because Chen should have been upset, but instead, he was excited and started planning a trip with Lily. They decided to go on a Monday at the start of the next month, as it was the quietest day of the week. They planned to leave early and return by midday to avoid losing customers. Meanwhile, Lily would practice driving around the allotments. Mui, despite her doubts, bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen. However, Lily felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.

An hour after leaving home, they reached the English Channel. Lily drove perfectly, and even Mui, who was ready to give directions from the back seat, had to admit it. Lily overtook a few slow vehicles with great skill, and Chen even applauded her. After passing through the gasworks of a seaside town, they drove along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a small street with many empty parking spaces. She wasn't sure about the road markings, so she preferred to pay a parking fee rather than risk getting towed or fined. This cautiousness might have reassured Mui. During the drive, Lily noticed Mui's tense face in the mirror and decided not to mention any worries that hadn't occurred to Mui.

Lily locked all the van doors carefully. Chen joked, "Don't worry, no one will want that old van." The sisters were annoyed. Lily accused Chen of being ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for being too proud and easily fooled by appearances. Surprised, Chen took their son, Man Kee, to look at the sea. He lifted Man Kee onto the railing and held him. Man Kee was a warm, responsive child and put his hand on Chen's sleeve. In that moment, Chen decided to raise Man Kee his way, ensuring he got a good education in business and eventually owned many restaurants. The sight of the sea made Chen feel thoughtful as he planned Man Kee's future.

Chen saw a ship on the horizon and used a telescope to look at it. At first, he couldn't find it, but then he saw it clearly: a small, old, rusty tramp steamer. He lifted Man Kee to the eyepiece and said, "Do you see the ship, Son? It's a special ship for people like us. It's small and old, but we know it's the ship that will take us home when we're done here. It will take you to your homeland, which you've never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui joined them, and Lily put her arm around Chen. Chen said, "The little old ship. Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee didn't want to let go of the telescope, and when he finally did, the view was gone. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship had disappeared over the horizon, and Lily could only see seagulls following the ship's path.

**THE WELL**

I had read somewhere that if you looked up from a deep hole, you could see the stars during the day. I convinced you to help me test this idea. You watched nervously as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it on the edge, and climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn't think about how much heavier the bucket would be with me in it, or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You tried to hold the handle, but as soon as the bucket left the wall, I fell. You screamed and tried to stop the handle, but then let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. At that moment, I didn't realize I had sort of achieved my goal. I saw strange lights, like the stars and planets in cartoons when a character gets hit. At first, I was just dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say. You called down to ask if I was okay. I was about to shout back when you called again, sounding more panicked, which stopped me. I lay still, watching you through my eyelashes. You ran off to get help. I waited a bit, then climbed out of the well and onto the courtyard stones. I heard worried voices from the castle. I ran the other way, hiding in the shadows near the moat bridge. Mother and Father came out with you and old Arthur; Mother was panicking, and Father told Arthur to use the winch. You looked pale and shocked. I felt a mix of excitement and fear. Then I noticed the trail of water drops I had left from the well to where I was hiding. I was horrified. The drops were visible in the sunlight. I couldn't believe no one had seen them. Mother was screaming, a sound I had never heard before. It shook me deeply. What should I do? I had gotten back at you, but now things were more serious than I expected. It had gone from a clever idea to a big problem that wouldn't go away without someone, probably me, getting in trouble. I regretted not thinking it through. From a smart plan to a disaster in minutes. Then I had an idea. I gathered my courage and left my hiding spot, pretending to be weak and dizzy. I called out softly, then louder when no one noticed. I stumbled forward and collapsed dramatically. Sitting up, comforted by my crying mother, I pretended to be relieved and said I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and crawled through it to escape. I thought I was convincing them until Father asked me to repeat the story. I did, but hesitated. His eyes narrowed. Trying to cover up, I said the tunnel collapsed after me, so there was no point in checking. I claimed the well was dangerous and I barely survived. I looked into my father's eyes and felt like I was looking into a dark tunnel with no stars. It was like he was seeing me for the first time, and I was seeing how adults view children's lies. My words stopped. "Don't be ridiculous, boy," he said, with more contempt than I thought possible. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked at me, disappointed, not because of my adventure or that my father didn't believe me, but because he saw through my lie and worried about my character. His pity was as painful as my father's words, showing that this was the adult judgment of my actions, not something I could ignore. It affected me deeply.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Susan, a widow, is moving out of her family home now that her children are grown. The moving van had "Removers of Distinction" written on it, and Susan noticed that everything unique about her house was being packed away. Fred, the removal man, was carefully wrapping fragile items, while his team was less gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-story house with a view of a small harbor. Memories of her children growing up there lingered in the air like dust.

When they first bought the house, her son Robert, then five, had asked how they would bring the house home. Now, Robert was helping with the move, making sure Susan didn't mention the piano. Her daughter Francesca was also there, insisting she was the only one careful enough to handle their Steinway piano.

Fred, the removal man, commented that Susan didn't seem like she was going to cry, which surprised her. He explained that many people cry when they see their homes being taken apart, but they feel better once they reach the new place. Susan could understand that feeling.

Susan remembered when they first moved in. The piano was the first thing they brought in, but it got stuck on the stairs. The removal team struggled for hours, and Francesca, who loved music, was upset. Her late husband, Peter, solved the problem by hiring a builder to remove a window and using a crane to lift the piano inside. It was an expensive process, and they couldn't afford to tune the piano for months. Peter had said the piano would stay there forever, but forever is a long time.

Now, Susan's children were busy, and she found it hard to move around the house. She realized she should have warned the movers about the piano, but it was too late. As they prepared to move the piano, Susan felt anxious. Fred reassured her, and Robert and Francesca watched from the hallway.

Susan was on the verge of tears, realizing how much the objects in her home meant to her now that they were being moved. But when the piano was successfully carried out of the house, Robert started laughing, and soon all three of them were laughing uncontrollably, relieved that the move was over. As they left the house arm in arm, the only tears Susan shed were tears of laughter.

**Online Literary Criticism for Everyone**

**Is DIY Literary Criticism Just Harmless Fun?**

From the beginning, the idea of open access to the Internet was a key principle. In theory, anyone could publish their thoughts or start a music channel online. In practice, though, some technical skills were needed, especially in the early days. However, one area that truly opened up to everyone was literary criticism. With Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could try writing book reviews. Amazon's approach was simple: anyone could write a review and rate a book up to five stars. This seemed like a great idea. Each book had its own page, and new reviews appeared automatically. This allowed Amazon to fill its pages with free reviews, and potential buyers could see what other readers thought, instead of just reading the publisher's blurb or professional critics' opinions. Other online bookstores with physical stores offered similar features. But as the largest player, with over 80% of the online market, Amazon attracted the most customers and reviews, and thus faced the most issues.

This open review system led to some problems. Thousands of reviews were submitted daily, so it was impossible to check them all. Instead, a team of editors checked that reviews followed Amazon's guidelines. Reviews with just one word, personal attacks on the author, or those with obscenities, spoilers, or references to other reviews were not allowed. However, reviewers were anonymous, and problematic reviews were only removed if Amazon's editors noticed them. This allowed for some mischief. For example, writers could give their own books positive reviews. One writer, Lev Grossman, was upset by bad reviews of his first novel and wrote several positive ones himself. His trick worked until he wrote an article about it, and the fake reviews were removed.

Authors could also comment on their books by clicking a link saying, "I am the Author, and I wish to comment on my book." Most authors used this to encourage readers to buy and enjoy their books. Some even shared their email addresses to communicate directly with readers. However, Amazon did not verify if the comments truly came from the authors, except for famous ones. A lesser-known writer once pretended to be John Updike, calling himself "talented but over-hyped," but this was quickly removed as a fake.

The real drama came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's book "We've Got Spirit," about a cheerleading team, was published, it was praised by the mainstream press. But many people mentioned in the book felt betrayed and used Amazon's page to express their anger. Many critical reviews were submitted but disappeared after a few days. Despite such incidents, Amazon saw the high number of reviews as good for business. Since reviews were meant to be a "forum to talk about a book," Amazon closely monitored bestselling books to ensure reviews followed the rules. This meant that silly reviews were more likely to be found on less popular books. For example, "The Story about Ping," a children's book about a duck, inspired humorous reviews because "ping" is also a term used in Internet technology. One review humorously compared the book's plot to Internet architecture.

However, such silliness was rare. Most reviews on Amazon were taken seriously by their writers. Overall, these reviews provided a surprisingly accurate idea of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once complained that reviewing too many books meant inventing reactions to books he didn't care about. This makes the democratization of the review process seem like a positive development.

**Art in Modern Times**

In the last two hundred years, people have started to think that every artist must rebel against the art of their time. Art is often praised for being unique, revolutionary, or even shocking. We admire artists whose work was not appreciated a hundred years ago. However, when it comes to contemporary art, we often hesitate and say an artist has gone too far, questioning if it can still be called art. The media often express these doubts for us, and we tend to agree because we expect art to be puzzling and new. This expectation can make us overlook the old themes, methods, and virtues present in today's art. We see artists as separate from the rest of us, with special talents and energy that cannot be contained by conventions. In the past, people commissioned art for specific purposes, making it part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to their own devices and get annoyed if they try to be more relatable.

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26th, there is an unspoken rule in the art world that once an artist finds success in a particular style, they should stick to it. Collectors expect consistency, and trying something new can upset them. Gallery owners prefer safe bets, and the art-buying public often seeks comfort in continuity. However, some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, have successfully broken this mold. Eric Rimmington is another artist challenging expectations. **Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. I use the word 'escape' because the villagers jokingly say only a sick person would choose such a remote place to rebuild. So, I am here to heal myself, if you want to put it that way. Apart from an old peasant woman who comes from the village each day to clean the house, I am alone. **Family Business**

"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were driving back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also just sat through Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my final exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were heading home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, though I had a feeling I knew what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. Normally, he talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you'll get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I said, trying to act confident. "Mightn't that be useful?"

"I also heard," he continued, and I knew a confrontation was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.

"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"

"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can quickly understand a lot of information, you can talk well, and you enjoy performing."

"I don't know about that," I said. "All I know is what I see in TV dramas."

"Be that as it may," he continued, pulling himself together, "I feel your heart's never going to be in the business now. Obviously, you'll go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us."

The problem was that, like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by family expectations. I saw different career options and wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him intimidating.

"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.

"I tell you you're not going to want to join us," said my father, who was usually right about these things, "and it's a pity because you've got the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."

"There's still Maurice," I said, sulking. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.

"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a sort of consultant."

My mother wasn't around to help - she had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger, and because he was motherless, I got used to taking care of him. It wasn't a hardship. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived in luxury - a big house in London, fancy schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew all kinds of people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was full of interesting conversations.

"I tell you what," my father continued. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and be a real help to me."

"OK," I said, relieved to avoid immediate decisions and especially the depression and sulks my father would fall into if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.

So it happened. In my last term at school, and then during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on the safer tasks. I became one of the smarter students, with a little house of my own, a small but powerful white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label that I planned to wear for my final exams.

In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I stayed focused, he might be right. I felt confident and concentrated.

This was not to be. My father told me that, in about a week, he needed me for one last assignment, the most important business the family firm had ever attempted, and that it would be worth my while.

"But Dad," I protested, "I've got my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."

I could tell that such pressures were beyond my father's imagination (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him?) and that he would see a refusal as a betrayal in his time of need.

That was not all. As he described the procedures, I saw more clearly than ever before the single-mindedness of my father - the clarity and resourcefulness with which he approached his work, the dynamic energy, the perfect self-control. In his way, he was a sort of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans and hopes seem less important.

"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being extremely careful with their money, which wasn't ideal. At first, it seemed like a good decision because Simon had been successful in his legal cases, and Lois had returned to her job at an advertising agency with a salary increase to thirty-five thousand. These needs could have been met in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted more than just space. She felt their old address wasn't suitable for their social and professional status. 

To save money, Lois decided one of them should use public transport. Since her job was far away, Simon had to take the crowded tube, which made him resentful. He often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he was treated with care and respect after a long day. But times had changed. Lois made it clear before they married that her career was as important as his. Their lifestyle depended on both their incomes.

Now, their situation was threatened by Venetia, who was very upset when she confronted Simon. She accused him of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed jurors in a case four years ago and that Cartwright had given shares to Simon's fiancée before the trial. I chose to live here because I thought I could be anonymous among people who didn't care if their rented houses were falling apart or if their gardens were overgrown. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you, even if you don't feel like you're living a real life. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, trying to ignore the summer outside, but tonight I'm watching the birds fly between the trees and roofs. I've cleared some space in the garden for a chair, and my arms are scratched from cutting back the plants. It's a small London garden where plants have to grow tall to survive. 

My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She's written several unpublished books, and as an English teacher, I sometimes have to pretend to be interested in them. I have her latest book with me now. 'How's the writing going, Jaz?' I ask. 'In no other job do people ask you about your work all the time,' she replies. Then she offers to bring a drink down. I don't really want her in the garden, which now looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. 'You're on holiday now,' she says, sitting in the garden. 'I should have been a teacher. Writers don't get holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can't, teach.' And some can't do either. 'What are your plans for the holidays?' she asks. 

I feel anxious about the school year ending. Empty days, hot pavements, and loneliness in the park. 'I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?' I ask, my heart racing. 'Of course,' Jaz says, knowing she will be around. 'Where will you stay? A nice B&B?' 'No, I'll stay with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We've known each other since we were eight.' This isn't true, but I often deal with fiction. 'Going back to your roots. What do you think of my book?' Jaz asks about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I haven't finished reading. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses and rejection letters to hers. I decide to be honest. 'Try writing about nice people for a change, people who try to be good,' I suggest. 'Teachers!' Jaz responds like a rebellious student. 'I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,' I say, sounding old-fashioned. 'Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.' 

Oh, I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes, reading on the tube. When we go inside, my calm kitchen reassures me. Then I suddenly remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now, winking at us and saying, 'I've had my moments.' We nearly died laughing.

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to their past. We often feel linked to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and their lives. Beyond personal stories, there is a broader need to understand our past to help us shape our future, both individually and as a nation. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity, helping us feel secure about the future by understanding the past. Just like we inherit genes, we also inherit culture passed down through generations. Even if there are parts of our national heritage we might not like, it is still part of us and provides a sense of belonging. Heritage teaches us a lot and is crucial for our well-being, influencing everything from customs to material culture. In the past, stories and legends from our ancestors connected us to our history. However, Western industrial society disrupted communities and families, leading to the loss of many oral traditions. Now, places and buildings serve as reminders of our past. It is essential to preserve these links to honor our ancestors' identities.

**The Fens**

I started writing a novel called "Waterland," where the landscape of the Fens in England became a key element. People often ask why I, a Londoner with no personal ties to the Fens, chose this setting. The simple answer is that I saw the Fens as a blank canvas for my story. However, I learned that the Fens are not just flat and empty. They are uniquely English yet strangely foreign, a place that feels both cultivated and wild, open yet mysterious. Although I didn't visit many places in the Fens while writing, I relied on my imagination. The Fens are not just a physical landscape but also a state of mind, as shown in Edward Storey's book.

**Museums**

Museums need to make their collections accessible. In the past, this meant putting items in display cases with long labels that were hard to understand. Today, accessibility means more. Displays should be engaging, using creative techniques to capture visitors' attention and evoke emotions. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can provide loan boxes of objects for teachers or use similar materials to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real artifacts, not replicas. They offer encounters with authentic items that existed and had meaning in history. This sets them apart from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and digital media. Museums that embrace this role and offer exciting displays and outreach programs will find that digital history can actually increase interest in the real experiences they provide.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to preserve things is not new, but changes in our towns happen so quickly now that everyone feels their impact. This can turn some people into strong preservationists and make others think more about the nature and future of towns. It can be argued that people who have lived through major events like world wars are more inclined to preserve things, as stability becomes important. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners should consider it. Change is not a threat if we learn to manage it. Physical changes in our towns reflect social changes, such as shifts in population, welfare, and demands.

**Einstein**  
If you ask someone on the street to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His image is often used to sell products that are linked to intelligence, like computers and encyclopedias. Most people don't really know what Einstein did, except that he created some complex theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that don't match everyday experiences. Einstein was part of a big change in scientific thinking, which marked the start of modern science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to describe the universe in a new, more logical way by studying how matter and natural forces interact. Einstein made important contributions by rethinking basic concepts like time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists followed Isaac Newton's idea that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but relative.

When we were children, Lydia and I didn't trust books that won prizes because we thought they would be serious and, therefore, boring. **Language**  
In 1851, Jacob Grimm wrote that 'The origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous'. This mysterious origin has led to many strange ideas. In 1928, Charles Caller suggested that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when they felt danger. "Meuh" sounds sad. A person walking through a dangerous land with scary animals might have made desperate noises, and languages have kept some of these sounds, like the word malaria meaning "fever" or the Latin mors meaning "death". Because of such odd theories, many people avoided the topic, thinking it was for eccentric thinkers. However, recently, the origin and evolution of language have become important research areas. Language likely developed in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly communication and played a key role in power struggles. Sharing information was probably not its original purpose, contrary to philosopher John Locke's idea that language is a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

Text: 'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode explores the art of writing reviews from a writer's perspective. Most reviews are created and shared under conditions that make them relevant for only a short time. There are deadlines and strict limits on their length. Once published, they last only as long as the newspaper or magazine they appear in—maybe a day, a week, or at most a month. The temporary nature of reviews often defines their literary value. Many people, including the writers themselves, think that reviewing is a job done out of necessity, like needing extra money, or because they can't spend all day working on a novel or a serious book. However, reviewing is a complex and skilled task. Writing a concise and fair review in 600 to 800 words for a newspaper is different from crafting a detailed 6,000 to 8,000-word piece for an international journal. A 1,500-word article in a weekly magazine combines challenges of both short and long reviews. Length isn't the only factor. Reviewers must consider their audience, from casual weekend readers to those deeply interested in the subject. A reviewer should know a lot about various topics and write in a way that intelligent readers can understand and enjoy. This means reviewers often write other things besides reviews. The American novelist John Updike, who isn't fond of criticism—calling it "hugging the shore"—still enjoys writing reviews between his major novels. He collects all his reviews, even the short ones, into books with modest titles. While some might think less famous writers should accept the temporary nature of their reviews, there's no reason they shouldn't enjoy some recognition if they believe their best work is in their reviews. I feel this way about my own work. My main job has been academic, and most of my serious books are academic, the kind professors are expected to write. In the English-speaking world, unlike other cultures, there's no strict separation between reviewing and literary study, so it's common for the same people to do both. The days when academics criticized professors for writing reviews are mostly over. Complaints from non-academics that professors are taking their jobs are also less common, partly because there's more reviewing work available now, and partly because the pay is often low. I believe this situation benefits both readers, who can trust the reviewer knows the subject, and professors, as it helps them stay grounded. It also reminds them to communicate clearly with non-academics. While they might use complex language with each other, they need to be clear when speaking to intelligent non-academics. Ultimately, reviewing is a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and entered the dark, still hallway. Even after three years, he sometimes felt a brief doubt about owning the place when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home eagerly, often as early as possible, curious about what the flat had been like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place where he was in control. He thought he should worry about things like intruders or leaks, but the flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either tidy or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as just another part of himself, a space filled with his thoughts and feelings. He became frustrated that it couldn't change. Sometimes, there would be a small pile of letters by the door or the answering machine would be blinking with messages. He was thankful that the windows hadn't been broken or the flat vandalized, though he wondered what it would look like if that happened. From his dull office on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to his evenings alone at home. Once he left the artificial world of the office and started to feel like himself again on the bus ride home, he realized he didn't need to be alone, a fact he often forgot when planning his social life. At his desk, he longed for solitude and time with his belongings, but once he escaped, he felt empty and waited in vain for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt a deep emptiness, making him suspect that doing work he didn't enjoy had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He would read or listen to music as the night went on, but he questioned why he did these things. His sense of direction was unclear, and his thoughts and feelings seemed to get lost in his mind. He remembered a time when he didn't feel so powerless, when he might have escaped if he had realized his own value. But he had been eager to settle into something and followed the first opportunity that came along, as if it was meant to be. After university, he tried to make a plan for his future, but he wasn't surprised to find that he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends, following their paths without imagining he could find happiness in his work. He went to his only job interview with gratitude and didn't think to evaluate the position—a vague editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was relieved to have a pleasant conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't think about the long meetings he would face daily. Neil offered him the job on the spot, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**How to be Presentation Perfect - we answer your questions**

I am not naturally good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and confidence? 

You are not alone. Presenting is a different skill from running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. To convince your audience, you must believe in what you're saying. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas in advance and ask colleagues to think of tough questions the audience might ask. Some activities simply cannot be rushed. They take the time they need. If you're late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you're impatient while making mayonnaise and add the oil too quickly, it will curdle. If you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will only get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some tasks are done very quickly, while others take longer—seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some mental tasks can be sped up, like solving crossword puzzles or doing mental math faster. But others cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they might fail, like the mayonnaise, or become more complicated, like the fishing line. Saying 'Think fast; we need the results' can be as unwise as trying to sleep for only half the time you need. We learn, think, and understand in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds, suitable for different tasks. 'He who hesitates is lost,' says one proverb. 'Look before you leap,' says another. Both are true. Generally, the mind has three processing speeds. The first is faster than thought. Some situations need an immediate, instinctive reaction. When my motorbike skidded on a wet road in London years ago, my brain and body quickly coordinated a series of movements that kept me safe. Only after it was over did my conscious mind catch up. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer doesn't have time to think about their next move. This fast, instinctive intelligence could be called our 'wits'. Then there is thought itself: the kind of intelligence that involves figuring things out, weighing pros and cons, building arguments, and solving problems. A mechanic figuring out why an engine won't start, a scientist interpreting an experiment, or a student working on an assignment all use this type of intelligence, which relies on reason and logic. We often call this 'intellect'. Someone good at these tasks is called 'bright' or 'clever'. But there is another, slower mental process. It is often less focused, more playful, leisurely, or dreamy. In this mode, we are thinking deeply or reflecting; being contemplative or meditative. Sitting on a rock by the sea, lost in the sound of the waves, or just before sleep, we are in a different mental state than when planning a meal or writing a letter. This slow, seemingly aimless way of thinking is just as intelligent as the faster ones. Allowing the mind time to wander is not a luxury to cut back on when life gets busy. On the contrary, slow thinking is an important part of our mental abilities. We need the slow mind as much as the fast one. Some problems are better solved with a slow mind. Some mysteries can only be understood with a relaxed, open mental attitude. Recent scientific studies show that these patient, less deliberate ways of thinking are especially good for understanding complex, unclear situations. Deliberate thinking works well when the problem is clear. When deciding where to go on holiday, the options might be obvious. But when we don't know what to consider or which questions to ask—or when the issue is too subtle for conscious thought—we need the slow mind. If the problem is how to manage a difficult team at work or whether to change careers, it might be better to sit and think rather than rush for answers. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and even 'wisdom'. Poets have long understood the limits of conscious thinking and have tried to develop these slower ways of knowing. Philosophers have written about the parts of the mind beyond conscious thought. Only recently have scientists begun to study these slower, less deliberate ways of knowing. The field of 'cognitive science' is showing that the unconscious mind can do many unusual, interesting, and important tasks if given time. It can learn patterns too subtle for normal consciousness, understand complex situations, and solve difficult problems better than the conscious mind.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**

I have been warmly welcomed here. It's a friendly and well-equipped base camp in a very remote area. At any time, there are about forty people - scientists, students, weather experts, and satellite trackers - forming a close community where everyone helps each other. My basic French is just enough to communicate, but not enough for casual conversation. I miss the subtle meanings, and my phrasebook is useless at breakfast. This isn't a practical problem for me, but at first, it affected my confidence. I felt a bit nervous about mealtimes. I would hesitate, unsure which table to join, worried about the silence when I spoke, feeling anxious like I did in my first weeks of school. I still smile awkwardly or panic when people talk to me. I think this occasional sadness isn't about missing company or communication; it's because I've lost the social advantage that my ability to talk has always given me.

**Elliot**

When I first met Elliot, I was just another young author, and he didn't pay much attention to me. However, he never forgot a face, and when we met again, he would shake my hand warmly, but he didn't try to get to know me better. If I saw him at the opera with someone important, he would often pretend not to see me. But then I had a surprising success as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to show more interest in me. One day, he invited me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me. After that, because my success brought me many new friends, I began to see him more often.

**Alfred Hitchcock**

The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said he didn't care much about the story or the acting in his films. Instead, he focused on the photography, the soundtrack, and all the technical details. For Hitchcock, it wasn't the message or a great performance that moved the audience. He believed that people are affected by pure film, no matter their cultural background. So, if a film is made correctly to have an emotional impact, audiences from Japan and India should react at the same moment. Hitchcock's view of himself was always clear and logical. He was a man of reason and a talented craftsman who enjoyed hearing an audience scream. He didn't deal with speculation or intellectual ideas, and he didn't explore his screen characters deeply. He focused on film, pure film, and the precise, calculated beauty of what a strip of film can do to an audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**

Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts or catalogues. Telescopes were basic, and there were few books on how to do astronomy. Now, you can buy almost any telescope or equipment you need. Electronic calculators and computers have made it easier to create charts and analyze observations. This might seem like the best time ever for amateur astronomy. However, some things have been lost. Today, you might need to travel 80 km to find a sky as clear as it was in cities 50 years ago. During the day, airplane trails can turn into clouds that block the sun and make it hard to observe the sky at night.

**Too Much Choice**

Today, society has too many choices. There are too many things to do and too many options. People always want the newest product or service, and technology makes everything change faster. New products come out all the time, making it hard to keep up. This can be stressful and make life feel disconnected. More choices mean more stress and less time. People are now looking for "simplexity"—simple things that bring meaning in a complex world. But simplifying life is hard when there are so many products and services. There are more types of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and too many software updates and phone plans to follow.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It's a family tradition started by my grandmother, and it's very important to us. We don't let anything disrupt this ritual. The people who stay at McAndrews are similar: old-fashioned and maybe a bit snobbish. I don't like the rude behavior of shop assistants today, which is seen as being equal. I also dislike overly friendly waiters who seem like they might slap you on the back. I know most of the other guests' names because they have been coming here since they were children, like me. But I can be sure that when I see them around the hotel, we will only exchange polite greetings. This respect for privacy is rare in hotels today.

**Othello**

An outstanding production of Shakespeare's play "Othello" has moved from Stratford to London, giving me a chance to correct a previous unfair review. When the show first opened last spring, I criticized Ray Fearon for being too young for the role of Othello and underestimated his acting skills. Although I still believe that the age difference between Othello and Desdemona is important to the story, I must admit that Mr. Fearon's performance is truly remarkable. In fact, the entire cast is excellent. Some unforgettable scenes include Cassio's dangerous games with other young officers and the moment when Iago starts to lose control and struggles to regain it. The scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed is particularly moving and might bring tears to your eyes. The production maintains great pace and tension throughout. Don't miss it.

**Lake Vostok**

In the center of Antarctica, there is no movement. While the edges of the continent are full of penguins, seals, and birds, the vast white interior is lifeless. However, beneath nearly 4 kilometers of ice lies Lake Vostok, a huge hidden freshwater lake directly under the coldest place on Earth. This water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its depths to find out what unusual organisms might live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also very interested. For the past two years, scientists from around the world have been planning how to uncover the lake's secrets. If successful, the next few years could be known as the decade of Lake Vostok.

**Scientists**

There was an interesting discussion on the radio last week. A group of scientists is debating what motivates them to pursue science. The phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know it's about the quest for knowledge and understanding everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists are curious about why we want to know these things in the first place and why science can't explain this desire. It seems more important to consider whether what scientists are doing is right, rather than getting caught up in debates about the purpose of it all. The key issue should be recognizing that science is a tool, and we must decide how, where, when, and why to use it.

**Food**

Our connection with food is basic and fulfilling. Many people who love cooking buy cookbooks like this one. Often, we think that cooking is only worth it for special occasions or complex dishes. But that's not true. You can make a delicious soup by simply putting some chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and a few herbs into water. This is much more satisfying than buying a packet or opening a can. Instead of buying a chocolate mousse with too much sugar and preservatives, you can make a delicious dessert in five minutes that both adults and children will enjoy. Cooking is also a way to show care and love by bringing your own creation, no matter how simple, to the table. Sharing food is full of meaning and meets our deep human needs, which is why all our celebrations, like birthdays and anniversaries, happen around tables. No one would have a takeaway for a wedding or anniversary party! And few people would want to discuss a business deal over canned soup.

**In the Elevator**

This morning, Alistair tried to tidy up his office, but papers were still everywhere. Tax forms were stuffed in desk drawers and boxes, waiting for a day when he felt like filing them. Owning an apartment building added even more paperwork. Books and journals were near the new bookshelves but not organized. As the elevator took him to his floor, he knew Mallory would be on time for their meeting. She would knock on his office door exactly on the hour. She was very precise about time and neatness. How would she react to the mess? She might think someone had vandalized the place. He could pretend to be shocked when he walked in behind her. Mrs. Wilson, his cleaning lady, arrived while he was trying to clear some space on the carpet. He smiled at her hopefully as she unlocked his apartment door. Her eyes showed she wasn't going to help with the office mess. She believed he was like a visitor from another world, not part of her familiar Brooklyn streets.

**KAREN**

Karen wanted to be different from her mother, which led her to create her own story of strength. In her story, there were important moments, like when she was twelve and her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she was blind, but the bone protected her, as the doctor later told her. The club missed her eye, and she only needed a few stitches. When she opened her eyes in the doctor's office and saw her mother talking about miracles and small mercies, she felt she was saved for a reason.

**Miss Fogerty**

Miss Fogerty walked quickly across the wet grass of the village green, feeling both excited and sad about what she had just seen. It's exciting to be the first to know something important, especially in a small community, and Miss Fogerty's life was usually quiet. But she was very sad about Dr. Bailey's condition. He had been her doctor for many years, helping her with her yearly laryngitis, which was her only health issue. She appreciated how he always made time for his patients and listened to their worries. This quality made him very loved in the village. He was always willing to give his time, knowledge, and humor, and in return, he received loyalty and affection.

Joanna's Lessons

Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. Despite her hectic schedule, she has started writing books for young children learning the piano. Her performances are so captivating that even someone who claims to be tone-deaf would be moved. Watching her play is like seeing a pianist test the limits of human ability. However, at a recent concert for children, one boy was not impressed until she played the theme from "Match of the Day." For him, that was the real test of her skills. Joanna found this amusing and passed the test with ease.

Joanna is unique among top pianists because she is interested in how young children learn the piano. She has published her own beginner piano book for children called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World," even though she has a very busy work schedule. This summer, she is performing at many festivals and is involved in a collaboration with young composers and artists. She also runs her own recording label, Sound Circus, and loves working on joint projects with other artists. So why did she decide to write a book? Joanna believes that the first lessons are very important. She thinks that the music profession often focuses too much on creating child prodigies, while most people have a more everyday interest in music, which she finds more interesting.

Joanna's experience in teaching comes from her early years. Before she became a concert pianist, she taught beginners how to play the piano. Her childhood was filled with other children learning music at her home, where her mother taught piano. This experience shaped her belief that music should be accessible to everyone, not just those with exceptional talent. She thinks everyone should have the chance to learn the piano, just like learning to swim or speak a little French. Some children learn quickly, but she is more interested in those who progress at different rates and sometimes give up. This can happen at any stage, often because of frustration or pressure to meet high expectations.

Joanna is careful not to criticize other piano teaching books or teachers. Her books are colorful and engaging, but she acknowledges that there are many good books available. Her unique approach is to include a storyline in her books and CDs to make learning fun. From the first lesson, there are different styles of accompaniments for teachers or parents to play along with the child. If parents can't play the piano, the accompaniments are available on CDs. Joanna insists that learning should be fun and encourages improvisation and exploration of the keyboard.

As children progress, they face bigger challenges, like learning to read music instead of just playing by ear. Joanna understands this because she relied on her ear when she was young. However, she believes practice is the most important factor. She admits she didn't practice seriously until she attended the Royal Academy of Music, where she had to practice to handle difficult contemporary pieces. Now, she enjoys practicing and considers it the core of her musical life, even more important than performing. She sympathizes with those who find practice difficult and believes it's not discussed enough. Her advice is to plan what you want to achieve in each practice session, reward yourself by playing through a piece, and mix difficult pieces with easier ones.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**

Dr. Johnson once said that writing without effort is often not enjoyable to read. This suggests that good writing is difficult to achieve. When I look back at my handwritten school essays, I notice they have very few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand is physically hard, which makes you think more carefully. You write with care because it's hard to change or erase what you've written. On the other hand, using a computer can make you careless. Many writers find that they spend as much time fixing drafts on a computer as they did writing by hand. Also, emails, unlike handwritten letters, can be emotionally heavy. Some say emails have brought back the art of love letters, with millions being sent instead of just casual talk. That's a good thing. At least these emails are written in some form of English and grammar. But words on a screen can feel dull. Writers often don't realize the power of written words and tend to exaggerate. Words typed quickly lack the care and personality of handwriting.

**The CD**

I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was plain, but the shiny disc inside was interesting. "Aren't they amazing?" Mr. Warriston said as he came back into the room. I agreed and carefully handed the disc to him. "It's incredible they can fit seventy minutes of music on them," he said, turning on the hi-fi system. He pressed a button, and a small tray came out. He placed the disc inside and pressed the button again, and the tray went back in. "Some people say they sound too clean, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. "What? No," Mr. Warriston said, standing up straight. "No, you only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He looked puzzled, then thoughtful. "You know," he said, "I have no idea. I don't see why you couldn't make both sides playable and double the capacity..." He looked at the machine. "You could have two lasers, or just turn it over by hand... hmm." He smiled at me. "Yes, good point." He nodded at my wooden chair. "Anyway. Let's get you sitting in the best spot for the stereo effect, okay?" I smiled, happy to have asked a technical question Mr. Warriston couldn't answer.

**Books versus Electronic Text**

When comparing books and electronic text, author Malcolm Bradbury was right when he said that if matches had been invented after lighters, we'd think they were a great improvement. Many people, excited by new technology, say electronic text is as big a change as the invention of printing and that it's almost complete. They forget that changes in how we think take a long time. This kind of talk is self-centered, thinking our generation is at the peak of history. For example, a book from 1979 predicted that books would start disappearing in the 1980s. So far, that hasn't happened. Reading long texts on a screen is so unpleasant that most people avoid it. Also, the way information is organized on computers makes people skim through text. Some tech enthusiasts say this leads to new ways of storytelling. But there's nothing new about reading non-linearly. Many books, like religious texts, dictionaries, and poetry collections, aren't read from start to finish. What's new is that computers don't encourage reading a whole text in one go.

**The Office**

Charles walked into the office and saw a perfectly organized space. The carpet was free of the papers that had covered it since it was laid down, and the desk was dark wood, just as he remembered from the auction five weeks ago. Neat file-holders were being placed in drawers. Twelve years of trade journals filled the shelves on one wall. Kathleen struggled to close the filing cabinet and then turned to him. "You need to switch to computers, Charles. This is too much." "Hello, Kathleen. Oh, this is amazing." He admired the room and its antique furniture.
