He wasn't thinking about a computer or any other machine in it, not even a pencil sharpener. "Simply amazing," he said, avoiding the topic of computers. Over the two years he had known her, they had this conversation many times. She couldn't understand why he resisted technology when he was so good with computers and had even published an important paper on computer skills. She had inspired that paper. With a keyboard, she could transform any software into something new and exciting.

Lancelot's secretary shouted, "You don't take sugar, do you?" She wasn't really asking because she had been making him coffee for months. She often forgot things because he wasn't supposed to be there regularly. However, he was there all the time now because staying away led to chaos. He thought about how he had gone from being a respected advisor, meeting authors and playwrights over lunch, to a stressed worker with no parking space at work.

His secretary handed him a folder, saying it was from someone in Los Angeles and that he wanted to see it. The label read: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert" and "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot didn't want another synopsis; he wanted a first draft. Ian Cuthbert had received a large advance for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was an old friend, and Lancelot regretted commissioning books from friends. Ian was unpredictable and had not delivered the manuscript.

Lancelot skimmed the synopsis, recognizing almost every phrase. He set it aside, realizing Ian's manuscript might never come. The synopsis lacked the brilliance Ian was known for and felt uninspired. Lancelot remembered a famous author who had to be paid for each chapter to finish his book, but Ian had already received a large advance. Lancelot, who studied modern languages at Oxford, recalled when Ian was a promising talent at Cambridge. Ian's peers had taken over British theatre, but Ian's potential remained untapped.

Ian was difficult to work with, even when he was influential. He was supposed to edit an arts magazine but never published an issue, using up the budget. His contract with a fashion magazine produced little except stories about his high salary, which increased to encourage him to work. At editorial meetings, Ian was critical and sarcastic. Ten years later, he was unreliable. Lancelot was starting to admit that commissioning "A World History of the Short" was a mistake.

England's breakfast change

Health experts agree that having a good breakfast is very important. However, in England, breakfast is a relatively new tradition. In medieval times, breakfast was rarely mentioned in literature. There are a few mentions of travelers eating at dawn before long journeys and sick people having breakfast for health reasons. But most people, except for kings and nobles, did not eat breakfast. 

In the sixteenth century, breakfast slowly became common for everyone. Some people think this change happened because there was more food available. However, they often overlook other important social changes. For instance, new work patterns might explain why breakfast became more important. People started working fixed hours, often starting very early in the morning. So, having a meal in the morning became necessary and was no longer just for the wealthy.

**Photography**

When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to include based on their skills, personal views, and experiences, along with social and cultural norms. In this book, we will explore how these factors influence the style, content, and expression of a photograph, and how viewers perceive and react to these images. For instance, a newspaper reader might think they understand the photos they see. However, instead of just accepting the photo as it is, we might ask if it truly shows the scene as it was. Does it reflect the photographer's perspective? Is the exact moment captured important, or should the photo be seen as a symbol of a broader situation?

**More than a Game**

For me, sport is more than just a game. The most successful athletes have complete self-confidence. You need to focus entirely if you want to succeed in sports. There's only one way to be the best, and you must prioritize it above everything else. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. It's a matter of survival. Sport has taught me discipline and determination, but it also shows the value of teamwork. My sport allows individual excellence, yet it's a team game, so you must balance both. It's like life—you can succeed alone, but you must remember others around you. Sport has given me a lot—not just money. It has opened doors and my eyes, letting me see things worldwide that others might not. But you also have to sacrifice a lot for these benefits.

**Tuning In**

Some experiences are so vivid that they stand out clearly in our memories. For me, one such moment happened one night in California years ago. I was awake, listening to a mockingbird singing beautifully from a hidden spot in a tall tree in the neighborhood. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's amazing singing kept me awake. As I listened to its complex melodies, I felt drawn into a new artistic world. To follow the bird's patterns, I used my knowledge of jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was hearing an incredible, spontaneous musical performance. I reacted with groans and cheers as each surprising musical variation came through my window, until I finally fell asleep.

Birds have always been important in human culture. They are loved, feared, and even worshipped. But what does this say about us? Paul Evans explores this idea. 

In a greenhouse, a small brown bird, a wren, is bumping against the glass. Wrens are seen as mysterious birds, linked to omens and predictions. Is this wren trying to send a message from a world beyond our understanding? Or is it simply a bird trapped in a greenhouse? Both interpretations could be true, depending on how you see it. 

Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed that the direction a wren flew could predict their luck. Today, images of wrens are still found in British homes, even if the old beliefs have faded. A forest without wrens feels empty and sad. This connection to birds is part of a long tradition of folklore, which dates back to when people relied on nature for survival. 

Our views on birds can change over time. For example, in the early 1500s, red kites were common in London and were seen as helpful scavengers. But later, they were considered pests and almost disappeared, except in Wales. Now, red kites are protected and have become symbols of conservation in Britain.

Our relationship with birds goes back to our early ancestors. They watched birds closely because birds could warn of danger, bad weather, or food sources. Birds also connected people to the spiritual world. When we think about why birds matter to us, we also think about what it means to be human. Birds represent flight, song, and freedom, which we admire and wish to emulate. Some might say these feelings are outdated, but they are still part of us, like our appendix or wisdom teeth.

Birds are now seen as indicators of environmental health. In Britain, 30 bird species are endangered, which is concerning not just because of the loss of these birds, but also because of the cultural loss. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing have deep cultural meanings, representing love and magic. Their decline is felt deeply by those familiar with literature and folklore.

Folklore is important because it keeps stories and legends alive, connecting us to the past. These stories have a stronger bond with their subjects than scientific terms do. They evoke feelings and attitudes buried under modern life. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel is hard to explain scientifically. Birds engage us in ways we don't fully understand, and the stories we tell about them help us interpret their messages.

The wren in the greenhouse creates a link between the present and a distant past, holding a mystery in its song and flying into the future, leaving us to wonder.

Maps are tools that show how different points and features on the earth relate to each other, mainly through distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance by time, like "a day's journey," which told more about how easy it was to travel through an area than the actual distance. Direction was less important for travelers who just wanted to know where to go and how far it was. Because of this, written travel guides were popular for a long time, sometimes more so than maps. Even today, some maps, like those of train systems, don't always show true directions. Early maps used symbols to show landmarks, and these symbols varied depending on the map's purpose and location. Understanding these symbols is key to studying old maps.

The history of map-making, or cartography, is about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and adding more details to maps. Over time, cartography has used other sciences to help. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people used the magnetic compass, which allowed for more precise measurements. As knowledge of the world grew through exploration, maps became more detailed. Astronomers found that the earth is slightly flattened at the poles, which led to more precise mapping of large areas.

The needs of map users have changed over time. Travelers and merchants were not the only ones using maps. Soldiers needed accurate maps for artillery use, which required showing the land's surface features accurately. This led to the invention of contour lines. Archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also needed maps for their work, each with specific requirements. Today's cartographers create maps showing various distributions, like geological layers and climate patterns. The recognition of maps' value in many sciences has led to a modern revival of cartography.

The development of maps has not been a smooth, continuous process. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid development. Sometimes, old ideas persisted alongside new ones. Cartographers often knew what was needed for progress but had to wait for better tools to implement their ideas. Since it was easier to copy old maps, and because of the investment in printing, map publishers were sometimes slow to adopt new ideas. Therefore, maps should not be taken as perfect evidence of the knowledge and techniques of their time. The many maps we have today are the result of much human effort and thought, making them valuable records for studying human history. This is what makes the study of historical cartography so interesting and educational.

TIM RICE

I was invited into a young man's living room, which felt like a calm and cultured space compared to the messy rooms around it where his less ambitious family members spent their time. Moving from the kitchen to his living room felt like going from economy to business class on a flight. In this room, I saw the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had come across, and surprisingly, a teenager who had spent money on Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's version of the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as wild; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams weren't a matter of life or death, although it's easy to say that now. They might have been if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested a new crazy ambition for me—to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammerstein—I was willing to try. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting, he played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very talented. As he confidently played selections from the many shows he had written and produced at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' LP collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn't have much to impress him with, except for instant praise for his music and a real, released seven-inch single of a song I had written (both words and music) that an unknown pop group had recorded three months earlier, which ended their failing career. We parted, promising to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop charts than in West End theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I told myself I had just met someone with rare talent and determination, and I would be foolish to miss the chance to work with someone who was clearly going to make a big impact on musical theatre, probably very soon. And even if we didn't succeed in challenging the top musical composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later in the summer. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and would need new material. The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to become a lawyer, the brief certainty I had felt about a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber had faded a bit. I would, of course, keep an eye on the small ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a vocalist and would write a few more simple songs that wouldn't show the limitations of my voice, but it was still likely that I would eventually pass my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would surely have outgrown pop music, as my father confidently predicted I would by the time I was twenty-one. This was worrying—if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But in the meantime, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to see a musical with him and to write lyrics that imitated musical lyricists rather than pop stars. Andrew was a fascinating person who talked about Good Food Guides and Victorian architecture, and he supported the Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't convinced by the idea for a musical he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965, I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was undeniable, and he claimed to have all the contacts. I was soon back in his living room. The idea was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, the nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded the orphanages that bear his name. His story was indeed worthy, but it didn't really inspire me. The hero was too perfect, at least in Andrew's version of his life, and the project was unoriginal in both concept and execution, owing too much to Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. On the other hand, Andrew's belief in his score's brilliance was infectious and not entirely unjustified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who later became my agent for over twenty-five years, memorably (and repeatedly) said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar on the block, there's room for two. We could be the second hamburger joint. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially on the songs meant to be funny. Andrew outlined the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the title as well, most of which had probably been thought up by his former school friend who had already tried. I skipped a day at the solicitor's office, pretending to be sick, to write my first batch of theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it that day, but I had changed careers.

**Language**

Humans have an amazing ability: we can communicate with each other in a very precise way. Language is so important to us that it's hard to imagine life without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will probably start talking. Even when alone, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to speak naturally, just like spiders know how to spin webs. Spiders didn't learn web-spinning from a smart spider or need special training; it's just something they do naturally.

**Climate and Weather**

Climate and weather, created by the air around us, have a big impact on where animals and plants live. Climate can shape the look of landscapes. For example, warm and wet climates all year allow tropical jungles to grow, which are full of many different species. On the other hand, cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather patterns, which make up the climate over time, are caused by large masses of air moving and mixing. The atmosphere is always in motion. Some of this movement is because the air is on a spinning Earth, and since air is light, it doesn't move as fast as the Earth spins. The sun is an even more important cause of air movement.

**Coffee**

As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks, but I was most worried about making coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I went through several days of intense coffee-making training, learning a lot about cleaning and maintaining the restaurant's shiny espresso machine. I also learned the key steps to making a perfect cup of rich, frothy cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making good coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might be sent back to simpler tasks like cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. "Making coffee is both an art and a science," he said, "and you need time to get good at it."

**Art on TV**

Why does television often fail to make good programs about visual arts like painting and sculpture? These subjects should be perfect for TV because cameras can show an entire artwork and then zoom in to see the details. However, there are few TV series that successfully show both the enjoyment and complexity of looking at art. A good example of this problem is Robert Hughes's series "American Visions," which is about American art. Hughes is a reliable critic with a strong personality, and he had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which is often ignored by British galleries. I thought the series would focus on great artworks, but instead, it was more about how American history and culture are shown in its art and architecture.

**Dealing in Metals**

For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known for taking risks. The metals market is less regulated than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Risk-taking is a normal part of the industry. This adventurous culture fits well with a global free-market economy. However, the free-trade economists who said the market would keep the prices of scarce metals high have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being extracted, and the cost of raw materials is going down. Considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.

**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**

Abaco and its nearby cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, stretching from Florida past the Tropic of Cancer to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something unique. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If your accommodation doesn't include one, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis available. You can also rent a boat if you want to travel on your own. Sailing is the most popular way to get around here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm, naturally protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

**Build Your Own Bamboo Bike at the UK's First Workshop**

At the Bamboo Bike Club in Hackney Wick, east London, you can spend a weekend building your own custom bamboo bike frame. This unique workshop is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan. On a Saturday morning, the sound of machinery fills the air as participants gather to start their bike-building adventure.

Bamboo is becoming a popular material for bike frames, with companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire leading the way. However, these ready-made frames can be expensive, costing around $2,995 or £1,868. James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable and accessible, so they spent years developing a product that cyclists could build themselves.

Their goal was not just to sell bike frames but to share the joy of creating something unique and sustainable. The Bamboo Bike Club is more of a community project than a business, as both James and Ian have full-time jobs—James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. Despite this, their monthly courses are popular, offering a custom-designed bike frame and a fun weekend experience at a competitive price.

For someone like me, who struggles with DIY projects, the quality of the final product was a concern. On the first day, participants learn how to choose strong bamboo and form solid joints. The process involves gluing bamboo tubes together to create the bike's frame, with metal parts added for areas needing extra strength. James and Ian are always on hand to help, ensuring every cut and joint is perfect.

Most participants enjoy the challenge of building their own bike, and many are engineers. But even if you make mistakes, it's easy to try again with another piece of bamboo. Each piece is checked for quality, and you can choose from different styles like plain, black, or mottled bamboo.

Sunday is more relaxed, focusing on wrapping hemp bindings around the joints and securing them with epoxy resin. This creates a strong, durable frame. After a final waterproof coating, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other personal touches. These bamboo bikes are built to last, as strong as metal ones. Ian has used his bike for over a year on a long commute, and James has tested his off-road without any issues.

While bamboo bikes might look a bit rough compared to professional frames, they have a unique charm. They are perfect for a relaxed ride rather than racing. I chose a 'Classic English' style for a smooth, easy-going experience. The bikes ride well, absorbing vibrations for a comfortable journey.

James believes the real joy comes when the bike is on the road. They are light, easy to ride, and a lot of fun. And the best part? The cost is less than £500.

**Self-help Books**

Dione Reverend was just an editor at Random House in New York when she found a manuscript by an unknown pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. "I saw the title and knew it would be a bestseller," she says, laughing. She was right. Dr. Gray is now a multimillionaire, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book on how men and women can communicate better is a key part of the growing self-help industry. This industry claims to help Americans improve their lives, but it also takes advantage of their desires for self-improvement. It supports the New York publishing world. In Britain, the genre is also popular, with many books that seem exaggerated or fake. However, many self-help books are rejected for being too similar to others or too specific. This is a relief. Editors are always looking for the next big hit, focusing on how marketable a book is. "How promotable is the author? What's the 'hook'? Is it universal enough?" Ms. Reverend lists the important questions. She admits, "If someone has a catchy title, that's most of the battle won. You know you can reach people."

**Autobiographies**

There is an unspoken agreement between an autobiographer and the reader that the truth is being told. However, this agreement is often not fully kept. Writers might leave out things they find too embarrassing or unimportant. There are also more complex reasons for not telling the whole truth. An autobiographer might think that inventing stories can show the truth about themselves better than sticking to the facts. Or they might decide from the start not to follow the truth. They might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is fiction. This can be done without being cynical.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**

Experts say detective stories became popular because they reflect the conflicts of late 19th and early 20th-century society. These stories are like allegories. The crime represents human desires like lust or greed, and solving it shows how society can function smoothly again. In Hammett's stories, society returns to its old ways, but it is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same coin. They understand each other and are comfortable with each other. The detective is both a crook and a competitor. His mission is sometimes affected by his connection to the criminal, and sometimes his desire to punish is stronger because of this connection.

**Science Writing**

Stephen Jay Gould is considered today's greatest scientific essayist. To talk about his writing, I met him at the Grand Hotel, where he was staying while promoting his new book. Neither of us felt comfortable there. Gould said, "I couldn't write about a place like this. Trollope might, but he knew the culture. Understanding the culture is key to being a successful writer. Science is like its own civilization. Only scientists can present it well. If you don't live in the community and don't know its rules, you're at a disadvantage." One of Gould's rules is to never talk down to the reader. "Don't make concessions," he says. "You can simplify the language but not the argument. If readers feel patronized, your piece fails."

**Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym in the City of London, the air feels very cold. The gym has turned up the air-conditioning too much to cope with the unusually high summer temperatures. At quiet times, it feels as cold as the Arctic. This is an example of how air-conditioning is often overused in modern life. It has become a key part of both work and leisure, showing how humans can control or change the climate. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and ventilation, and have thicker walls that absorb less heat during the day and release it at night. These simple methods can be very effective and would greatly reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It is not surprising that as we enter a new millennium, there is a renewed interest in sundials. Sundials are tools that tell time based on the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were essential for keeping clocks accurate. But as clocks and watches improved, sundials became just decorative garden items, seen as outdated in a modern technological world. Now, people are taking them seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, believes their charm comes from their connection to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts working. They are calm, romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show long ago. There, serious-looking older women showed how to paint delicate flowers on a teacup with precise brushstrokes. It was fascinating because each stroke was perfect. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. It seemed like these women had either practiced for many years or had a natural talent for precision. Remembering this, I wondered who would be brave enough to take a china-painting class. Would beginners also have natural artistic skills? In reality, the class was not intimidating at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers on teacups as quickly and perfectly as I had seen before.

Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to book the trip, the travel agent mentioned that the other people in their package were a school group learning Italian. However, something went wrong. Due to a mistake, either at the travel agency or at the airport, Keith and Dawne ended up in Switzerland, at a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212.

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their details and said everything was fine. On the plane, they were surprised to hear people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.

When they arrived, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but Keith assumed it was part of the plan. It was almost midnight when they reached the hotel, and they were too tired to question anything. The next morning, they realized they were supposed to stay there for the whole holiday, which worried them.

The receptionist told them about the lake and the steamer to Interlaken. Keith calmly explained that they were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist didn't know about any mistake. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip, hoping it would help.

A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they had seen at Gatwick, approached them. Dawne explained they were in the wrong hotel. Mrs. Franks explained that Your-Kind-of-Holiday had many destinations and that all tickets and labels looked similar. She laughed, saying it was unlikely they would end up in the wrong place.

Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks left them standing there, and the receptionist was gone. Dawne thought Mrs. Franks seemed kind, but Keith was lost in thought, trying to remember everything that had happened.

An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, approached them, saying they had slept well because of the lakeside air. Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They didn't mention the irony of ending up on a holiday with elderly people when they wanted to escape such responsibilities. Uncle had insisted on this holiday for them, even though they had tried to convince him to join them.

**He Was a People Person**

American business leaders are now looking up to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a great example of good leadership. Eluned Price reports.

In Britain, many people know about Sir Ernest Shackleton and his achievements. However, in America, he is only now becoming well-known. The Wall Street Journal once described him as an "Antarctic explorer whose feats went unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which might be an exaggeration. But now, Americans are showing a lot of interest in him. Books about Shackleton and his famous ship, the Endurance, are being written and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a movie about his life.

Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his actions and learn leadership and communication lessons from his story. They even use the term "speaking Shackleton" to describe their approach. Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become a symbol for modern management consultants.

Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has been inspired by Shackleton for years. His company deals with communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises, like when a company's plant explodes or when many employees are laid off. MacGregor believes Shackleton is a great example of leadership and communication. Shackleton was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of his most important decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole in 1908. This decision showed his commitment to his men's safety.

In a crisis, people want to know someone is in charge. Unlike some managers today who avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take charge. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually crushed. Shackleton told his men they would reach safety if they trusted him and did their best. From their diaries, it's clear that Shackleton was always in control.

Shackleton planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and valued their opinions. He was flexible and ready to start over if needed. MacGregor says Shackleton's story helps clients understand leadership without feeling criticized.

Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, endurance, and patience. MacGregor notes that in America, people often want quick solutions, but sometimes it's better to wait. For example, if you invest in bonds and the interest rates change, it's better to hold on rather than sell at a loss. Similarly, if a product isn't selling, don't keep pushing it.

Shackleton led by example. On the return journey from the Endurance, he noticed the expedition photographer, Hurley, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, insisting he wear them. On a previous expedition, when they were starving, Shackleton offered his last biscuit to someone else, showing his selflessness.

Caroline Alexander, author of "Endurance," says that people today are increasingly interested in heroic stories. Shackleton represents the ideals we long for, standing out as a true hero.

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a primate called the aye-aye that has a lifestyle similar to a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye search for insect larvae hidden in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to gnaw into the wood and its long, thin third finger to reach and scoop out the insects.

Although scientists described the aye-aye's feeding habits over a hundred years ago, they have only recently discovered how it finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of some aye-ayes named Nosferatu, Poe, Samantha, and her daughter Annabelle. He wanted to see if they found insects by looking for signs on the wood's surface, like holes where insects might have entered to lay eggs.

Dr. Erickson gave the aye-ayes logs with several drilled holes. Some holes led to cavities with mealworms, while others were empty. The aye-ayes went directly to the cavities with food, showing they didn't need visual clues like surface holes. Dr. Erickson then tested if they used smell or sound to find the insects. Even when the smell was blocked, and the mealworms were dead and silent, the aye-ayes still found them.

Dr. Erickson discovered that the aye-ayes could sense the cavities themselves. When searching for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its middle finger and focuses its large ears forward. Dr. Erickson suggests that the aye-aye uses echo-location, listening for echoes from the taps that indicate a hollow space below. It might also hear insects moving when disturbed by the tapping.

The idea that the aye-aye fills the role of woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting. However, there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also search for insects in wood, so the woodpecker role might not be empty. The aye-aye can be seen as a mix of a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat. It also behaves like a squirrel, as its incisors grow continuously, and it has been seen in the wild gnawing through nut shells to get the nut meat with its long finger.

Title: 'Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives'

Most of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we really know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries and family stories give us only small, incomplete glimpses. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do. We might leave videos instead of photos, but they still only show part of the story.

Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people, creating a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if wanted. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary lives. The idea came to her when she realized how much of her own family's past was being forgotten. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "People say they do it for their children or for the future, but they also enjoy the process."

The promise of privacy helps people be honest. A 62-year-old man, who made and lost a fortune, shared his story. "I was surprised at what I revealed. Some things were painful, like my divorce," he says. "I did it for my family, so they might learn something, but I haven't let my children read it yet. If they insist, I will, but I'd prefer they read it after I'm gone."

He noticed patterns from his childhood that led to repeated mistakes. Ms. Renier has seen this in others too. "It's amazing how much people are influenced by their parents," she says. "The things parents say and do affect their children for life. People often marry someone their parents would approve of, or they rebel and do the opposite."

Many people still feel disappointed about unresolved issues with their parents, even 60 years later. They try to impress a parent who was never impressed, and some want to say, "I can't stand my mother."

Ms. Renier acts as a recorder, not an interrogator. "It's not for the public, and I'm not there to pry. People sometimes share things and then doubt if it should be included. I include it anyway, and they can decide later if they want to remove it. But generally, people want to be honest."

"It's not about vanity or thinking the world needs to know about their life. Things are changing fast, and we're losing touch with the past. This gives people a connection to their ancestors. People want a little immortality."

Each book involves up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story, organizing and interpreting the information. Modern technology allows her to produce everything except the book's binding. The final product is high quality and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost deters many. "I thought it would be more affordable," she says. "But my clients are often well-off, the kind who might have had portraits painted for their descendants."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few remaining collections of Greek and Roman sculpture casts in the world, with over six hundred pieces. Remember, none of the sculptures here are original; they are all precise copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is located in a specially designed gallery with great natural light. Plaster casts have many benefits: sculptures that were originally displayed together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together as they were meant to be. You can view almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in just one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery that shows a variety of photography exhibitions and related media. We regularly offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels, including our popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows all our members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (aged 12 to 16) to improve their skills with our Young Members program, led by our resident photographer. We sell photographic books and magazines and have a full range of photographic materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has an impressive collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all geological ages and from all over the world. It also holds Britain's oldest complete geological collection, belonging to Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). This includes nearly 10,000 rare and interesting specimens kept in their original early 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, greatly expanded the collections, creating the foundation of an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, allowing visitors to trace major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays the beautiful minerals and gems from the collection, with detailed labels explaining their nature and modern uses.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
This collection has over 400,000 air photographs, both oblique and vertical, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and conducts photographic work throughout Great Britain. The photographs are interesting as they provide a detailed, year-by-year record of the landscape, showing both the natural environment and human impact from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the knowledgeable library staff are happy to answer questions. The photographs cannot be borrowed, but copies can usually be purchased. These are made to order and typically take about a month.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world and is a unique tourist attraction in the region. Visitors can enjoy creating wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. By making resin copies, known as facsimiles, the center has preserved the originals while making brass rubbing accessible to everyone. Brass plates, used as an alternative to tomb statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many of the beautiful brasses were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and the widest range can be seen at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Paternity**

**A. The Theatre Director**

I have had 35 years of being around small children due to my unusual personal life, and I have loved every moment of it. This morning, I fed the baby, and to me, that's what being a father is all about. I'm very lucky with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This creates a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up, and I have become more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in physical punishment. I have slapped my children in anger before, but I don't support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be available. I'm here if they need me, but I let them contact me. If you start chasing them to ask why they haven't been in touch, you make them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**

I was young when my children were born, only about 25, and I admit I found the responsibilities and limitations quite annoying. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I have always appreciated. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to things I might have lost touch with: music, youth culture, and fashion. This has been very helpful for running the agency. I have never felt out of touch. When they were young, I was busy building my business, so I missed some things like their first concerts and sports days. I'm sad about that, but now there are benefits, like being able to take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and come to parties and advertising award ceremonies with us without feeling shy. I think it's an advantage that I do something they find glamorous and interesting.

**C. The Politician**

My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more politically active, time became a real issue. I make sure that I only accept weekend meetings and public appearances where there are facilities for one or more of the kids to come with me. If I didn't, they would just be left out. This way, they understand what I do when I'm not with them, and there's no feeling of Daddy disappearing. I've noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we are all becoming more aware of the need to involve our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**

My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were quite young, so I had to think more deeply about fatherhood than I might have otherwise. I made great efforts to stay in touch with the children. My ex-wife and I even tried living next door to each other for a while, so they could come and go as they wished, but I think Kate and Bonnie would say now that they found that quite confusing. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I'm not sure I was a very good father. It's true I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I think I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate was complaining just the other day that we were too liberal. I think I could have introduced more structure and order. Instead, I took a very relaxed approach. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as I do about my youngest. In that way, your kids never leave you.

**E. The TV Presenter**

I was ready for kids. I had turned 30, met my wife, and we had a lovely house, so we thought, "Why keep spending our money on new sofas every Saturday when we could have a child instead?" Having my daughter Betty has made me come to terms with who I am. You feel you are doing something very special when you have a child, and you are. But you are also becoming just one more parent in a long line of parents. It's a great equalizer. I do get annoyed sometimes, but if ever there is a moment of irritation, it goes away with just one look at her. A baby's smile is the greatest way to make you feel better. It can melt a grown man.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's long play about a powerful warrior can feel endless, but in Terry Hands' version, it's one of the most exciting shows of the year. He has cut a lot from the original text, making it fast and full of action. Antony Sher is amazing in the main role, doing stunts like somersaulting from a balcony and sliding down a rope while speaking. His performance is captivating, showing a wild desire for power and glory. A must-see.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

**B. Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall, first shown in Manchester, is now in London. The first act creates a tense atmosphere as two couples talk on a sunny lawn. The second act shifts location and becomes a deep, emotional look at the impact of illness. Wall was a promising talent lost too soon at 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*

**C. Amphibians**  
Billy Roche, an Irish playwright, brings another play set in Wexford. This one looks at the decline of the fishing industry with rich characters, strong emotions, and unexpected humor. The play can feel a bit unfocused but ends powerfully.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
A classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play writers trying to kill each other. It's familiar but cleverly done.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*

**E. The Alchemist**  
Director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century con artists. First shown in Stratford, it works well on the Barbican's main stage, with great performances by Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

**F. The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society moves to London after success in Edinburgh. The production is stylish, the acting excellent, and the play is an overlooked classic.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*

**G. Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a charming take on Beauty and the Beast set in London suburbia. With a beautiful score by John Pattison, it celebrates romantic love and is a delightful show. London producers should take note.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*

**H. The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy is almost disappointing, but saved by great comic performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Others seem a bit embarrassed.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

**I. The Voysey Inheritance**  
Another revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. This play about a seemingly honest lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son is excellent.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek** by Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game by watching a suspicious bookshop. She is surprised to see her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him to turn her against her friends. Coppard creates believable characters in Emma's friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes intense, especially when she is trapped in a cellar. The book explores family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always protectors. It's a powerful and convincing read.

**Backtrack** by Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, discover that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915, where eight people died. The story uses different viewpoints and documents like maps and first-hand accounts to uncover the truth. The reader, like the characters, must work hard to understand what happened. It's a clever and complex novel that rewards careful reading.

**Pigeon Summer** by Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer doesn't fit into her family or male-dominated society. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves to find work, she takes care of them and wins prizes, despite conflicts with her stressed mother. Set in 1930, this story shows that there are different kinds of intelligence. Thoughtful readers will find it satisfying.

**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
Robert Westall tells a chilling story of rural prejudice through the eyes of a mature woman, Rose. She rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage to escape her materialistic life. A fierce cat and strange items in the house reveal why Yaxley disappeared. The locals become hostile, putting Rose and her children in danger. By the end, the violence is controlled, but Rose is troubled by her son's ruthlessness. It's a gripping story.

**Someone's Mother is Missing** by Harry Mazer  
Sam, from the poorer side of the family, is in awe of his sophisticated cousin Lisa. When Lisa's privileged life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the value of family. The story is a bit slow in parts but has gentle humor and convincingly shows the growing closeness between the two teenagers. It's interesting for both boys and girls.

**Stanley's Aquarium** by Barry Faville  
Barry Faville writes with humor and confidence, bringing his New Zealand setting to life. Robbie, the narrator, takes a job gardening for Stanley, an elderly man. At first, Robbie finds Stanley fascinating, but later repellent. When Robbie discovers what Stanley keeps in his aquarium, the story takes a thrilling turn while still exploring character and relationships. It's unusual and compelling.

**Dodger** by Libby Gleeson  
This is a sad story about Mick's troubled personal relationships and difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, a teacher's letters, Mick's notes, and a sympathetic narrative. Mick learns to overcome others' negative expectations and his own low self-esteem through a role in a school play and the help of a sensitive teacher. It's highly recommended, though it's a painful read, especially at the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing their ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, it looked like a regular airplane. The pilot informed the young passengers that it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964, based on the Boeing 707 passenger plane. However, the inside was different, and the 13 students from Europe and America were about to have an extraordinary experience. Inside, the plane was a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, except for a few at the back, where the nervous young scientists sat. They had spent 12 months competing with other students across the continent for a chance to be on this flight. The European Space Agency challenged them to propose creative experiments to conduct in weightless conditions. Those with the best ideas won a spot on this unique flight, which was like an incredible roller-coaster ride.

For the next two hours, the Boeing's flight would mimic a giant bird flying erratically, soaring upwards and then diving towards Earth. The goal was to create a moment of weightlessness at the top of each curve. At 3,000 meters, the pilot cut the engines, and the plane continued to rise due to its momentum before gravity pulled it back down. In the brief seconds between rising and falling, the plane and everything inside became weightless, and the 13 students would feel as if they were closer to the moon than to Earth.

The plane took off smoothly, but any thoughts that we were on a regular flight vanished when the pilot put the Boeing into a steep 45-degree climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and bodies were scattered across the cabin floor. Then the engines stopped, and we instantly felt weightless. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence: the floor felt like a trampoline, and a single step sent us flying towards the ceiling. We drifted aimlessly; directions like left, right, up, or down no longer made sense. Only gravity, by anchoring us, allows us to understand the concept of moving somewhere else.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. The return of gravity was not as immediate as its loss, but it was sudden enough that some students landed with a thud. With the first curve completed, some students turned pale at the thought of 29 more to come. Thirty curves meant ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. The Dutch students quickly began studying the movements of Leonardo, their robotic cat, to understand how cats always land on their feet. They released the device, which floated belly-up, and one student managed to turn it belly-down using radio controls. However, during a less controlled return to gravity, another student accidentally landed on top of it.

Next to the slightly dazed robotic cat, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how the quality of metal joins is affected by the lack of gravity, with future space station construction in mind. Another team from Utah State University explored the possibility of creating solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by ultraviolet sunlight. They spent the flight trying to produce these films in microgravity. They believe that once perfected, satellites could use solar sails to harness the sun's radiation, similar to how a yacht uses the wind.

After two hours of swinging between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unsettled, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This was an experience that would stay with us for a long time. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I already wanted to become an astronaut, but now I want to even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**

**Jonathon Porritt Talks to Danny Danziger**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.

I had a unique time in my life when I didn't experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer in the UK, which is winter in New Zealand, so I had nine winters in a row. I enjoyed it because I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my siblings and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which was special since my father grew up there. They found a plot about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very fertile, but it was good for planting trees.

I've always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing various farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees appealed to me. I was eager to start, and my family became enthusiastic as we progressed. We began planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted all 70 acres.

In 1968, New Zealand had a very rainy winter. It rained almost every day while we were planting, and I was often wet and cold. Each morning, I faced the challenge of getting ready for another day of planting. I would step out of the Land Rover, already damp from the previous day, with wet boots and slippery laces. During this time, I had many thoughts and reflections about life.

In the first year, I worked with an experienced tree-planter, which was helpful since I had never planted trees seriously before. We used a planting bag filled with as many trees as possible. The bag was heavy at first, but it got easier as it emptied. The hardest part was keeping the planting lines straight. We used three poles to mark the lines and planted along them. I enjoyed the physical work, and it made me fit. After a while, planting became automatic, and I developed a rhythm. It was a regular process: taking a tree from the bag, digging a hole, planting it, and moving on.

Mentally, it was interesting. My mind wandered, and I started thinking about the natural world and our place in it. These thoughts have influenced my life ever since. I've returned to New Zealand four times to see the trees grow, which is satisfying. I worry when I read about storms or droughts in New Zealand, but the trees have done well and are now 20 years old.

In 1984, I took a break from teaching and spent three months alone in New Zealand. I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*, in a simple cabin on the tree farm. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. I still feel a strong connection to that place. It's where I feel most connected to the earth, and it's a powerful bond.

**Bringing Up Badgers**

When one of my helpers handed me a cardboard box, my first thought was, "What now?" My husband Derek and I had turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an "open farm" six years ago, and we had become known for caring for orphaned animals. The noise from the box—a mix between a cackle and a bark—was unfamiliar to me. Curious, I looked inside and found three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their coats felt like velvet, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and spend their early life underground. If orphaned, they usually die of starvation and are never found. These three were brought in by building contractors who accidentally dug into their sett while laying drain pipes. The mother was found dead with her babies still nursing. The cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing their fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them by the stove for warmth. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe each cub with a warm cloth to mimic the mother’s licking. This helped them empty their bowels and bladder. For the first few days, they were fed every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though unsteadily. With each other for company and a heated pad as a substitute "mum," they seemed content.

Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was lethargic, although he was still eating normally. It was a warning sign I missed. The next morning, I found him dead. A vet's post-mortem revealed Willow had died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat, even with antibiotics, in such a small animal. Disheartened by my failure, I continued caring for the others. Then, six days later, a local farmer who heard about our cubs brought me another male cub. He found it abandoned behind some silage bags. The mother wouldn’t return because the area had been disturbed too much, and the cub was cold and hungry. We named him Willow II. At six weeks old, he was about two weeks younger than the females. Over the next few days, I discovered why his mother left him. He was very difficult to feed. To get him to drink, I had to keep moving the bottle's teat around in his mouth and squeezing it. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t drunk all day. By the end of April, the females were weaned onto creamed rice and then anything else. Willow was different. He was happy to stop using the bottle but couldn’t eat without walking through his food, tipping it over, or sitting in it. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly chewed, played with, and finally ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready to try other foods.

At nearly five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, plus beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and even plant shoots or roots. My badgers were better off than others that year; the summer was very hot, making it hard to dig for earthworms. By August, my foundlings had become nocturnal and would only go for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where the long grass was a playground. The cubs would get excited, fluff up their fur to look like snowballs, and chase each other's tails. As "human badgers," we were part of this game. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, never did. His reactions to being caught were as colorful as his bruises. During these late-night walks in the dry period, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely expanding their territories to find food, as badgers are very territorial and will kill intruders. We were warned they might climb into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we covered the gate with sheet metal to keep it secure.

The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response was so great that we started an appeal to build a sett on the farm for them. With advice, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew up the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate facing their usual walking direction. It had three chambers, one slightly larger, with a glass side so people could see inside from a darkened enclosure. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they forgot about the walks, excited by climbing through the tunnels and arranging bedding. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company, Badgerline, sponsored part of the appeal, and local firms donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers with a home of their own. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I returned to check on them and saw three badgers curled up in their chambers, sound asleep. These days, I don’t walk with them as often, especially since they’re not fully awake until midnight. We see Primrose occasionally (she joined a neighboring sett), but Bluebell and Willow II still rush up to greet us before dashing off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have accepted.

Text: 'In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to map compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his major achievements was mapping 'compass variations' during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors couldn't accurately correct their compasses, making it hard to determine longitude and navigate the seas. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at the time, set out for the Cape Verde Islands to map declination in the North and South Atlantic. The first trip was cut short due to crew problems, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, past South Georgia, up to Newfoundland, and back to England. From these travels, Halley published a 'New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans' in 1701. This chart was very useful to sailors for over a century until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it outdated. Dr. Clark, who also loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first cross-Antarctica expedition, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley during a two-year stay at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist. 'Halley led a remarkable life,' Dr. Clark says. 'He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He wasn't just an astronomer; he also did geophysics research. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and found time for other interests.' During this time, Halley developed a diving bell and advised Sir Isaac Newton on his book Principia Mathematica, the foundation of classical physics. Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The planned expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking the same measurements Halley did, but with more accurate instruments. These measurements need updating because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data collected will help improve the current mathematical model of Earth's magnetic field, known as the international geomagnetic reference field. 'It's common to measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field. You need to know true north to measure the direction,' says Dr. Clark. 'On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites to find that.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. Coincidentally, a Danish satellite will be taking similar measurements globally. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill any gaps in its coverage of the Atlantic Ocean and notes that ground-based measurements are useful for comparison. It's easy to forget how important Halley's Atlantic journey was. It was the first scientific sea expedition, and Halley was the first civilian appointed as a naval captain to pursue what many saw as an obsession with declination. Does Dr. Clark have the skills to make his voyage successful? Besides spending two years in Antarctica and working in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey, he has already sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with four different crews. Does he share Halley's obsessive nature? 'I'm willing to dedicate eight months of my life to this, so some might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to cross the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

**POWER DRESSING**

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens. This display raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: in a world where survival is tough, how did such extravagant features evolve? Darwin believed that evolution happened through natural selection, where the strongest and most adaptable survive. However, the peacock's tail seemed to contradict this idea because it is large and cumbersome. To explain this, Darwin proposed 'sexual selection,' suggesting that females choose mates based on beauty alone.

Darwin's colleague, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He thought that if peahens preferred showy tails, there must be a practical reason. Perhaps these tails indicated some hidden quality that helped survival. Wallace believed the tail was not just for show but a sign of a male's overall fitness.

Today, researchers like Marion Petrie at Whipsnade are trying to answer two main questions: Do peahens really prefer males with the most impressive tails? And do these males have other advantages, as Wallace suggested, or is it just about appearance, as Darwin thought?

Observations at Whipsnade show that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails, which are linked to tail length. These males attract more mates. However, it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways. Some scientists, like William Hamilton from Oxford University, suggest that showy males might be healthier and free of parasites, but this hasn't been proven in Whipsnade's peacocks yet.

This year, Dr. Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive and less attractive males to see if the former grow faster or are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is practical.

There's another theory by R.A. Fisher called 'Fisher's Runaway.' It suggests that if females start preferring slightly better tails, over generations, this preference and the trait itself will grow stronger. This could lead to the extravagant tails we see today, supporting Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake.'

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of impressive yachts with the latest technology. Most of these yachts are based on a design change from 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly anchored in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. You might think I'm a romantic dreamer, and maybe I am, but this boat uses both old-fashioned design and modern technology. 

Modern technology is essential in boat design and building today, but it often separates sailors from the real experiences of being at sea. These are the experiences they wanted to find by sailing. I'm not saying sailors should suffer through every hardship. I always make sure my boats have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable beds. But why sail if every sail sets and furls itself automatically? Sometimes, dealing with the sails is part of the adventure. 

Also, why move the steering from the safe back of the boat to a risky spot in the middle? The sad reason is to create a cabin like a luxury liner, with a bed bigger than the one at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a floating house. 

When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, for a TV race around Britain, the former owner said it had every comfort but no luxury. During my time with Hirta, I learned how right he was. Hirta had heavy sails, no pumped water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest and kindest boat I've ever sailed. 

However, classic boats need a lot of care. After a back injury, I realized I had to end my 15-year relationship with Hirta. I couldn't find a suitable younger boat, so I decided to build a new one. The Westerman has never let me down. Designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett used computer programs, but Irens first sketched the boat on a napkin. He then made a model, like in the old days. We refined the design using computers until it was perfect. 

The finished boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. She looks timeless, sails beautifully, and her interior, made from reclaimed pitch pine, feels peaceful. This is because she was designed purely as a sailing boat, not based on the furniture we might add. This traditional method works well. The Westerman shows that you don't need to follow trends to be satisfied and that history can teach us valuable lessons. Made from wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. She has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a traditional one.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places and share their experiences.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was excited to spend six days at Henlow Grange because I needed a break. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt relaxed right away. On the first day, I rested and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors were very skilled, and I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, such as aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and facials. The staff were friendly and professional, creating a lively and enthusiastic atmosphere. Henlow is planning to add a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds or take a peaceful walk in the garden. By the end of my stay, I felt energetic and happy. I look forward to visiting again. This is a great place for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

From the moment I entered Shrubland Hall, I felt calm and relaxed. The hall has a beautiful library and conservatory, and plenty of space to be alone if you wish. Upon arrival, everyone gets a medical check-up, which includes weight and blood pressure checks. I was called a "patient," which felt strange since I was healthy. However, they found a shoulder issue during the check-up, and the fitness instructor helped me work on it. Each person gets a specific diet plan. I lost weight without fasting, but I did get a headache from hunger on the second day. My meals included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and fruit with yogurt for dinner. If you're not on a diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is delicious. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day, and extra treatments are reasonably priced. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys Manor is not a health farm, but a charming old manor with cozy log fires and a large lounge. If you're watching your weight, you might want to skip the gourmet food, which includes rich sauces and creamy desserts made by a French chef. Luckily, there's a gym and pool to help burn off the calories. You can choose a health-conscious diet if you want to lose weight. The spa facilities include a bath, steam room, sauna, and treatment rooms. There's also a sports injury clinic where I got advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested exercises and massages. Careys is both comfortable and luxurious, and the surrounding countryside is great for exploring. - Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. The estate has beautiful woodland walks and gardens. Waldo's, the restaurant, is famous for its delicious food. The menu is extensive, and the meals are wonderful, especially the sticky-toffee pudding. After enjoying a meal, I spent time in the gym to burn off some calories. I also had a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden offers fitness assessments and beauty treatments if you want to use them before enjoying a meal at Waldo's. - Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It's delicious but high in calories, which isn't great if you're trying to lose weight. The aromatherapy massage is also fantastic. I chose relaxing oils and fell asleep twice during the massage. The modern facilities are well-run, with many therapists and beauty rooms, so it's easy to book appointments. They offer a variety of treatments, from manicures to deep-cleansing facials. Guests include football teams, families, friends, and singles. I would love to visit here once a month. - Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans split from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much genetically. We are still over 98% the same as chimps. This means that what makes us different from animals is a recent development. Our ability to create art and other human traits must come from a small part of our genes. This is a big responsibility for just a few genes. 

Studies of animal behavior show that many traits we thought were unique to humans are not. For example, both chimpanzees and sea otters use tools. Chimps use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple languages with different sounds for predators like leopards, eagles, and snakes. These findings suggest that the differences between us and animals are not as big as we once thought.

Art might be one of the few things that truly sets us apart. But if art is a unique human trait, it's strange that our ancestors didn't create it for most of our history. The earliest art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these don't last over time. Clear evidence of human art, like cave paintings and sculptures, only appears around 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.

If we say our recent creativity makes us different, how is our art different from animal creations? Three main ideas are often suggested: human art is not practical, it's made for beauty, and it's learned, not instinctive.

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means human art doesn't help us survive or reproduce, unlike most animal behaviors. While human art can communicate ideas, it's not the same as passing on genes. Birdsong, for example, helps birds defend territory or attract mates, directly helping them reproduce. By this measure, human art is different.

Second, human art is often made for aesthetic pleasure. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during mating season, suggesting they sing for practical reasons, not just for pleasure. This makes human art seem unique.
