She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed it off, saying everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, a line had formed outside, and Amanda felt nervous. She worried about remembering orders, but everything was automated, so that wasn't a problem. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she couldn't get used to the loud music. She had to keep asking customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and wanted to soak her feet. She was surprised when a waitress said it had been a 'quiet' day. Amanda realized waitressing was more tiring than she thought. She had always believed it was a job for shy people, but it actually required being outgoing and calm under pressure. She didn't like the pay either and didn't receive any tips. Amanda was happy to return to her children, finding it easier than waitressing.

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy was nervous but excited to be a 'mum' for the day. She had been warned that Amanda's daughters were cheeky, but she thought she could handle it. After Amanda left for work, Cindy had to dress and feed the girls. She dropped Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, thinking she would have some free time. However, Amanda left a note with chores like making beds, cleaning, and doing laundry. At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. When Sophie came home, the girls turned the sofa into a trampoline and screamed loudly. Cindy hoped they would tire themselves out, but they didn't. She managed to get them to bed by 8 pm, but they kept asking for water to stay up and watch TV. Cindy found it exhausting to negotiate with them all evening. She didn't realize how tiring it was to look after two small children, with no time for herself and a huge sense of responsibility. Despite this, she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, a 42-year-old dairy farmer, swapped with Hilary, a 30-year-old primary school teacher. On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a treat. She was unsure about what to wear to school, as she couldn't show up in farm clothes. At assembly, she faced about 400 pupils and hoped she blended in. She helped with a maths class where children worked in groups, which was different from her school days. She also assisted with a nature project involving snails. By lunchtime, she was tired and looked forward to a break, but teachers only had a few minutes to eat. She attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson and a French lesson, where the children practiced on her, revealing her rusty French. Finally, they had Physical Education, and Rosemary was exhausted, but the children were full of energy. She found speaking in front of the class daunting. Despite teachers having more holidays, she preferred farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, surprised that Rosemary had been up for three hours. The farm had 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 ewes. Rosemary also made ice-cream, yoghurt, and cream to sell. Hilary spent the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk and packaging ice-cream. It was hard to resist tasting the treats. At lunchtime, she checked the sheep and helped a fallen ewe, which could die if left for more than 12 hours. After feeding the calves, she started milking, which took two-and-a-half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year. Hilary found the day lonely and missed the children, as animals don't talk back. The hardest part was not being able to take time off, as the cows needed milking daily. Rosemary only gets about three days of holiday a year. Farming seemed romantic, but the reality was different, with irregular income and dependence on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without a musical background. Hakan Hardenberger, the only child of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has become a standout trumpet player by the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new compositions. When you meet him, he appears youthful and energetic, much like the sound of his trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a TV feature highlighted his work and growth, filmed in both the UK and Sweden.

Hardenberger was born near Malmo, and his career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong's music, decided to give him a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and Hakan played it constantly. His mother found a teacher for him, the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, who quickly recognized Hakan's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful for having such a dedicated teacher from the start. Nilsson was passionate about the trumpet and would connect with players worldwide, always searching for the perfect mouthpiece. However, Hardenberger notes that the trumpet is a simple instrument with unavoidable flaws, and no two mouthpieces are identical. He believes in understanding and working with these imperfections.

From a young age, Hardenberger had a unique sound, which he developed early on. Unlike John Wallace, a British trumpet virtuoso who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger always saw himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also focused on solo performances. Hardenberger collected Andre's records and looked up to him. His parents supported his dream of becoming a professional trumpet player. At 15, he needed to decide where to study. America was considered too far and risky, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud advised against joining an orchestra, comparing it to gardening. Hardenberger knew he played better than others his age, but it was during his first competition at 17 in Paris that he realized he had a special ability to connect with audiences. Thibaud encouraged him to enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger only prepared for the first round but advanced to the second, where he knew most of the pieces. In the final, he faced a challenging concerto. He didn't win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and noticed that people listened to him despite his mistakes. Hardenberger's honesty about his work might seem arrogant, but it's not. He avoids analyzing his gift for communication, believing that trying to explain it could ruin it. He thinks the power of music lies in its ability to move people.

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It's a unique tale about human power, history, and humor. The author has skillfully created a world with its own history and traditions. The book is known for its humor and the author's special way of seeing things, combined with deep psychological insight. It's a challenging but rewarding read.

**B.** Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she wouldn't meet someone like Sheila, who is from a working-class background and takes care of her elderly father and grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe. After the court case, neither boy talks about the incident. Leo, who was a good student and never fought before, won't say why he did it. Joe recovers physically but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him consumes her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author is great at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives and captures a mother's feeling that she can never do enough.

**C.** This book, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most remote Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. It connects this story with important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the daydreams of a young character, Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears at one point but returns after World War II, having learned to value the simple lives of his ancestors.

**D.** After a recent successful book, the author has written a sequel with the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life is a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, and Rosie helps her in her enjoyable manipulation of suitors and friends. By the end, Aurora must face the reality of aging and a new generation taking over. The author is good at revealing the sadness beneath the ordinary aspects of life and focuses on the unpredictable nature of events.

**E.** Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses impressive descriptive language to show each person's journey of self-discovery as they prepare to return home, their spirits renewed by life at sea. The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which are both challenging and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their different jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and what a typical workday looks like.

**A. The Brain Surgeon**

**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34

**Anne's Day:**  
Anne wakes up at 6:30 am, goes to the gym at 7 am, and starts work by 8 am. She begins operating at 8:30 am on Mondays, Wednesdays, and some Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can last all day. Sometimes, she works for ten hours without a break. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. While she doesn't feel stressed during surgery, she often worries about the next day's tasks. Brain surgery is usually a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it's very rewarding. From 10 am to 1 pm, she meets patients to explain surgeries, which she enjoys. However, time constraints can make it hard to comfort upset patients. Anne leaves work between 6 pm and 8 pm. She is on call some nights and weekends and always carries her pager. On holidays, she worries about her patients for the first few days and dreams about operating at night. She finds it hard to relax.

**B. The Senior Designer**

**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31

**Marita's Day:**  
Marita gets up at 7:45 am, leaves home by 8:20 am, and arrives at work by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, her team meets to discuss projects and any issues. Her team includes three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. Only 10-15% of her work is design; the rest is production. She receives a brief from the client and spends three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After presenting her ideas to the client and getting approval, she manages budgets and hires photographers and illustrators. She coordinates with printers to ensure deadlines are met. Managing multiple projects can be stressful, and no day is the same. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, often at a pub. If a client likes her designs, it's very satisfying, but it's disappointing if a project is rejected. She gets home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often later, and finds it hard to unwind.

**C. The Chauffeur**

**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42

**Linda's Day:**  
Linda usually wakes up at 7 am, but on days she meets early flights, she gets up between 4:30 am and 5 am. Around 10:30 or 11 am, she might go for a bike ride or swim. Since her job involves a lot of sitting, she watches her diet and exercises regularly. She eats a big breakfast and snacks during the day. Clients often ask for recommendations on restaurants and shops, so she needs to know the area well. Most jobs are pre-booked, allowing her to plan routes. Not all passengers are polite, but most are well-behaved, and she has good relationships with regular clients. She works seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, and tries to sleep by 11 pm.

**D. The Landscape Gardener**

**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27

**Tracy's Day:**  
Tracy gets up at 7 am, leaves by 7:30 am, and starts her first job. She and her assistant mainly maintain gardens they designed. They work mostly in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each. Around 11 am, they have a big breakfast at a cafe. In summer, she may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. Her business office is at home, where she checks messages and returns calls. She often meets clients in the evening to discuss garden designs. They use old materials to make gardens look aged, but sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren't appealing. It's satisfying to see a garden completed and blooming. Tracy finds it hard to relax in the evenings because she can hear the business phone. She sleeps well because the physical work is tiring. The job is tough but allows for creativity.

**E. The Civil Engineer**

**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27

**Zena's Day:**  
Zena arrives at the construction site by 8:30 am. As an assistant resident engineer, she oversees the building of bridges and a retaining wall. She ensures contractors follow schedules, safety rules, and minimize environmental impact. She coordinates site professionals and solves problems. Contractors start at 6 am, so she first checks in with the clerk of works to learn about any issues. Her day involves paperwork and answering design questions. Lunch is usually a quick half-hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm. When contractors are on break, she checks the site. Her role can cause conflicts, so she maintains open communication. She meets the duty resident engineer daily but acts immediately if urgent issues arise. Zena leaves the site around 6 pm and is always on call.

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I handle customer programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards program in major European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and answering emails. I manage advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan strategies and future developments. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. There are nine customer service units in Europe, and I travel to different markets once or twice a week to discuss issues. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I start work at 10:00 am and go through the mail, which includes 10 to 20 demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day about campaigns or projects for artists, involving the press, marketing, and the managing director. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be constructive because it's important work for the artists. I know instinctively if the sound fits our label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs, producers, and musicians. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing and sales. I also oversee budgets and spending. I leave work at 7:00 pm at the earliest and often go to gigs, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. After gigs, I might visit an artist in the studio. My social life is mostly work-related, and I often get home at 1:00 am, where I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I open the mail, check the diary for client visits, and wait to see who comes in. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and making sales, knowing the furniture is going to a good home. We sell antiques priced from £1,000 to £6,000, buying from London salerooms, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work with a full-time restorer and liaise with gilders, picture framers, and paper repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while having coffee to stay updated on the business, and I often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts monthly and the tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm, and it usually takes me about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work set shifts, leaving home at 6:00 am for early shifts. At 7:00 am, I take over from the night shift at one of the four control positions in the tower. We rotate stations, working for about an hour and a half, then taking a half-hour break before returning to a different station. The team includes air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and a watch manager, and we control aircraft movements together. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing me to read up on new air traffic requirements between 12 and 4:00 am. It's crucial to be alert in this job, so I don't hesitate to call in sick if I'm unwell. The work is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually a general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I'm on an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is at the till and coordinate staff lunches and breaks. I spend the morning helping customers and ordering books for them. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be frustrating when they expect me to gather many books based on reviews. Between 2:00 pm and 4:00 pm, publishers' representatives visit, and I discuss new titles for the coming months. I decide how many copies of a title the shop might sell. When featuring a new title, I ensure it's delivered on time. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm. I work late shifts twice a week, closing the computer system, locking up, and going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact our freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies abroad, warning clients of potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. My first executive preview is due by 10:00 am, and the second by 11:00 am, so I quickly gather stories. I type them, send them to my editor for approval, then make any changes before they go live. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events or stay updated. I leave work around 6:00 pm. It's hard to switch off, and I'm often awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

**A. What Makes a Good Leader?**

A good leader is someone who inspires others and brings about change. They guide people forward. Leadership isn't about your background or how tall you are, as some early thinkers believed. It's not just about being smart either. Pat Dixon, who wrote "Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace," says leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is crucial, and to spread it, a leader should speak clearly and with confidence. Dixon says it's about having the courage to say "I believe" instead of "I think."

**B. Discovering Leadership Potential**

John van Maurik, who runs a Leadership in Management course, believes many people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing, developing, and using these hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it's easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst, Mahatma Gandhi, or Richard Branson, it might be harder to see it in our own workplaces. Yet, leadership is now seen as essential for effective management.

**C. Reflecting on Leadership Styles**

Think about the best and worst bosses you've had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these? The best leader motivated and supported you. The worst made you feel unimportant and kept information from you, blaming you when things went wrong. The first led well; the second just managed poorly.

**D. Leaders vs. Managers**

Leaders and managers are different. Managers like working within set rules. Leaders create new paths. Michael Shea, author of "Leadership Rules," says a good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can transform a struggling organization, whether it's a company, a sports team, or a nation.

**E. Improving Your Leadership Skills**

Whether you're the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons:

- Leadership is best when you choose to do it. Find out what you're passionate about. When you feel inspired to lead, use that energy and take action.
- Think of yourself as a leader. Recognize your ability to lead.
- Collaboration is good, but sometimes firm leadership is needed. Try different styles. If you're usually a negotiator, try taking charge. Notice how this changes the outcome.
- Set goals and exceed them. Look at your job and identify where leadership can improve your effectiveness and career prospects.

**F. Developing Leadership**

- Leadership doesn't just happen. It develops from taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and give feedback.
- Don't assume your leadership style will immediately win over colleagues. It might even push them away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don't have to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be.
- Be visible and accessible to those who matter. Remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know where your contribution is vital and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Film Critic Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before making Titanic, director James Cameron created this intense Cold War thriller. It’s about oil rig workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The main character, Bud, and his team remind us of the cool heroes in Howard Hawks' movies. The production design and special effects are very impressive, but the dialogue and character development are not as strong. Despite the skilled filmmaking, the story feels like a typical B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of Andrew Marton's version of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal is interesting to compare with Terrence Malick's new film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's is a more traditional war movie, often closer to the book. It focuses on one soldier and his tough relationship with his sergeant. Although Malick's film is richer and more complex, Marton's version has its highlights. The flashback scene, where the soldier dreams of his wife, is portrayed with a harshness that might be more effective than Malick's softer imagery.

**C. On Guard**  
Loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, this entertaining swashbuckler is better than most musketeer films. Fabrice Luchini plays a perfect villain, a sneaky politician causing chaos behind the scenes. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is short-lived. Daniel Auteuil, while perhaps too serious for this type of film, also shines as an acrobat-turned-swordsman. The filmmakers use costume-drama clichés with such wit and energy that it remains enjoyable.

**D. Character**  
This is a visually beautiful but somber story set in early 20th-century Rotterdam. The detailed production and costume design make the film look like a museum exhibit. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is ruthless when evicting tenants. The tense relationship with his son is central to the story, but the filmmakers focus too much on period details, missing the chance to fully explore the dark and intense narrative.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This digitally re-mastered video release highlights director Leone's skill. The sound editing is excellent, making every sound clear and distinct. The story is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's powerful music brings it back to life. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Eli Wallach), as they all act ruthlessly in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
This three-hour war epic by Darryl Zanuck boasts "forty-eight international stars." With four directors and 23,000 extras, it feels overdone. The early scenes, where soldiers wait for the invasion, are as slow for the audience as for the characters. Logistically impressive, it is best suited for the big screen. On video, the experience is less impactful.

**BOOK A**  
"Compelling Evidence" by Steve Martin is a gripping story. The narrator is a lawyer trying to start a new practice after leaving a big law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife, who is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, with the verdict uncertain until the end, and there's a surprising twist in the final pages. This is a great first book in a popular genre.

**BOOK B**  
"Curtains for the Cardinal" starts with excitement and follows Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy. He gets involved in political and church intrigues and a high-society murder. We always believe he will solve the case. The plot is complex and the book is a bit long, but it's still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C**  
"File Under: Deceased" introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, created by first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah is a tax inspector who starts investigating when a strange man dies at her feet. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a local detective sergeant, Leah is determined and successful.

**BOOK D**  
"Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk to remove drug dealers from a poor area in Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and there is more philosophy than violence. As always, Parker provides high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E**  
"False Prophet" by Faye Kellermann features detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate an attack and burglary at the home of a famous film star's daughter. Kellermann's easy writing style and insight into human behavior make this mystery entertaining.

**BOOK F**  
In "Blood Red, Snow White," Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock write about a lawyer with a female client. The action happens outside the courtroom, and the lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book mixes romance, money, and violence to create a suspenseful novel.

**BOOK G**  
"Dead for a Ducat" by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher, who becomes a target. A funny group of characters gathers to film a Robin Hood story, but Philip feels his career is not going well. Shaw usually entertains, but this time the story is not as strong as his usual work.

**BOOK H**  
"Fall Down Easy" by Lawrence Gough is his best book in a while. Canadian police are after a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow build-up of tension and the portrayal of the smart, troubled robber make this more than just an average detective novel.

At 34, Tim Pozzi decided to leave his stable job and go backpacking in Southeast Asia for a year. He reflects on why he and others his age are making such bold choices. Although he has traveled before, after university, he spent two years exploring North and South America. But life happened—he fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to a steady income. Over time, he realized he was sacrificing his personal happiness for his job. Quitting felt like taking control of his life again. 

Many of his friends are now married with children, and while they wouldn't trade places with him, they do envy his freedom. Tim is single and has no strong career ambitions, so he feels he should make the most of his freedom. However, he is nervous about the practicalities, like renting out his flat and deciding where to travel. He is also worried about fitting in with younger backpackers and adjusting to a simpler lifestyle.

Tim is not alone in this feeling. More people in their late twenties and thirties are choosing to leave their established lives to travel. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says people are realizing they can have adventures if they are brave and organized. For some, like Danny and his girlfriend Tammy, it's a chance to have one last adventure before settling down. Others, like Matt, use travel as a way to transition from one phase of life to another.

The modern workforce is more flexible, with more short-term contracts, making it easier for people to take breaks. Some companies even support career breaks, knowing employees might return with new perspectives. Dan Hiscocks, from Travellerseye, notes that many people are reassessing their lives and realizing that jobs are not permanent. Travel offers a chance to reflect and consider what they truly want.

Jennifer Cox argues that this trend is not about avoiding adulthood but about seeking a balanced life. Ben, a 32-year-old heading to Central America, sees it as running towards something he wants, not escaping. He does feel nervous about leaving his comfortable routine behind, but he is excited about the possibilities.

Tim shares these feelings but admits that a difficult boss pushed him to make this decision. Often, a significant life event, like a breakup or job loss, can be the catalyst for such a change. Despite his initial hesitation, Tim is now excited about the year ahead and feels proud to be taking this step. He believes many others in his situation feel the same way.

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her journalism career and felt disconnected from the technological changes. She shares how she turned her home into an efficient workspace. At 37, she realized she needed to revive her journalism career, which seemed outdated. Her resume was stuck in the 1980s, back when typewriters were the norm. She felt unqualified for jobs requiring desktop publishing skills, which she lacked. Even simple technology like pocket calculators confused her, and she couldn't use the video timer. She knew she had to act fast to save her career.

Then, she entered a competition in a local newspaper and won a computer package for her family. They received a laptop for her husband and a personal computer for everyone. They quickly adapted to new terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing. The family started chatting online with people worldwide. The children stopped watching TV, and Georgina set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and modem for internet access. This setup allowed her to work from home and still take the kids to school. The children were already familiar with computers from school, but Georgina was hesitant, fearing she might lose her work by pressing the wrong button. However, she learned the basics and found it logical and easy.

Georgina started freelancing for a magazine, writing two articles a month, and felt she had the best of both worlds. The computer helped her become organized, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets helped track income and expenses, and pre-formatted invoices saved time. For a journalist, being online meant she could research stories, ask for information, and discuss working from home with others worldwide.

However, working from home has downsides, like isolation and household distractions. There are also arguments over computer use when the children are home. Despite this, more people are buying multimedia PCs for education, leisure, and work. In her neighborhood, a new type of home-based work is emerging, avoiding the daily commute.

A report on PC usage in UK homes describes the typical computer user as 38 years old and well-educated, with most owning a personal computer and many having a CD-ROM, laser printer, and modem. Georgina feels ahead of the curve and dreams of emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing her own magazine from home. The possibilities seem endless, with cyberspace as the limit.

The Tartan Museum

The new Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh stands out with its modern, cheese-wedge shaped buildings and a large yellow sandstone tower. It contrasts with the historic surroundings of the city. When it first appeared, people had mixed reactions to its design, ranging from praise to criticism. Now, as the museum is about to open, the focus is on its exhibitions.

The museum aims to tell Scotland's story through various historic objects, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and the Holyrood chapel silver. It provides a timeline to help visitors understand the displays without overwhelming them with national pride. The main question is whether the museum will be interesting enough for people to return.

Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, wants the museum to be enjoyable for everyone, not just experts. He avoids using imaginative recreations of the past, believing that the public deserves the truth. Instead, the museum relies on explanation panels, captions, and some multimedia to tell the stories of the objects.

Inside, the museum features a series of interconnected galleries with pale, wood-paneled walls and deep display cases. Natural light streams in through narrow windows, creating a pleasant atmosphere for visitors to explore.

The museum also includes a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to input from a Junior Board of 9- to 12-year-olds from across Scotland. Although the children wanted to ride through the displays, they got a hands-on center instead.

On the top floor, the Twentieth Century gallery is a temporary exhibition that will change every three years. It showcases objects chosen by Scottish people and other personalities that have impacted life in Scotland during the twentieth century. Items include an electric guitar, televisions, and Thermos flasks. While the idea is entertaining, it might seem less serious until the computerised bank of personal stories is activated.

Overall, Dr. Clarke believes that objects can vividly open windows to the past. The modern architecture of the museum works well from the inside, but its fit with the historic location is still debated.

The end of print media might take longer than expected. The word "transition" suggests a smooth change from one state to another. However, the shift from print newspapers to online versions is not smooth or certain. Many believe that print newspapers will eventually disappear because their sales are dropping, while visits to their websites are increasing. For example, newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen a decrease in print sales by 8% to 10% over the past year, but their online traffic is growing.

Despite this, the situation is not straightforward. The World Association of Newspapers reported a 1.1% increase in global newspaper circulation last year, mainly due to growth in Asia, even though sales in the West declined. News magazines, which are also expected to suffer in the digital age, actually saw a 5.4% increase. Similarly, while e-readers like Kindle are becoming more popular, the sales of physical books only dropped by 0.4%.

The idea that young people are abandoning newspapers is exaggerated. According to the National Readership Survey, nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read major national newspapers. Different countries in Europe show different trends. For instance, the UK has seen a 10.8% drop in newspaper sales, while Germany's decline is only 7%, and France's is 3.1%.

The assumption that online advertising would support digital newspapers is proving false, as digital ad revenues are decreasing. In response, 360 US newspapers have introduced paywalls. Interestingly, offering a combination of print and digital subscriptions seems to attract more paying readers. Print remains important for selling online subscriptions and generates significantly more advertising revenue than online ads.

Maintaining both print and online editions is challenging and costly for newspaper companies. However, print still plays a crucial role in maintaining a newspaper's brand visibility, which is harder to achieve online.

**Photographing People**

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A picture with a person in it is usually more engaging than one without. However, photographing people well is challenging. Besides technical and artistic aspects, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, the camera can make people act unnaturally.

**A. Grouping People**

Avoid straight lines in group photos. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances, or on different levels. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so all faces are visible, or take the photo from a higher angle.

**B. Posing for Pictures**

People often act unnaturally in front of a camera. They might become stiff and awkward. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**

Don't pretend you're not taking a picture when you clearly are, as this can create tension. Most people will agree to be photographed, even if they protest at first, and might feel flattered. However, they may become self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. A photo can be ruined if the subject looks aimlessly away, making the interest lie elsewhere.

**D. Eye Contact**

A photo has more impact if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, but they don't have to smile. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny or unexpected to get a genuine reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**

Instead of direct eye contact, the subject can focus on something within the picture. This might be easier for them, and the viewer can follow their gaze. Candid shots are fascinating, and the subject's expression is crucial.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**

Expressions and gestures reveal a lot about the subject. A laughing child can make the viewer smile, while a sad expression can evoke sympathy. Look for familiar expressions like shrugs, winks, or thumbs-up. They are a universal visual language.

**G. Situation Interest**

While close-up shots of faces are impactful, the background can add interest and information. When using a background, exclude irrelevant details or blur them. Ensure the subject isn't overshadowed by the background. A wide-angle lens can make the subject appear larger compared to the background.

**H. Interaction**

When people are interacting, there are great photo opportunities. Couples, mothers and babies, teachers and children, or teams working or playing sports make appealing shots. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a hand on the arm. Capture reactions with animated expressions or gestures.

**I. People and Places**

Many photos of people are taken on holidays to show the places they visit. To improve these pictures, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the whole scene. Ask your subjects to come close to the camera, forming a foreground without blocking the background. An elevated camera position can help. A good picture balances the subjects and the place, so both are equally interesting.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**

Decide why you want to take the picture. If it's to remember someone you met briefly, ask them to pose against a nice background. Family photos can be boring if they are just formal poses. Candid shots of events are more lively, and you're more likely to get natural photos when you know the subject well. A spontaneous picture can bring back memories better than a posed one.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is an artist who specializes in trompe-l'oeil, a style of painting that tricks the eye into seeing a three-dimensional scene. In this interview with Joanna Watt, Sarah shares her thoughts on her art and career.

Unlike many artists, Sarah doesn't sign her work unless asked. She believes the art itself is more important than the artist. Sarah is very modest and almost suggests that her paintings create themselves. This humility makes her a challenging interview subject. She admits, "I just don't like to talk about myself," and is uncomfortable being photographed.

However, once she relaxes, the interview becomes engaging and funny. Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing at art school, earned a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But illustration didn't fulfill her, so she joined a decorator named Jim Smart, who introduced her to trompe-l'oeil. This experience focused her interest, and she eventually started her own business.

Sarah's keen observation skills and attention to detail, developed through illustration, are crucial for her trompe-l'oeil work. She believes that trompe-l'oeil can't be taught; it's about observing life. She insists she's still learning and says, "The moment you think you've mastered something, you might as well stop."

Sarah is honest about her limitations, like her struggle to paint bread, which she says looks like "grey concrete." She also doubts her math skills, recalling a time she was overwhelmed by calculations for a chapel ceiling project. This self-doubt leads her to speak about her work as if someone else did it.

Despite her modesty, Sarah's work stands out. She has completed many significant projects for both companies and private clients. Her art often draws inspiration from architecture, like a dining room designed to look like a Venetian palace or a painting that creates the illusion of extra rooms.

Sarah knows that trompe-l'oeil must first trick the viewer and then engage their imagination. She believes the art should be personal to the client, and she enjoys collaborating with them to develop ideas. Many clients become friends because she spends so much time with them during projects.

Sarah appreciates her clients, especially those who give her creative freedom. They, in turn, are pleased with her work, keeping her busy despite her modesty. She repeats, "I really don't like to talk about myself," preferring her work to speak quietly. But her art is anything but boring, and it deserves more recognition.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

**A** The way we are evaluated at work is changing. It's not just about how smart we are or our training, but also how well we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging people is important for deciding who gets hired or promoted. It helps identify who might excel and who might not. These skills are crucial for future job opportunities. Unlike what we learned in school, doing well in exams doesn't matter much here. This new standard assumes we all have enough intelligence and technical skills. Instead, it focuses on social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness. These are known as emotional intelligence.

**B** In today's world, job security is uncertain, and the idea of a 'job' is changing to 'portable skills'. Personal qualities are becoming more important at work. These have been called 'character', 'personality', or 'soft skills' in the past, but now we understand them better as 'emotional intelligence'. This means being able to understand and manage our own and others' emotions, and using emotions to guide our actions. At work, it includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Emotional intelligence isn't just about being nice. Sometimes it means being honest, even if it's uncomfortable. It also doesn't mean expressing all feelings freely. Instead, it involves managing emotions so they help people work well together towards a common goal.

**C** More businesses are realizing that emotional intelligence is important for management. The more complex the job, the more these skills matter. A lack of emotional intelligence can limit how well someone uses their technical skills or intelligence. While some people succeed despite lacking emotional intelligence, as work becomes more complex and team-oriented, companies that foster these skills have an advantage. In today's workplace, which values teamwork and customer focus, emotional intelligence is essential for success everywhere.

**D** Unlike IQ, which doesn't change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life experiences. Studies show that people generally get better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and understanding others as they age. This growth in emotional intelligence is often called maturity. We can learn and improve these skills, which is important in a time when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence isn't a magic solution for struggling companies, but ignoring it can make everything else less effective.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important events, but social media has changed citizen photography even more. News often first appears on social networks, so some journalists use them to find images during fast-moving events. Unfortunately, some reporters have used user-generated content (UGC) without asking for permission. Official guidelines say that images from social media can be used without permission only in special cases or if there is a strong public interest, but people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, so UGC is clearly important for the future of the media. However, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media must make sure people are properly rewarded for their work and always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

**Acupuncture's Origins and Uses**  
Acupuncture is a practice that is 2,000 years old, originating from traditional Chinese medicine. This system also includes herbal remedies, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat various conditions, but it is most recognized in the West for its role in pain relief. Some general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly to help with pain.

**Understanding Acupuncture**  
Traditional Chinese medicine views health as a balance of energy in the mind, body, and spirit. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along paths known as meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an internal organ, and many smaller ones that distribute Qi to every cell. If the flow of Qi is disrupted, it can lead to weakness or illness. During an acupuncture session, the practitioner identifies imbalances in Qi by checking your pulse, examining your tongue, and observing your overall appearance. They will also ask about your medical history, current health, and lifestyle habits. Acupuncture involves inserting fine needles into the skin, sometimes using heat from herbs or applying pressure to stimulate Qi flow.

**Acupuncture Points**  
The points used in acupuncture are linked to meridians and may not be near the area of pain. Patients often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is manipulated, either by hand or with an electro-acupuncture machine. This sensation indicates that the needle has reached the Qi in a meridian. There are over 300 main acupuncture points, with many more used less frequently.

**Scientific Explanations**  
Even without accepting traditional Chinese principles, Western doctors acknowledge that acupuncture can relieve pain. Scientific explanations suggest that acupuncture might work by stimulating nerves to block pain signals or by releasing natural pain-relieving substances called endorphins.

**Types of Pain Treated**  
Acupuncture is often a last resort for people with chronic pain. It is commonly used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and post-surgery pain. Acupuncturists also claim to treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**Modern Use of Acupuncture**  
Although acupuncture has been practiced in China for over 2,000 years, its use as an alternative to anesthesia in surgery began in the 1950s. This development helped convince some Western doctors of its effectiveness. In China, acupuncture is used in various surgeries, sometimes with electrical stimulation or drugs. It is said to eliminate pain without the side effects of conventional anesthetics, allowing quicker recovery.

**Effectiveness of Acupuncture**  
Clinical trials for acupuncture are challenging to conduct, but those that exist show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists report similar success rates, acknowledging that it doesn't work for everyone. For chronic pain, noticeable relief usually occurs after six or seven sessions, with some improvement after two or three visits.

**Different Approaches to Pain**  
Western and Chinese medicine have different views on pain. Acupuncturists take a holistic approach, considering the whole person rather than just symptoms. They spend time diagnosing underlying weaknesses in Qi and consider external factors like weather conditions that might affect pain. This approach is different from that of most Western doctors.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**  
Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that only by using traditional Chinese methods can deep, lasting changes be achieved. When choosing an acupuncturist, ensure they are qualified and willing to refer you to a medical doctor if needed.

P.D. James, whose full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, is a famous crime writer known for her complex and imaginative stories. Despite her calm and authoritative appearance, she is actually quite shy. She admits that her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is somewhat based on herself, imagining how she might have been if she were a man. Like Dalgliesh, she prefers to work alone, especially when writing, needing privacy to focus.

James is modest about her success, even though she is one of Britain's most famous crime writers, with millions of readers worldwide. She admires the works of her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. Her reading preferences include books by women authors like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she also appreciates male authors like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh.

James's success came later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, "Cover Her Face," was published. Born in Oxford and raised in Cambridge, she met her husband, Connor Bantry White, there. Her life has had its challenges; her husband returned from World War II very ill, and she had to work hard to support him and their two daughters. Her husband's parents helped care for the children during these tough times.

While working full-time for the National Health Service and later at the Home Office, she used her organizational skills effectively. Her work in forensic science exposed her to the realities of crime, but it was the structure of writing crime novels that attracted her. She wanted to be a writer and saw detective stories as a way to learn the craft without drawing directly from her own life experiences.

James believes that writing detective stories is about creating order from chaos. Solving a crime in a story shows the value of life, even if the life in question is not particularly likable. She emphasizes that nobody truly enjoys violence.

The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst

The study of handwriting, known as graphology, is becoming more popular as a way to understand a person's character. In some countries, when you apply for a job, you might be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This sample can be as important as other factors in deciding if you are right for the job. Graphology is considered a real science in many places. Researchers claim it can help identify certain illnesses like heart disease and cancer, and it can show psychological states and emotional issues. More companies are using handwriting analysis for career guidance and during job interviews. Many large companies hire graphologists to examine the handwriting of candidates for important positions. However, most doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the value of graphology.

Patricia Marne, a graphologist with over 20 years of experience, believes that doctors should take graphology more seriously. She argues that handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also assess mental ability and potential, whether someone should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a devious or open character." According to Ms. Marne, graphology is useful in identifying possible criminal tendencies: "Criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which is usually poorly shaped. Many criminals come from difficult backgrounds and have stopped developing emotionally. This often appears in childish handwriting and in going over letters multiple times. I can tell if people are honest, manipulative, or reliable employees."

Ms. Marne explains that young male offenders often have very high ascenders in their writing, suggesting they live in a fantasy world and dream of success. Graphologists can detect if violence is likely, if the writer is under extreme pressure, or if there are psychopathic tendencies. Handwriting can even predict potential suicides. Heart and lung problems might also be visible, she says. "You can't diagnose from one sample unless the writing is clearly shaky or disturbed. But if it changes over time or becomes disjointed, or if there's a break in the signature that wasn't there before, it could mean something serious has happened." A major emotional upset can also temporarily change a signature, she adds.

Ms. Marne says handwriting can reveal other psychological traits. People whose letters form 'threads' instead of being clearly formed are said to be devious and clever. Those who write mainly in capitals are trying to hide their true selves. Light pressure indicates sensitivity and low energy. Originality in handwriting, or how much it differs from standard script, shows confidence and artistic ability. Disconnected writing is a sign of a loner. Very small signatures suggest inhibition and an inferiority complex; circles over the 'i' are a call for attention, and crossing the 't' heavily over the whole word shows intolerance and a patronizing attitude.

Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, along with empathy and intuition. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a proper science, and she thinks this will happen soon. "It's actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because you can learn a person's entire history, including all their emotional crises, without asking them questions they might answer incorrectly."

Despite these interesting claims, there is little solid evidence to support them. Some psychiatrists are very critical, saying that handwriting is simply a result of education, artistic ability, and the style of writing taught, and it has no other meaning.

Is your office working well? Fresh air and comfortable chairs are important for a happy and healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were as work environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies people's working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their findings:

**Office A: Advertising Agency**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very simple, with no central heating or mechanical ventilation. The windows open directly onto the street. Despite this, the small team seems happy. They adjust to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, similar to what they might do at home. This homely environment, free from strict rules, might be why they are content.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is mismatched and often leads to bad posture. Many chairs are old, not adjustable, and some are broken. However, the staff have varied tasks, like meeting clients and giving presentations, which helps prevent fatigue and boredom.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The staff enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. They find the office the right size—small enough to know what others are doing but big enough for personal work. The office feels both efficient and creative.

**Office B: News Service**

- **Building Health Consultant:** The office is comfortable and well-maintained, with good air quality, helped by a No Smoking policy.

- **Ergonomist:** The company has already used an ergonomist. Chairs, lighting, and computer equipment are good, but the layout could be better. The environment is impersonal, with grey walls.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls are bare except for planners and a maternity rights poster. Most staff have been there for over five years, and relationships are okay. The office could improve by rearranging desks for better information sharing and displaying project successes.

**Office C: Bank**

- **Building Health Consultant:** The office feels like a glass case, with a mix of smokers and non-smokers. Surprisingly, the air doesn't seem stale, even near smokers.

- **Ergonomist:** The office is standard and uninspiring. Desks are just adequate, and not all chairs meet requirements, but this is by choice. Computer setups are outdated.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** Staff support each other and have good technology. The office is busy, but the wood paneling and brown carpet make it look dull.

**Office D: Newspaper**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has many issues. The air-conditioning is poorly controlled, causing temperature changes. The space is cluttered and dusty, with dust falling from the roof.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is more suited to a workshop. Most chairs are not good for keyboard users, especially shorter people. Many chairs are old and lack adjustments.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office has old chairs, dirty carpets, and dust everywhere. It needs cleaning and better air conditioning, especially with many smokers. Few conversations were happening; everyone seemed stressed by deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.

Chewing Gum Culture

Chewing gum is popular and not limited to any social class. In the United States, people chew 12 million sticks of gum every day. This habit has turned into a big business. Each stick of gum has less than ten calories, but it is considered a food. This means it must meet the standards set by the American Food and Drug Administration. Most modern gum is made from synthetic materials, with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and improve the texture.

In the past, things were different. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, found mainly in Greece and Turkey. Greek women used it to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. In America, colonists learned from the Amero-Indians in New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, spruce gum was sold in the eastern United States, making it the first commercial chewing gum there.

Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to the growth of a whole industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla trees commercially have not worked. As the demand for gum increased, synthetic alternatives were developed. Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, called chicleros, have a tough and dangerous job. They travel long distances in nearly 100% humidity to collect sapodilla sap. They face many dangers, like poisonous snakes and insects, including the chicle fly, which lays eggs in their ears and nose. Despite these risks, chicleros climb trees with just a rope and an axe to collect the sap, which is then boiled into bricks at forest camps. Life at these camps is hard, with a basic diet of maize and local alcohol.

Even though their work is difficult, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. The U.S. used to import 7,000 tonnes of chicle from Central America each year, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to cut costs and meet demand.

Gum producers are also finding new ways to market their products. They claim gum helps you relax, boosts energy, and reduces tension. During both world wars, soldiers were given gum. The biggest claim is that gum reduces tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms and causes decay. Saliva neutralizes this acid and provides minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride. Gum makers say chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow. Research is ongoing for new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are used to mix the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still need natural ingredients. In the U.S., 137 square kilometers are used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the calm of an English country house with Indian cultural elements. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests into their home. The facilities are simple, with hot water provided in buckets, but this simplicity adds to the hotel's charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
The Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island is one of my favorite places. I discovered it by accident while climbing. After a long climb down from a glacier, I was surprised to find this hotel in such a beautiful, wild, and high location. It was amazing to arrive tired and find luxury, with someone playing Cole Porter on the piano.

**C. MAURITIUS - BEACHCOMBER PARADIS HOTEL**  
Located on a peninsula in the quiet southwest of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is quite isolated. The road to the hotel winds along the coast past empty beaches. The hotel is not small, and many people enjoy the free watersports, but you can easily find solitude along nine kilometers of private beach. In the evening, when everyone leaves, you can sit on the beach and feel far away from everything.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia is set in one of the Caribbean's most stunning locations. It is quiet and remote, standing 1,000 feet above sea level. The open rooms offer views between the twin peaks of the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The hotel has a colonial style, with mahogany and greenheart wood furniture and four-poster beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
This hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a perfect escape from Istanbul's noise. The islands are an hour away by boat and are idyllic, with no cars, only horse-drawn carriages, and beautiful 1920s wooden architecture. The Splendid Hotel is a landmark, painted white with red domes, resembling a hotel from the French Riviera. Though a bit worn, it retains its charm.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the heart of Champagne, is a beautiful 17th-century chateau. Surrounded by a moat with swans, the chateau was a family home until recently. It has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one even has a billiard table. There are special weekend rates that include breakfast, dinner, and complimentary champagne.

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel in Nairobi is a rare find in Africa—a comfortable hotel without excessive luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers resting from one safari and planning the next. Some guests decide to stay longer after seeing the gardens, rooms, and dining options. The hotel is on Nairobi Hill, away from the city's busy center, and is a great place to watch the African sunset with a drink and a hearty dinner.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Duke of Windsor was the first to sign the guest book at Hotel Splendido. Since then, many famous people have visited, including Lauren Bacall, Humphrey Bogart, Liz Taylor, and Richard Burton. Today, you might meet a wealthy businessperson. This former monastery-turned-hotel is still splendid, with simple yet delicious food, fine Persian rugs, and homemade pasta.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they meet certain standards. Christopher Middleton watched her inspect the Globe Hotel. Right from the start, things didn't go well. The receptionist was busy on the phone and didn't notice Sue, which is a common mistake. Sue expected better because the Globe Hotel has three red stars, meaning it's one of the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide she works for.

The entrance to the hotel was also disappointing. It was through an unmanned door with a buzzer and a long, empty corridor. When they finally reached the reception, the receptionist couldn't find Sue's booking, even though most rooms were empty that night. The room they offered her was stuffy and had a hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.

Sue has a reputation for being tough, but she insists she's fair. The next morning, after paying her bill, she revealed her identity to the hotel manager, Robin Greaves. He was worried, especially about a bad smell in the lounge. Sue suggested fixing the plumbing and not taking guests to that room until it's sorted.

Not everything was bad. Sue praised Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, a waitress, for their good work. The dinner was also good enough to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating. Greaves asked what they needed to do to get three rosettes, and Sue suggested not serving desserts that fall apart.

Sue's job is to point out problems that guests might not mention. Sometimes people complain about her feedback, but she has to be honest. She gives a verbal report and a written one because hotels pay to be in the guide. Despite the issues, Sue decided not to take away the Globe's red stars. However, another inspector will visit in two months to check if improvements have been made. Greaves said he looked forward to it, but he didn't seem very happy.

**Seven Up: Conquering the Seven Summits**

Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experiences of climbing the highest peak on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. His journey began later in life, and he recounts his climbs in the order he completed them.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave near the summit when Dougal started talking to someone who wasn't there, likely due to lack of oxygen. Doug also found himself talking to his feet, worried about frostbite. Despite these challenges, Doug felt confident with Dougal by his side and managed to reach the summit by finding a better climbing rhythm.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
Known as one of the most dangerous mountains, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier in April 1976. They carried their gear and food on their backs, attempting a new route. The low air pressure made it feel like they were at a higher altitude. After a tough climb, they reached the summit and descended successfully.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and Paul Braithwaite intended to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up on Kilimanjaro. They got lost in the jungle, struggling to find water, but eventually found a trail. They attempted a challenging route but switched to the Umbwe route to reach the summit.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, joined a group led by Phil Erscheler to climb Aconcagua via the Polish Glacier. Due to time constraints, they opted for the standard route. Despite strong winds, they reached the summit and returned to base camp, where Doug was encouraged to complete the Seven Summits.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
In November 1992, Doug's team traveled to Antarctica. Despite harsh conditions, they reached the summit in 8 hours. The experience was exhilarating, though visibility was poor due to a storm.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St. Petersburg. After acclimatizing, they used a cableway to reach 3,900m and then walked to a refuge at 4,200m. They faced strong winds and icy slopes but eventually reached the summit, only to discover another ridge to climb. They returned to the refuge as night fell.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
Doug's team aimed to establish a new route and interact with the local Dani people. Despite warnings of danger, they proceeded with their climb. On May 12, they reached the summit, marking Doug's completion of the Seven Summits, celebrated with a standing ovation. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**

Style affects every part of our lives today, from clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley shares the latest fashion trends for this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**

Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He suggests avoiding traditional, stiff dresses and the 'frilly' look, choosing simpler styles instead. Ingham has been designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to cut and make clothes. You don't have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs long, classic evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer something less daring, he offers a classic navy-blue summer suit, a staple in English women's wardrobes for much of the 20th century. Ingham's version looks fresh and modern.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**

Sally Quail, who once worked for an art dealer, has no formal training in jewelry. She started designing her own engagement ring when she couldn't find one she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Now, many famous actors and actresses seek out her work. Her style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, inspired by 18th-century jewelry. Recently, she started using diamonds. At 36, Quail says, "I reached that point in every woman's life when she wants a diamond, so I began working with them."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**

Lily Grimson entered the competitive fashion world four years ago with only a basic art and design course. Two of her handbag designs have been chosen for a major exhibition. Her bags, whether made from fine calfskin or heavy silk, are always noticed. They are handmade in the UK and combine elegance with careful craftsmanship, making them special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**

For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of some of the world's most famous people. He says, "Most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home." His unique approach ensures clients don't look like they just left a salon. However, this relaxed style is expensive, costing £250 for the first appointment, with a three-month waiting list. Peter has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, so people can style their hair at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**

Penny Pratt runs a small shop and is a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain. She also provides floral ideas to top restaurants. Despite having no formal training in floristry, she left her teaching job 10 years ago to try something new. Her simple yet modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. Pratt advises keeping flower arrangements simple and strong, with few leaves. For wedding bouquets, she says the key is to use flowers of the same species.

**Five-star luxury with modern technology**

The Merrion Hotel, a new five-star hotel in Dublin, has just opened. It took almost two years to transform four large 18th-century houses into this luxury hotel. This transformation allowed the hotel to include the latest technology for both staff and guests.

Peter MacCann, the General Manager, wants his staff to know guests by name. However, he uses the hotel's computer system to remember guests' preferences. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. MacCann is confident that the system will be worth the investment over time. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature, where staff can record any number of preferences.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. The Merrion has a high-tech system to manage this. Guests can adjust the temperature themselves within three degrees of the standard 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can set each room's temperature between 14°C and 25°C.

The technology in the rooms is especially appealing to business travelers, who are expected to make up 65% of the hotel's clientele. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has prepared for future technological advancements by installing extra cables. Televisions are rented, not bought, so they can be easily updated, and DVD recorders can be upgraded as needed.

Despite all this technology, MacCann ensures that guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, and welcoming. The hotel also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

The food at the Merrion must be excellent, as expected in luxury hotels. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He has a modern kitchen and better parking facilities, while the hotel offers a popular dining option without financial risk.

With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to succeed.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden, full of her favorite flowers like tulips and poppies, provides many of her painting subjects. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures, especially in the two long flower borders along the path. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well, and although Danny initially doubted some of her choices, he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint them.

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they grow, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, "I don't set the whole thing up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another, building the painting over time. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish." Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the process of flowers decaying fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up when left in water, becoming more interesting over time.

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers back then, thinking they looked artificial. She admired how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Today, her garden includes plants from distant lands, which feel at home there. She has a relaxed approach to gardening, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, she finds it hard to spend time gardening. She now has an extra gardener but believes that to stay connected to her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Many trees in the Brackham area were knocked down during the terrible storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. This change upset many of the town's more traditional residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, who leads the local police, would have been upset too. However, during the storm, Pelham was too sick to notice anything. He was a strong and healthy man, but he got very sick with bronchitis for the first time in his life. When he first felt a headache and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, tried to get him to see a doctor. Pelham thought the police needed him too much, so he ignored her and kept working. This made him forgetful and irritable, though he wouldn't admit it. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon, she took him to the pharmacy to get his antibiotics and then home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed. On Thursday morning, when Molly told him the walnut tree had fallen, Pelham couldn't really understand it. On Thursday evening, he weakly asked if the house was damaged, was relieved to hear it wasn't, and went back to sleep. It wasn't until Saturday, when the antibiotics started working and his fever went down, that he got up and realized the walnut tree was gone. This made a big difference to how the living room looked. The Pelhams' large house was in a big garden. It was expensive, but Pelham didn't regret buying it. The garden made it feel private. But now, the storm had changed things. Before, the view from the living room included the beautiful walnut tree. It didn't make the room dark because there was another window on the opposite wall, but it created interesting light patterns that hid the worn-out furniture they brought from their old house. With the tree gone, the room was very bright, and the shabby furniture was clearly visible. The view from the window was also unpleasant. The tall house next door, which the tree had hidden, was now visible, with its ugly purple bricks and outside pipes. It seemed to have many upstairs windows, all looking at the Pelhams' house. "Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham said hoarsely to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. "I've been telling you since we moved here.
