We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

Living in the Valley

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first realized the dangers in the surrounding hills that could threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall, and within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. On the nearby hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. Up there, the wind was very strong. In our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind; trees swayed, but the branches stayed firm. Yet, we knew we had reason to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient, but they didn't trouble us much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that worried us the most. It reminded us of what could have happened if the water from the hills had not been controlled by a series of dams many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These grey clouds spread over the valleys, twisting and turning, warning us of what was to come. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder every day. The snow was gradually washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but high up in the hills, the reservoir was filling and was close to danger level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Up in the hills, it was like Niagara Falls, as water surged over the edge of the dam and poured into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the waters rushed down to its lower parts. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream was wild under the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it so close to our home, fiercely hitting its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Fortunately, our hopes were answered as the dam held, and the waters began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river often flooded the nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine; the large amount of water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with only occasional overflows. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the large clouds over the valley and be amazed by the river's power. Thanks to this, we feel our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

Mark Adams reflects on his decade-long career as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing about films for this newspaper was his first serious job. Before that, he had done some reviews for novels, films, and radio. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, through radio and television work. Tom hired him, but he wasn't mainly a journalist, or he might have been more selective with his team. Initially, Tom wanted a group of critics to cover art forms that didn't need specialized knowledge, like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They planned to have weekly lunches to choose what to review, with guests to keep things friendly. It felt like a dream to Mark, being part of a new newspaper in a competitive market. He even doubted it was real, thinking maybe a millionaire was just pretending to employ him. The first time he saw someone reading his review on the London Underground, he felt awkward. 

Tom's idea for a team of critics didn't work out. It was a good plan, but they never met as intended, so they communicated by phone. The public preferred critics to focus on one area, so Mark chose film. Thanks to Tom's initial push, Mark now writes a detailed weekly piece, usually on one film. This suits him well, as he wouldn't enjoy the typical critic's job of reviewing every film. That would quickly bore him, making him dread watching films. The space he has allows him to expand his arguments or get creative during slow weeks. 

Mark wonders about his role in the public eye. He thinks people choose films based on stars, publicity, or directors, and rarely change their minds because of a review. So, if a review isn't a guide for consumers, what is it? He doesn't feel he needs to be 'right' about a movie or decide how many 'great' or 'bad' films there should be each year. His job is to present an argument, not to be a judge, and he prefers it that way.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because she thinks it's fun. A teenager who loves endurance sports is looking for a training partner. Ideally, this person should be a sports enthusiast, preferably female, and interested in becoming an Olympic champion. The partner should enjoy long-distance running (regular 15 km sessions), swimming in cold rivers during winter, and cycling long distances (100 km rides). They must be able to do all three activities without resting.

The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. It attracts large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes swimming 1500 meters, cycling 40 kilometers, and running 10 kilometers without stopping. It might be exciting to watch, but why do triathletes push their bodies so hard? And why would a talented 17-year-old with excellent grades choose this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears hasn't yet learned the usual phrases athletes use about personal satisfaction and mental challenges. She says, "You swim 1500 meters, then get out of the water and jump on your bike while still wet. Of course, you get cold. After cycling 40 kilometers, you have to run 10 kilometers, which feels long when you're tired. But it's great fun and worth it in the end."

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14 and won the junior section, although she was the only junior competing. Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Despite having the second-fastest swim and the fastest run, she didn't place well. She followed someone and ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. She cried during the run but didn't give up and is determined not to.

Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. He says, "I tested her fitness, and she worked so hard on the running machine that it threw her off into a wall. She gave it everything, but unlike most people who stop when they can't go further, she kept going."

Melanie was the top junior at this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. She was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running but slower in cycling. That's why she's working hard on it. She's trying to convince her parents, who are paying for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships, to buy her a £2,000 bike. This would help her compete in national 25 km and 100 km races.

However, her intense training has made her a bit of a loner. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I keep in touch with the other girls on the team by phone and letters." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our race times."

Where will her focus lead her? Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," which involves swimming 750 meters, cycling 20 kilometers, and running 5 kilometers. She wants to try even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. It's surprising, isn't it?

Amanda Roy discusses her love for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It's a world full of passion and excitement. But if you don't truly love an item, don't collect it. 

Since ancient times, people have felt the urge to collect. Early humans collected pebbles for their beauty and wore them as necklaces. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for their shapes and colors. I've been a collector all my life, gathering everything from tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. At six, I went to a school in a remote, windy part of England. My parents would take me to a local museum filled with fascinating objects collected by others.

Many people share my interest in collecting. The reasons vary, but some find it gives them a sense of control. For me, it's simply enjoyable. A famous collector, the Duc de Berry in France, had a 'room of wonders' with items like coconut shell cups and Oriental china. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You don't need to be wealthy to collect. I've collected tulip bulbs and china cups with great determination. I once convinced another tulip collector to give me a bulb, only for it to be stolen later.

I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching across the USA for different designs. Sadly, this collection was destroyed in a house fire. The next day, I stood in the ruins, unsure if I was more upset about the furniture or the dolls. 

I'm fascinated by how collections change hands. A silver spoon once owned by a king or poet gains value. As items become popular among collectors, their prices rise. Toys from the 1950s are now valuable investments, especially if you kept the original boxes. Unfortunately, I threw mine away, along with the toys.

**My Line of Work: Four People Talk About Their Jobs**

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**

I organize temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. My job includes planning, designing, and promoting these exhibitions. First, I learn about the exhibition topic and talk to experts to decide on the main themes and goals. I choose which objects and pictures to display. It's important that visitors understand the exhibition, so I plan interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also work with engineers and electricians to ensure everything is safe. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform the public.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**

I start my day at 7:30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I prepare new maps and documents for students to learn the routes needed for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are learning how to plan the best routes, using the correct one-way streets and turns. I help when there's a disagreement, like if a right turn is possible at a junction. As the test approaches, I challenge students by giving them a route and then telling them it's blocked, so they have to find another way. This helps them think critically.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**

I live by the coast and mostly work from home. My job involves answering phone calls, creating educational materials, and organizing training courses. Sometimes, I visit our main office, but I usually work on the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers, and I run courses for coastal managers. I take them out to sea to help them understand marine life better, which often changes their perspective. I love my job because conservation is my passion, but working for a charity means I always need more funding, which can be challenging.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**

My job is quite varied. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and manage the stock of about 300 books we publish. We maintain high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which need careful replies. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with a passionate team, which makes the job enjoyable. However, like many jobs, there's too much paperwork, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, the four of us spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have expanded it, but they've done it very tastefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. "How about this?" he asked one evening and read the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, though my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school because Dekko Deacon sounds nice. He and Strafe went to school together, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We're all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it's quite a coincidence. "How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling as she welcomed us again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive because she's usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium." These are the names of the rooms reserved for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of details like that, while her husband handles redecoration and repairs. "Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said, coming into the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh again. Arthur led us to the rooms, carrying as much of our luggage as he could and then coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not too long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full. From where we sat by the window, we could see some people walking on the lawns and others taking the path down to the seashore. In the morning, we'd do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then return in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, this routine had developed. Since we first came here, we all fell in love with the beautiful landscape.

Title: Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experience as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. This is her second year working there, where she cooks and cleans for visitors staying in chalets, which are typical wooden houses in the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She sees being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a couple of years before starting a more permanent career. 'It's a great way to meet successful people,' she says.

Sarah doesn't live at the chalet. She starts her day at 7 a.m., walking about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing a full breakfast for the guests, including porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she finds the hardest part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski and enjoys being on the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

In the evening, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower but avoids napping, as it makes her too tired. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., with coffee by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and loads the dishwasher, preferring to leave the kitchen tidy for the next morning. Sometimes she chats with the guests, while other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make the week enjoyable, but sometimes things don't go as well,' she notes.

Sarah meets her friends at her own chalet and they go out around 11 p.m., visiting places like Bananas, G Jay's, and Dick's T-Bar. However, she doesn't stay out too late on Saturdays because Sunday is her busiest day. 'It's a tough day,' she says, 'and you don't want to cook breakfast with a headache.' On Sundays, she starts work earlier, serving breakfast by 7 a.m. for departing guests. Once they leave, she cleans the chalet thoroughly, stripping beds and getting everything ready. If she hasn't done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By 3 p.m., after cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests arriving around 4:30 p.m. She helps them with any questions and takes them to the ski shop if needed. After that, it's time for dinner again, and sometimes a drink, but often she's too tired and opts for an early night.

Miss Rita Cohen, a small, pale-skinned girl, visited Seymour's factory one day. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was six years older. Rita was dressed in overalls and big shoes, with a bushy head of hair around her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 

A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions over the phone or giving a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class, who had visited the factory years ago. Marie's class came from their rural school 50 kilometers away to see how gloves were made, especially Marie's favorite part, the laying-off table. This is where the men shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. As a child, Marie was fascinated by them and called them the 'pancake hands'.

Rita asked Seymour, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" He replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She kept taking notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained, "They come to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they make it into the right kind of leather for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" Rita said, "Not yet." Seymour offered, "You should visit a tannery if you're going to write about leather. I can arrange that for you. They're primitive places. Technology has improved things, but it's not that different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. Tanning is said to be the oldest industry, with remains found from 6,000 years ago in Turkey, I believe. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. It's an interesting subject once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; you should talk to him. He can talk about gloves for two days straight. That's typical: people in the glove trade love everything about it. Have you ever seen anything being manufactured, Miss Cohen?" Rita replied, "I can't say I have." Seymour laughed when she said she had only seen her mother make a cake as a child. 

Rita's eagerness to learn reminded Seymour of his daughter Marie, who was much taller and fairer than Rita. Marie would come home from school full of what she'd learned, remembering everything and writing it down in her notebook. Seymour decided, "I'll show you the whole process. We'll make you a pair of gloves, and you'll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

Text: 'Is it really a dream job? Chris Arnot talks to four people with jobs that seem perfect to find out if they really are. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. However, there's one small issue - she hates flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm down,' she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so cramped with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. Her tasks include organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for the job. She met a pop group's manager by chance, which led to a job offer. She took secretarial classes in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he preferred being a caddy because he loves golf. But there were downsides. Caddies get a small fixed fee plus a percentage of the winnings. Average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, and much of that goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first worked for golfer Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the course.' His accounting skills were noticed by European Tour Productions, who made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies' scorecards. These results are used by TV commentators, golf magazines, and the golfers themselves. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is trying food at top restaurants. What does he think about restaurants with high prices? 'For those who can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave.' His cooking skills led to a food column offer from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. At the time, Martin was a creative director at an advertising agency, and the column was a good extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a career.' He still cooks at home and tries to keep fit by cycling a few miles to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's authors. 'Before that, I loved words and enjoyed using them, but I mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. I used to be a farmer and knew about the problem of foxes killing chickens. So I wrote a story with a twist called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's book.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That's what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing out the morning's notes - all with one finger on an old typewriter instead of a laptop. I get between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that's the part of being a writer I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust, like golden mountains, reaching down to the blue lake. One afternoon, with nothing else to do, Michael and his friends climbed a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof, landing on the sawdust and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to get them to jump too. They looked down, nervous and pale, but one by one, they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the hot sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. Then one of them said, "Let's go back up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they all went back up and started jumping off again, determined and a bit desperate, until only Michael was left on the roof. The others were below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the edge, licking his lips nervously, wondering why the jump seemed longer this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried counting to ten and jumping, but it didn't work. He tried taking a deep breath and closing his eyes. The others started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted. When he didn't move, they began to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour as the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set beyond the lake. His clothes were wet from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. The yard was silent; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump earlier. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to get home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little gray in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled sternness, but Michael, with his dark, unhappy face, barely heard her. He was still thinking about the grinning faces and the laughter from earlier.

Careers Advice

Are you unhappy with your current job but unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change careers are turning to career advisers for guidance. The process usually involves writing a brief history of yourself and taking several tests called 'psychometrics'. These tests help identify your strengths and suggest possible career paths, along with any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a large organization that provides career advice. Taking their test felt like being back in school, with a group of about ten people answering questions under time pressure. It was important to remember that the test wasn't about passing or failing. The psychometrics included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the test, I had a long conversation with an adviser who used the test results to create a report with observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of the conclusions, although I was surprised to learn I didn't do well in scientific, technical, and practical areas. It was comforting to know I made the right choice in pursuing journalism.

Changing your career doesn't always mean a complete change of direction. For example, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company after five years. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to step back and review my career,' says Donna. Some results were unexpected. 'I didn't realize I had a talent for design, but I had to consider the cost of retraining against my financial responsibilities,' she explains. Other options included taking a year off to work in the Far East. 'I decided to use my existing skills and move into a field better suited to me than insurance. I'm now a Public Relations officer. Career Analysts helped me see clearly what I wanted to do. I've recommended them to several friends who are also happy with the service.'

Some people feel they wouldn't have made changes without help. Juliet Greene, 26, visited Career Counselling Services and made life-changing decisions. 'After six years at a major bank, I found my job boring and needed a new challenge. I didn't know what I wanted, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser, and the third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget what you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course this year. The advice was worth the fee. I'm much happier and more positive now.'

However, career advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I was at a point in my career where I didn't know what to do next. I hoped a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary cut or a lot of retraining. I didn't learn anything new about myself,' she says. 'You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that a friend could have given me similar advice.'

Title: A New Experience at the Dentist's

When you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch for patients. Jerome explains that many people only visit the dentist when they are in pain because they are scared. To change this, he has created a welcoming environment. He doesn't wear a white coat because it reminds people of pain. Jerome believes dental visits should be relaxing and even enjoyable.

This idea is surprising because most people think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome says that if patients are relaxed and entertained, they will forget their past bad experiences. One of his new techniques is using virtual-reality headsets. His practice was the first in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater wildlife while Jerome examines their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view inside their mouth, which most patients find interesting.

The dental office also smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today, it smells like oranges. Jerome believes that smell is important because the typical dental smell can make people anxious. I found the pleasant smell in the office very nice.

Although Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, he takes his work seriously. Relaxation is important, but the quality of treatment is the top priority. For example, he uses a tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a bit strange at first, but it is not painful if you are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. He discovered that making things easier for patients also makes it easier for dentists. He believes this patient-focused approach is the beginning of a change towards less formal dentistry in Britain.

As a patient arrives, Jerome offers him a cup of tea and asks what video he would like to watch. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The dental office feels more like a fancy beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a huge global business worth millions. During Easter, people in Britain spend over £230 million on chocolate, with eight percent of all chocolate sales happening at this time. Only at Christmas do people consume more chocolate. 

The large-scale production of chocolate began in the 19th century, but the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is an evergreen, tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans due to a spelling mistake from the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish preferred it with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread across Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate.

Until the 19th century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847 when Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, combined cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. A Swiss company later added milk solids, creating milk chocolate.

At the start of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to add some French charm. But Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, originally called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular thanks to clever advertising linking it to the healthy qualities of English countryside milk. 

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain is about four bars per week. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. The latest trend is the 'extended line,' where chocolate bars become ice creams, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to those tired of regular snacks.

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices from the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. Perhaps you could think of them as you enjoy your next chocolate bar.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke, at 83, has mastered the art of creating unique objects from shells. Although he is interested in trying new crafts like paper-making and feather-work, he is currently focused on his shell art, which he has been perfecting for the past ten years. As he shows me around his apartment, he worries about being boring, but his enthusiasm and the beauty of his work are captivating.

Cooke points out a pair of shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace. He mentions that he doesn't mind if they don't sell because he has grown fond of them. Initially, he didn't plan to sell his work, but friends encouraged him to hold an exhibition. This led to a successful show in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition just opened, featuring 86 pieces with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Some pieces are priced as high as £2,000.

Cooke is open about the prices, explaining that his work is unique and that one day, when he stops creating, his pieces will become even more valuable. He wishes he had started this craft earlier in life, as he feels physically limited now compared to when he began. Despite this, his work is far superior to the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. He creates intricate designs, like boxes covered in tiny shells and realistic flower baskets.

Cooke has developed his own techniques, using materials he finds, such as cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases and a special glue from a sail-maker. He washes the shells with washing-up liquid. His creative process seems effortless, but the detailed and symmetrical results show great skill.

His search for beautiful, especially small, shells has taken him to beaches in France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. Cooke only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of harming the environment. He argues that many shells are destroyed by people walking on them or by the sea itself. He believes that collecting empty shells is harmless and that his art enhances their natural beauty.

The Schoolgirl Model

When 15-year-old Kira Langer isn't traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, she's probably studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

The receptionist at the agency told me, "Kira will be a little late." I said, "Oh, fine, no problem." I was trying to ignore the negative things I had read about models, like being difficult, vain, and unintelligent. Now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided going to the hairdresser was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions.

But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she came with her mother. Kira wasn't wearing expensive designer clothes, just a simple black dress and trainers. She didn't seem selfish at all; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mom, very proud of her successful daughter.

Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense since it was unexpected. Her older sister was the one who thought she should enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should go in for it," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When she got the call saying she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she did great. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work.

Kira now finds it challenging to balance her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, some unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I have too high an opinion of myself." This must be hard for Kira, as she seems very humble. But she says, "They assume that because I've suddenly become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident—not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she has a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they even finish their school exams. As I finish the interview with the girl who seems to have it all, I ask what she would like to do if she didn't have the beauty that seems certain to take her to the top of the profession. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

Father and Son Start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold of Canada to the warmth of Africa in search of valuable metals. Terence, an explorer, and his son Chris, a mineral expert, believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we find a lot of gold; we just need to dig a few more meters to reach where it is concentrated."

The Maddens have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best area to explore. After clearing the land and finding small pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission to dig, taking earth samples, and cleaning up old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, it seems unlikely, but we have some people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread, the idea of finding gold excited both locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are cautiously hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "It would bring more people here if they are right, but if they find gold, I hope millions don't come and damage the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, the wonder of finding hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University, teaching and researching marine geochemistry, which is the study of chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she dives three kilometers deep into the ocean in a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is so tight that she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they can't stand or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button, which releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. However, no one has tested this yet, and it might not be a pleasant experience.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle on a ship's deck with an instructor, who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, she has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys releasing black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers," another name for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius. The only time Rachel felt scared was during a dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest parts of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere under all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't take any more stress. My mind couldn't handle any more foreign schedules, currencies, or languages. "Never again," I said, as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could spend a whole month traveling anywhere I wanted in Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've learned to sleep in a train corridor, the rhythm rocking you into a deep sleep. Carrying all your belongings in a backpack makes you have a very simple approach to travel, and encourages incredible wastefulness, like burning socks that have become too smelly, and getting rid of books when finished. On the other hand, this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail, where common sense and reasoning can be thrown out of the window along with the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to achieve this carefree attitude is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that lets young people travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be pretty special. On that first trip, my friends and I didn't realize the possibilities of this type of train ticket at first, thinking it was just a cheap way to get to and from our chosen campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel was too tempting, for there was always just one more country over the border, always a little bit further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was a first holiday without parents, as it was for most other Inter-Railers, and in organizing our own schedule, we left out everything except the most immediately available sights. This was the chance to escape the guided tour, an opportunity to do something different. I took great pride in the fact that, in many places, all I could be bothered to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by, and to have a good time doing so. In this, we were no different from most of the other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food and water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. It is as if the city you arrive in never actually existed until the train pulls into the station and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and seeing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind. Everybody knows what is there, but it is meaningless until you see it yourself. This is what makes other people's holiday photos so boring. While the train trip won't allow you to discover anything new in the world sense, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best opportunity to recognize this ... though in our case it didn't happen immediately.

Arriving at an airport in another country only to find out your baggage is missing is very frustrating. At best, you might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. At worst, you could be in a completely different climate, far from home, with clothes that are not suitable. Airlines don't often say how many bags they lose, but frequent travelers know that losing luggage happens sometimes. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and no airline can promise that your checked luggage will always be on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.

Here's how the system works: Airlines ask passengers to check in early to give enough time for baggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between flights, and these are also set to allow for baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can delay flights, which can cause problems with the baggage system. Human errors or accidents, like a torn-off destination label, can also happen. These issues are more common at large transfer airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport managed over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when you can and check in early. If you must change planes or if it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline for the whole trip. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Include your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer who specializes in kingfishers, which are beautiful blue-green birds that live near streams and rivers and eat fish. These birds are often seen in areas where old trees hang over the water, creating a mix of soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher moves quickly and directly through this scene, like a flash of light, leaving a lasting impression despite its small size.

Charlie developed a love for kingfishers when he was young. He finds it hard to explain exactly why he is so drawn to them, but they are indeed fascinating creatures. In Greek mythology, the kingfisher is linked to a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story suggests that the kingfisher's colors come from flying so high that its top side turned blue like the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. Scientifically, kingfishers don't have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, the structure of their feathers reflects light in a way that makes them look blue or green, depending on the light.

Many wildlife photographers are passionate about kingfishers because of their vibrant colors and the fact that, although they are shy, they can be observed from a hidden spot. Charlie's first attempt at watching kingfishers involved using an old blanket as a hideout. The bird came very close, but it took him four years to capture a good photograph. During this time, he became very focused on the European kingfisher, which is the only one of its kind that breeds in Europe. His dedication was noticed, and at 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He later worked as an assistant editor and eventually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Charlie dreams of making the perfect kingfisher film, with no narration, just stunning images. He is drawn to the simple beauty of the bird, especially the colors of its wings. Even after spending so much time with kingfishers, they still fascinate him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but he knows that his connection with the kingfisher goes beyond what his work can show.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected start in conducting when she asked to watch Claudio Abbado's rehearsals in Vienna and ended up filling in for an absent assistant. This led to more opportunities, including helping with another opera the next season. Manson, who is American, works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in Europe, supported by the British Arts Council, and has worked with Abbado on several projects since her first experience. She says she was never nervous about conducting in front of an orchestra.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of conducting is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after failing in two others. He feels the timing was perfect, as earlier success might have led to his career fading away. The competition opened doors for him, including working as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he worries about being labeled as a "competition conductor." He hopes that in three years, his name won't be tied to the competition. Fortunately, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra have invited him back, which is crucial for his career.

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods in opera. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business sector until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. A turning point was taking lessons with Sian Edwards, who was similar in size to her, unlike her previous teachers. Kani appreciates the complexity of opera, including dealing with singers' personalities and the many arguments that arise.

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, found conducting unexpectedly fascinating. He started as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's "Agrippina" from the piano at a festival, which was easier than he expected. He knew the music well and aimed to achieve the performance he envisioned. His musical skills have earned him respect, and he is learning from all his experiences. Vignoles is open to trying new things to discover what he enjoys most.

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
Wayne Marshall, now 32, was noticed by conductor Simon Rattle in 1986, which led to his first conducting job in London on short notice. It was challenging, especially dealing with musicians who were too relaxed. He was firm with them, always giving a clear beat to get the best results. Marshall believes many musicians don't need much guidance from a conductor, but he is not afraid to express his needs. Although he hasn't formally studied conducting, he is determined and knows what he likes. People have been supportive of him in his journey.

**Variations on a Theme**

If you're planning to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options. We asked five families to try out some of the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**

Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There’s a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the kids wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park lacks a bit of atmosphere, and the scenery could be better. But the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and very focused on security.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He was thrilled with the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings at his height! The older kids enjoyed the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is perfect, and the staff are very friendly. There’s something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**

After seven hours, we felt there was still a lot to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you’ll get wet, but you don’t. For younger children, Toy Land is great fun. The kids looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line isn’t too boring. It’s very clean, and the staff are great. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**

We arrived at one o’clock and were disappointed that the park was only open until 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides aren’t too scary. I’m usually scared, but even I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then becomes really fun. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and then it was over quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but if you’re brave, it looked exciting. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit tame, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**

The park advertises that there is 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we felt that was true. Europe’s tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, although Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for a few of them but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome wasn’t always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

Running a business in the countryside: Five women share their experiences of starting a business in rural areas.

A. CHRISTINE HOGAN runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly income of over £200,000 and employs four full-time staff. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Having worked with computers before marriage, her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. She was careful with finances, always informing the bank manager if she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, and local clients usually pick up their work.

B. MAGGY SASANOW designs greeting cards from home and enjoys being independent. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but after marrying and moving to the countryside, she started her own business. She creates 50 different greeting cards, selling them to museums. She works in a large room upstairs. A downside of working from home is the constant household chores, like mowing the lawn. Her business grows through word of mouth, without advertising. People send work from London because she is cheaper than other artists. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, she finds more advantages than disadvantages in her work.

C. DELIA TURNER has a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started eight years ago when the business was growing, and her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. She used to manage six full-time workers but had to let them go due to economic decline, which was hard because jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and hires women who work from their homes. She must be ready to lower prices when needed and explore new opportunities.

D. TESSA STRICKLAND manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons, as London was expensive, and because she loves the countryside. She enjoys flexible working hours. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, requiring her to take calls at odd hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to stop working. She publishes children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt lonely as all her professional experience was in London.

E. MEG RIVERS runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop with a yearly income of £250,000, employing six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, interested in health, making fruit cakes with quality ingredients. As demand grew from friends and relatives, she began sending cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made, employing a baker, assistant, and professional cake decorator. She no longer cooks, focusing on the business side. Her biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as they started with limited funds.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is unique because not only are the sons talented musicians and composers, but their father, John, also makes musical instruments. When John and Hetty Watkins, both schoolteachers from South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son Paul, they found it too expensive to buy one. John decided to try making one himself. He attended evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, he successfully made his first cello for Paul. Paul used this cello until recently, and John has since become a full-time craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. Selling a violin to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo was a highlight for him.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano but soon became interested in the cello. His parents initially wanted him to play the violin to join his father's chamber music group, but Paul was more inspired by the cellist in the group. He began taking cello lessons and excelled. Huw, on the other hand, was not interested in the violin but found his passion in piano and composing. He appreciated having Paul as a role model.

Paul achieved great success with the cello his father made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. He played his father's cello until he recently started using a Francesco Rugeri cello, which is over 300 years old, on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul acknowledges that his father's cello will improve with age, but for now, the Rugeri has a better sound for large concert halls.

Paul will soon perform Elgar's Cello Concerto on television, but he won't be able to watch it because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival the same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall that evening. Their parents, John and Hetty, will have to manage their time carefully to follow both sons' musical careers in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: THE NATIONAL TRUST**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills because they often work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders.

Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his family's farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the warden job on the Lleyn Peninsula, but Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the position, even though he didn't have formal training. He finds it helpful that he still farms with his parents, which allows him to understand farmers' issues and communicate with them effectively.

His farming background also helps him handle the physical tasks of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and realizes now that farming has changed the countryside. He believes it's not the farmers' fault, as they were following government advice.

When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. Now, they are communicating better and understanding each other's perspectives. Gareth believes they are close to working together effectively.

Conservation is a key part of Gareth's work, along with managing public access to Trust land, planting and maintaining trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. He ensures that tasks are completed efficiently and economically. Gareth enjoys seeing projects finished, although he spends a lot of time on paperwork.

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys interacting with the public, though he finds some people's attitudes frustrating. He dislikes when people act entitled to the land. Despite this, he loves his work and suggests that if you have common sense and enjoy outdoor jobs, you might consider becoming a warden. However, don't expect a job to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula anytime soon!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is leading the team as they prepare for next month's World Championships. Her days are busy: she teaches at a local school and then trains in a supermarket car park. When asked if people stare, she says she's too focused on her training to notice much, though she might see cars slowing down.

Kendra is dedicated to being in top shape for the Championships. This will be her fourth time competing, and it's set to be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. She feels excited about having home support, which she believes is important for improving netball's reputation in England. However, playing at home also means more pressure, as fans will expect a strong start.

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra notes that England has always beaten Barbados, but they are still a skilled team. England is currently ranked fourth in the world, and Kendra acknowledges that the Championships will be challenging. Unlike a series where you can lose a game and still win overall, the Championships offer only one chance to succeed.

Over her 15-year career, netball has become faster and more competitive. Players train hard to win, but Kendra says they become friendlier once the game ends. The sport now uses more scientific methods for fitness testing. Kendra believes it's crucial to think and train like world-class athletes. As captain, she aims to have a strong mindset and lead by example, supporting and encouraging her team.

Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned from the start. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. While she may coach young players in the future, her focus is now on this final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might even shed a tear.

SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS

How should you support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know the best way to nurture their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult to manage. While most schools can handle children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools, which are relatively new. These schools create a supportive environment for talented children aged seven to eighteen to fully develop their skills with the help of professional musicians. Students at these schools spend a significant part of their day on music activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and secondary instruments), playing in orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and learning music theory. They also practice for several hours daily in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages. However, students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school full-time, which means they spend their formative years with peers who have similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; boarding fees range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question the wisdom of admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their main goal is to develop 'well-rounded and balanced individuals.'

There is a risk that separating musically gifted children from an early age can cause stress. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and offer support when needed. While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some are concerned about the limited academic program, which is secondary to music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, feeling frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide for themselves before considering a specialist education. Those who are also academically gifted might thrive in a less specialized environment, such as a school with an excellent music department or by combining regular schooling with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers and opportunities for orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her house is surrounded by a large garden, which provides many of her painting subjects. The garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread seeds everywhere. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures, thanks to the previous owners who loved gardening. They left behind plants that Susan liked, and she also inherited their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well, and although Danny sometimes doubted her choices, he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint them.

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants in their natural setting, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, "I don't set everything up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another, building the painting over time. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish." Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the way flowers change as they decay fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up in water, becoming more interesting over time.

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers back then, thinking they looked artificial. She admired how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Today, her garden includes plants from distant countries, but they thrive as if they belong there. Susan has a relaxed approach to gardening, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions, she has less time for gardening, so she hired an extra gardener. However, she believes that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Title: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is in her second year working as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. Known as Pilch, she works for a company that provides cooking and cleaning services for visitors staying in chalets, which are typical wooden houses in the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She sees being a chalet girl not as a career but as a fun way to spend a couple of years before settling down. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she says.

Sarah doesn't live at the chalet. She starts her day at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing a full breakfast for the guests, including porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds the hardest part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski and enjoys being on the slopes as much as possible. "On a good day, we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting, but she avoids napping. "It's fatal if you do," she explains. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., with coffee by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and loads the dishwasher. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning," she says. Sometimes she chats with the guests, while other times they prefer to be left alone. "Good guests can make a week brilliant, but some weeks don't go quite as well," she notes.

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and perhaps end the evening at Dick's T-Bar," she says. However, she never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. "A frightful day," she calls it, "when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted."

On Sundays, work starts earlier, with breakfast for departing guests ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans the chalet thoroughly. "We just blitz the place—clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready," she says. If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. "Sometimes they are disoriented and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them," she says.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests needing boots or skis by taking them to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it's time for dinner again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night," she admits.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, because of my shifts, I don't see daylight. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I might faint, but I was surprised that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't exactly pleasant, but it left me with a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt different—people suddenly respected me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return journey, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don't exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, you meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers didn't eat super healthy, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journey Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes that travels along the coast and crosses into Italy. It offers stunning views of the sea. No matter the weather or season, the scenery is always beautiful. From the other window, you can see some of the nicest gardens and homes in France, making you feel like you're peeking into the lives of the rich and famous.
