The passengers are always lively, a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I had never been on a train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I owe a lot to one train: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how wonderful it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unreliable—we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, hundreds of people rushed to get on, even climbing onto the roof for free. During the night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite train memories as children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important to me. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old, unused part of the line, maintained by volunteers. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could. When I returned last year, it felt like time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Are you trying to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, has the advice you need. Many readers ask us, "I've written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" The first thing to know is that you need to research the market and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Selling your writing requires understanding the publishing world. No matter what you write, you need to know the market you are targeting. The best way to do this is by reading everything you can find. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what publishers are looking for at any time. Keep updating your knowledge because new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. New titles come and go all the time. Publishers are always looking for new writers, so we must give them what they want. 

If you're unsure what to write, let's say you want to write short love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories, as it's a limited market now, and get recent copies. Learn what kind of stories they buy and who their readers are. Editors focus on meeting their readers' needs. Writers often ask me, "My story has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone, but the work might not be ready for publishing. I try to give honest feedback with a positive outlook. Many new writers send their work too soon, before they are ready for the market. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. 

When you send your work for the first time, start writing more stories while waiting for a reply. Write ten or even twenty more. Each one will be better, and you'll start seeing yourself as a writer. Your fluency and confidence will grow. Don't throw any stories away—improve them. I also suggest not showing your work to others, especially early on. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby or join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.

On the last day of a difficult year, I was at the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. The station was busier than I expected, losing its usual clean and airy feel. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. A well-dressed, grey-haired man was going around asking people questions. He approached a woman sitting alone and then a girl near me with long blond hair. He asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" She replied, "I'm going north, but to New York." He thanked her and moved on. 

I became curious about him. He asked an old lady, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" She said, "Wilmington," and he moved on to another couple. I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me, probably because I didn't look reliable to him. He seemed stressed and asked a woman reading a book, "Please, tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She said she was, and he asked her for a favor. I pretended to check my watch, even though I didn't have one, and listened.

The man explained that his daughter was flying abroad from Philadelphia and had forgotten her passport. She called home from the station, unsure of what to do. He told her to stay there, and he would find someone to bring her passport. The woman asked why he didn't go himself. He said he couldn't leave his wife alone because she was in a wheelchair. This seemed like a weak excuse to me. 

I noticed he was holding a padded envelope, not a plain one, which seemed suspicious. It looked stapled shut, making me think it was hiding something. I silently warned the woman to be careful.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, a restaurant owner, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a well-known TV chef.

I think everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was running a restaurant. When I found out about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was just what I wanted. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory, and I felt very sad because I was left alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife focused on taking care of the children and did all my accounts, while I managed the business. We lived above the restaurant back then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This has been very beneficial for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life.

Gary was a very energetic child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into our corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with small jobs, and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had plenty of money at school. He was disciplined. He would wake up even before me in the morning. In a family business, everyone helps out, and it was nice to see him involved. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was excellent in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as any of the adults working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He could make over a hundred meals, and I knew he would go into catering because he had a natural talent. So when he told me he needed to do work experience for school, I sent him to a friend's restaurant.

Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if his music career takes off. My advice to Gary is: if you try to do too many things at once, you might not succeed in any, so focus on what you know you can achieve. I told him, 'Gary, if you want to succeed in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it might be too late.'

Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students, who are usually beginners, were given a task meant to last all morning. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He had prepared everything. That's my son! In the end, he was helping others. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. I'm very proud of him. I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it because no one will just give it to you. He's seen the opportunity he was given and took full advantage of it. You talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even ten percent of what you tell them, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.

Finding an affordable flat in Dublin was as difficult as finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a flat, that often helped. But for Jo, who had just arrived in Dublin, there were no personal contacts to rely on. She had no one to inform her about available places. So, she stayed in a hostel and searched for a flat. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going; it was just assumed by everyone she knew from school that she would leave. Who would want to stay in a small, remote town? That's all she had heard for years. Everyone wanted to leave, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates had moved to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family to help them settle. But none from Jo's year were going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel, which was run by nuns, so she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm, as they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses in a hotel, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn't know they were all thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who seemed to have been rejected, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." "Oh," said Jo and continued climbing. "Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type." "What did she do?" asked Jo. "Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Jo realized Pauline was a punk, which surprised her. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one before. "I'm Jo, I work at the post office, and I called about the flat." Nessa said they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs. One had "Nessa," one had "Pauline," and the other had "Other" written on it. "We'll put your name on it if you stay," she said kindly.

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them at seaside marinas, in movies, and on TV. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds explains how dolphin numbers are decreasing. Dolphins are special to us because they are very intelligent, understand human emotions, and make us dream of freedom in the ocean. TV shows like "Flipper" and "Seaquest" have made us love them even more. But these shows don't show the real problems dolphins face in polluted and overfished seas today. 

For example, the number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think such popular animals are protected by law and live in special marine reserves, but this is not true. Without plans to protect them, dolphins might face one of the biggest wildlife crises of our time.

There are 40 different types of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two types usually live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups. We know little about them. The larger bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were once found along the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress, like skin injuries.

Dolphins have complex habits, making it hard to pinpoint why their numbers are dropping. Overfishing, which is reducing fish stocks and threatening local fishing industries, also affects dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are overfished in one area, they might not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they can't see. Modern fishing methods use large nets that float or are dragged quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on beaches in France and Cornwall, showing marks and cuts from these nets.

Pollution is another problem. Waste and chemicals in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and they accumulate in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk with high levels of pesticides, passing the poison to their young. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's poisoned milk.

Perhaps the most debated threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their world. Noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times better in water than in air, which might disturb dolphins in ways we don't fully understand yet.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels chaotic and fast-paced. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but it's really beneficial for you. There are many reasons to exercise and not many reasons not to, for most people.

Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It increases muscle power and helps you stand or sit with good posture. Good posture is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. Exercise also prevents muscle imbalances that can cause injuries. It quickly improves areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It also makes your heart, lungs, and blood circulation better.

You might have heard these reasons many times and feel bored. But here's something interesting: exercise can help with depression, tiredness, and sleep problems. It also helps control stress and can relieve some medical conditions. These reasons should convince you that exercise is good for you. If not, just think about it logically.

There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, lifting weights, or using weight machines. Remember, don't train too hard or with too much weight, as it can cause injuries. Start slowly and carefully. If you're unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you.

Good posture is important for improving your body shape. A stiff or sagging body doesn't look good, lacks energy, and can have minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling your head up. This helps lift your chest for better breathing and makes your body look slimmer. When standing with a balanced chest, you should be able to see your ankles.

Stretching your muscles improves flexibility and movement, helps maintain good posture, and prevents injuries. Stretching four or five times a week will make your body more flexible and fit. It should be a key part of your exercise routine, done slowly and carefully.

The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home comforts for months? It's their quest for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, finding producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman can be as challenging as spotting the wildlife they film. Currently, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, where six months of rain have caused unexpected problems. Newman mentioned they had to buy expensive equipment to rescue their vehicles from the mud. Their partnership has produced some of TV's best wildlife films, like their acclaimed film on leopards. Even while that film was airing, they were back in the wild, this time filming the elusive jackal.

This is common for TV partnerships. Film-makers have traveled the world to capture exotic wildlife since TV began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare visits to a safari lodge. He said they sometimes argue but resolve issues quickly. Neither sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they view animals similarly. They usually set up tents each night, but now they have a fixed camp. They prepare tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask. Their meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. 'We can be out for up to eight weeks, so food can be a challenge,' says Newman. It's a tough life, but being alone in remote areas lets them get close to the animals. Newman recalls filming a lion family where a lioness would greet their car as part of her routine.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on 'The Great Rift,' and two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. They spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before starting, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I have a good working relationship because we share the same ideas and vision,' says Newman. 'We aim to create films rich in atmosphere that capture the true spirit of the place and animals, touching people's hearts. Evoking an emotional response is better than appealing only to the intellect.'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis interviewed Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. When I met Kendra, she was having a typical day leading up to next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location. "Don't people stare at you?" I asked. "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice," she replied. "I might see cars slow down from the corner of my eye, but that's it."

"My whole life is about being at my best for the Championships," Kendra says. She follows a strict schedule to reach peak fitness. This will be her fourth World Championships, and they are expected to be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We'll have home support, which is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing here means more pressure and expectations from the home crowd. People expect us to start strong."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we've always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But Kendra notes that the World Championships are challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day, with no rest between games like in a series. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win overall. But in the Championships, there's only one chance, and you have to be ready."

In her 15 years of playing at the top level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don't train so hard not to win," says Kendra. "But once the final whistle blows, we become different people. We're all friendlier after the game."

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "It's essential that we think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. As captain, she believes it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. She sees her role as supporting and encouraging her team.

"From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned," she says. She decided some time ago that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University, teaching and researching marine geochemistry, which is the study of chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she dives three kilometers deep into the ocean in a small steel vehicle to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, space is very tight. Rachel can touch the two pilots sitting next to her. They can't stand up or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive lasts about 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.

If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant experience.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, she has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team to a site five days west of the Canary Islands. There, they explored a large area of underwater volcanoes, where the ocean seems alive. The Russian team was setting up equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When she's not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. Most of her salary comes from teaching, which she enjoys, but it allows her to continue her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes that release water looking like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and a temperature of 350 degrees.

Rachel recalls being scared once when diving with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the ocean's deepest parts is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out and sees the chimneys of the volcanoes, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. After studying black smokers for three years for her Ph.D., seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, body movements, how fast or slow we talk, and our voice's volume and tone, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she recalls. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should aim to present yourself in the best way." Many people ignore the importance of a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but didn't even get an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before applying again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from words, 38% from voice, and 55% from facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will trust the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will confuse the interviewer.

It's also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job immediately. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss sensed how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't turn him down. So, he offered me a lower salary than I hoped for. I'm sure I could have gotten more if I had controlled my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it will help in an interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about the company's activities. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive impression and show your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confused sentences. As she says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He spent 14 years in the business world, but over time, he found it less exciting and more of a routine. He didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but he was suddenly made redundant. Although the severance pay wasn't great, it was enough to start his farm. His big break came when he met the head chef of a local hotel with a top-rated restaurant. By supplying them, his reputation grew, and now he also sells meat through mail order. He's happy not to be in an office anymore, but he still works 80 to 90 hours a week and is still selling a product.

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. Painting started as a hobby, but he found it more exciting than his job. Taking redundancy and becoming an artist seemed like a logical choice. A career counsellor helped him, and Ron was probably the first person to say, "I don't want to go back to where I've been." Most people in their mid-forties need to return to work quickly for financial reasons, but Ron and his wife married young, and their children were independent. They moved to the north of England, leaving friends behind, but their friendships have survived, and many friends visit them now.

**The Hatmaker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats for private clients in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned a lot, but the hours were long. She didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more, so she left. Some people thought she would get bored, but that hasn't happened. The key is having deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and new trends, so she keeps a strict schedule. She's happier and less stressed now, though she misses socializing with colleagues. She loves being fully responsible for her work. If something goes wrong, it's her responsibility. When your name is on the product, you care more.

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. He liked the excitement but didn't find the work fulfilling. In 1989, he almost lost his job, but he resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what he wanted to do. Interested in health, he visited top gymnasiums and talked to their owners. He knew he needed qualifications to change careers, so he took massage courses. He was then offered part-time work at the Life Centre. He has no regrets and now feels in control of his life, which is the best part.

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I've always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. At 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing because I hoped for sponsorship to help with training costs. I train at home during winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because of the great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn't have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics, which would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so you often meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you have to avoid late-night parties. I don't mind that much, but I do miss sleeping in. However, it's worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I make sure to celebrate, especially if there's prize money involved. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship led to me hosting a surfing series on TV. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some say we act childishly, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters often care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can't focus on the sport all the time—it's not healthy. I'm known in the sailing world, but I've only been recognized in public a few times, which is good because I don't want to be a celebrity. I get many letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's amazing to walk on court and feel the crowd's support. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out shopping. It has downsides, though. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was tough, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport and be professional. It doesn't bother me much now. I'm focused on my game and will catch up on other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

Shopping with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her kids want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty when she gives in to their demands. She also feels bad for saying no all the time and gets stressed even before leaving the house. She tries to avoid taking them shopping but worries they won't learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and they find it hard to believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when faced with attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertisers and often end up disappointing their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. However, as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to make people want to buy products, so the effect is the same.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse is a major source of stress for parents. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and advertisements, which has helped reduce conflicts in the supermarket. Her son is now critical of ads, and they spend time looking at product labels together.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in how they respond to their children's requests. Mike, a father of two, says he refuses to buy sweets for his son because they're unhealthy, even though he buys treats like cream and chocolate for himself. He finds it hard to be consistent and says his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas for children. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands could attract more customers.

**Five-star luxury with modern technology**

The Merrion Hotel, a new five-star hotel in Dublin, has just opened. It took almost two years to transform four large 18th-century houses into this luxury hotel. This transformation allowed the hotel to include the latest technology for both staff and guests.

Peter MacCann, the General Manager, wants his staff to know guests by name. However, he uses the hotel's computer system to remember guests' preferences. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature, where staff can record any number of preferences.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. The Merrion has a high-tech system to manage this. Guests can adjust the temperature themselves within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can set each room's temperature between 14°C and 25°C.

The technology in the rooms is especially appealing to business travelers, who are expected to make up 65% of the hotel's business. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has prepared for future technology upgrades by installing extra cables. TVs are rented, not bought, so they can be easily updated, and DVD recorders can be upgraded when needed.

Despite all this technology, the hotel aims to make guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, and welcoming. The hotel also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

The food at the Merrion must be excellent, as expected in luxury hotels. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He designed a new, modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel benefits by offering a popular dining option without financial risks.

With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to succeed.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share their secrets.

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann - Journalist and Author:**  
"I get my energy from excitement. I need to be doing something challenging. Learning new things gives me a lot of energy. Activities with rhythm, like flamenco dancing, also energize me. Dance is expressive and invigorating. I think boredom can make you feel tired and like life has no purpose. Being effective, even in small ways, gives you energy."

**B. Linda Kelsey - Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it, so it doesn't feel like a burden. Enjoying what you do keeps you from feeling down, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep to feel great. When I only get six hours, I feel sluggish. Exercise gives me energy, but finding the energy to start is hard! I do yoga once a week and try to work out at home. Exercise lifts my spirits. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 PM, so I think it's good to eat something then."

**C. Annie Nightingale - Disc Jockey:**  
"I don't eat healthily for energy; I think it's my natural enthusiasm and positivity. I dislike negative attitudes. I believe we should enjoy life and seize the moment. Enjoyment is key. You need to set goals and achieve them. My job is exciting, with lots of lively young people around. I love being busy and social. I enjoy taking photos and writing imaginary song lyrics for fun. It's a good mental release when I travel."

**D. Floella Benjamin - Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in my work and family life, and being positive helps. I love working with kids because they are resilient and give a lot. Energy is like a natural chemical that comes from interacting with others. Smiling at people and getting a smile back is thrilling. I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, but I don't have an exercise routine. My most energetic moments are playing with kids."

**E. Deborah Moggach - Author and Playwright:**  
"I love turning wasteland into a garden. I once transformed a concrete area by breaking it up and adding soil. It was better than any workout. Knowing someone wants to read my writing gives me energy. I find it hard to write without an audience. I also enjoy sneaking into private lands like a child, pretending I didn't know it was private."

**F. Katherine Monblot - Therapist:**  
"I believe in having interest and respect for what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't want to do is exhausting. I used to be on committees and disliked the time they took. You have limited energy, so focus it on what's most important to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. People used these bone skates until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style to the sport, making it more popular. Today, modern skating combines art and athleticism, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. Your body position is important for balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees flexed to center your body weight, leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is key in skating, more so than in other sports. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot while making a small movement with the other foot. It's fairly simple, right? As you practice, you can gradually make your movements longer.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should master. Even professional skaters fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when you fall, which helps reduce the impact. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you feel confident moving on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn the basic moves, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.

If you watch a good or professional skater, you'll notice how relaxed and smooth they are. To achieve this, you should regularly practice exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises are important, especially for the legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also benefits heart and lung health and strengthens the body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very emotional. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges in their lives.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15,** won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to become a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard right now. I don't have time to watch TV, hang out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to focus on each day. When I'm extremely tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

**B. Annika's mother** says, "Annika showed great potential from a young age. I've seen parents push their kids, and it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People often say we've given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who sucked her thumb and hid behind me. Now, she's met people worldwide and gained confidence from her success."

**C. Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they are happy when I win, but I do it for myself. My goal this year is to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win an Olympic gold medal."

**D. Sarah's mother** says, "Sarah's passion for horses started when she was 1. At 5, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, you have to compete all over England. We save money by sleeping in the horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happiest on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is unbeatable."

**E. Jane McShane, 10,** is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about getting a big head. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like feeling embarrassed."

**F. Jane's mother** says, "Jane played her first game at 5. My father suggested it, and she loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to quit, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to discourage her because she's exceptional. If she has this gift, she should reach her potential."

Chris Greener was only fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, asking if he wanted to be the flagpole on a ship because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, Chris is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every ten years, people in Europe grow about one centimeter taller on average. More and more very tall people are being born each year. This doesn't mean we're becoming a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our original size from when we were cavemen. We are now overcoming the effects of poor diets from the past, which is having a big impact. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says we are becoming like the Cro-Magnons, who lived 40,000 years ago.

In the past, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. Some tribes still live this way today. One study found that they ate 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming began, which changed everything. Farmers took over most green areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health and growth. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing, turned out to be a health disaster. Despite this, farming spread because it could support more people than hunting and gathering. 

Only recently have wealthier countries started to improve diets to match those of our ancestors. In the US, the average man is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it brings challenges. Beds have been the same length since 1860, and legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased. Clothing manufacturers also have to adjust their sizes.

The question is, how tall can we get? We can't grow forever. Robert Fogel from the University suggests we might reach an average height of 193 cm this century. However, scientists note that while individuals are getting taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, humans were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate has warmed, we've become thinner and smaller, even with good nutrition. If the planet continues to heat up, we might shrink even more. So, global warming could counteract the growth in human height.

**Studio Audiences: What It's Like to Be in One**

Have you ever wondered what it's like to be in the audience when a TV show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman explored this experience. Studio audiences are a regular part of TV production, but they remain a mystery to many of us. When we see them getting excited on game shows, we often wonder: who are these people?

Studio audiences are sometimes seen as the least prestigious of all live entertainment audiences. Some people in the TV industry even look down on them, treating them poorly. I used to think that studio audiences were just people looking for a brief moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from all walks of life, including different social classes, jobs, and income levels. TV shows try to attract various types of people depending on the program.

For those of us who enjoy watching TV at home, it can be hard to understand why someone would want to be in a studio audience. Why go through the trouble of getting tickets, traveling, and sitting for hours in an uncomfortable studio when you can watch the same show at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on TV, even if just for a moment. I didn't believe this until I met Angela, who said she came for the chance to appear on TV. Another reason might be curiosity about how TV shows are made. But the most common reason I heard was simply that a friend gave them a ticket.

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. We imagine sitting tightly packed with strangers, following signs that tell us when to clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager mentioned that they hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.

Is there a difference between watching a show in a studio and watching it at home? For Claire, being in a studio is more exciting. Charlotte enjoyed feeling part of live TV. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. Watching him live was different from seeing him on TV at home."

From my seat, I couldn't see much of the live actors, just the back of someone's head. The opening scenes were filmed so far away that I ended up watching them on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people in the audience, it was just a fun and free night out.

**Bruce**  
I prefer places where nature and people mix. When I travel, I like visiting charming villages with old temples rather than empty deserts. As a child, I went to school in England and would cycle to the village of Lastingham on weekends. Cycling was my escape from school, and I enjoyed exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. Being from Scotland, the landscape felt both familiar and new to me, and I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in a diary, which was my first step into travel writing, a field where I later became well-known.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by hobbyists. I always choose first class because it's only a little more expensive. The scenery isn't dramatic, just fields, sheep, and a canal. But I love the part where the train goes through people's back gardens. For a moment, we can see people in their daily lives, like making tea or doing dishes. I see myself as a woman on a tiny train, looking into others' homes. The ordinary landscape makes me look closer and find something new.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and remote coast. The beaches are hard to reach and rocky, so they aren't crowded. Some surfers come, but most people enjoy the sea's beauty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walks along the coast and trips inland through valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering places with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. Few people live or visit there, making it feel spacious and remote. I found it by accident as a student and have visited every year since, sometimes alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It hasn't changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these trips more special, though it saddens me that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain, to find peace and reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon, England, at twelve. I used to cycle around the moors and villages. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's a magical, secluded, romantic house where you only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

Title: A Day of Animal Chaos

We are a family that loves animals and enjoys having them around. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work, excited because she found a pine snake. She asked if we could keep it, and I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank ready for temporary animal guests, and we liked to look them up in our natural history book.

I got home late and started cooking when I heard my sons shouting for help. I rushed to their room and found our cat, Domino, with a white mouse in his mouth. The mouse was a Mother's Day gift for me. Domino was running around the room, trying to escape with his catch, while the kids were waving their arms to stop him. I joined the chaos and accidentally fell over. As I lay on the floor, I noticed the snake was escaping from its tank.

The room was a mess of jumping kids, a barking dog, and a hissing snake. I quickly turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and returned to the chaos. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and saved the mouse, which was unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived to old age.

Feeling confident after saving the mouse, I tried to handle the snake. It was not easy, but I sat on the floor and slowly calmed it down. Eventually, I lifted the snake and took it to the garden, hoping it would leave. When I let go of its head, the snake surprised me by wrapping around my shoulders like a scarf. My eldest child, DJ, explained that I was warm, and the garden shed was not.

We gently encouraged the snake to move on, and it finally climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, summed up our feelings: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Send me a letter! In today's fast-paced world with phones, fax machines, and computers, the traditional art of writing letters is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter is a unique experience that no other form of communication can match. There's the excitement when it arrives, the joy of seeing who it's from, and finally, the pleasure of reading it. Letter writing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn't matter how short or messy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote home once a week, and my mother did the same. Sometimes my father would write, and his long, funny letters were always a delight to receive. Most letters from home were about everyday events involving my parents and their friends. Of course, we also made phone calls, but it's the letters I remember most. I also received letters from my boyfriends. In my youth, I often dated people who had to work or study far away, so we stayed in touch through letters. Instead of hurting the relationships, writing letters seemed to make them stronger. I found it easier to express myself in writing than in speaking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it's even better to have a year's worth of news! It's even more exciting when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. I get letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, someone I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have penfriends in Australia and Vancouver. There's also a lady from France who writes to me. We started talking in a restaurant on our way home from a holiday, my husband took her photo, and I asked for her address. If she hadn't replied, we would have missed out on a wonderful friendship. Now, we regularly write to each other. I can improve my French (she doesn't speak English); we've stayed at her home twice, and she's stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success was this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that a correspondence could last so long. The local newspaper even reported it on the front page. I'm happy that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, arranged by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become a 'lost art'.'

Title: Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Alpine Rock Art

In the French Alps, at Mont Bego, there are tens of thousands of ancient rock carvings that are being slowly destroyed. These carvings, which are about 4,000 years old, include images of horned cows, fields, and various gods and goddesses. Scientists are worried that the 36,000 drawings will be lost to future generations because they are being damaged so quickly.

The site, once a place for prayer and worship, is now a popular tourist destination. Unfortunately, the increase in visitors has led to the pictures being ruined by graffiti. Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, warns that if the damage continues, nothing will be left in 50 years. He has seen tourists walking on the drawings, which wears away the rock, and some even take pieces home as souvenirs. When visitors can't take clear photos, they rub the drawings to make them more visible, which damages them further. Some people even scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.

Experts disagree on how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, suggests making the mountain a 'no-go' area, allowing access only through guided tours. He believes this is the only way to save the site and continue important research. However, Jean Clottes thinks this approach is too extreme and would upset local residents. He emphasizes the need to preserve the site, which is classified as a historic monument.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also opposes closing the site. He suggests allowing people to visit but acknowledges the difficulty in preventing damage due to the site's large size. He mentions the financial challenge of hiring enough guards and suggests that charging an entrance fee might be necessary, as government funding is unlikely.

Annie Echassoux, a researcher in Nice, is concerned that easier access to the mountain, such as vehicle hire, will lead to more damage. She believes the area should be roped off and guided tours provided. She insists that financial constraints should not stop the preservation efforts, as the site is a historic monument and must be protected for future generations.

Shopping with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her kids want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty when she gives in to their demands, as she believes she's buying unhealthy items. However, she also feels bad for saying no all the time and gets stressed even before leaving the house. She tries to avoid taking them shopping but worries they won't learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and arguments about health don't seem convincing compared to the appealing ads they see.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertisers and often end up disappointing their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy, so even without direct instructions, the ads still encourage children to want products.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse can be a major source of stress for parents. One mother says she discusses food with her children and has taught her son to be critical of ads. They now have fewer conflicts in the supermarket because her children don't ask for things she won't buy.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they're unhealthy, yet they buy treats like cream and chocolate for themselves. He finds it hard to be consistent, as his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas for children. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands could attract more customers.

Text: 'Climbing Walls: A New Era Once, climbers only went to mountains. Now, challenging climbs can happen anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The audience watches closely. High above them on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by just two fingers, is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is more known for the TV show Gladiators, but both the show and the climbing championships have one thing in common - The Wall. This is possible because of new and fast-developing technology. Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were many good climbing spots. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. But as climbing became more popular, top climbers needed to stay fit. Since cliffs were unusable for much of the year, they used brick edges or stone buildings to train. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom. Soon, many sports centers started building walls for climbing, using bricks with special edges to hold onto. Many of these early walls were inspired by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher who, in the mid-1960s, built a climbing wall in a corridor at Leeds University. Robinson had the idea of setting natural rock in concrete blocks, which could be part of a wall. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls across the country in the 1970s, but they had design problems. These walls could only be vertical, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and angled rock slabs. Another problem was that once the walls were built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers would get bored with the same holds. In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a material that he shaped into forms like those found on cliffs. These could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a new challenge. French companies also started experimenting with panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls without major construction, but steel frames could be set up anywhere as free-standing structures. A system of interchangeable holds gave climbers endless new challenges.'

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it's 'risky' very quickly. And they are right; acting is a risky career. There are more people who want to be actors than there are acting jobs. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you're crazy, while others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But choosing to be an actor is a personal decision, and only you can be responsible for achieving your dream. There are no easy paths to success in acting. There are no exams to pass, and even if you finish your training, there is no guarantee you will succeed. Success depends on luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new talent, and acting can be exciting and glamorous, with the chance of big rewards. People often ask what talent is. I think talent is natural skill plus imagination, with imagination being the hardest to judge. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. Why do people want to act? It's hard to explain why you want to act. In theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what drives actors to perform. If you ask successful actors how they made it, they might just shrug. They know some things about themselves and their techniques, but they don't take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job, and fame might not last. Disappointment is an actor's biggest enemy. Last month, you might have been out of work, doing other jobs like selling clothes or waitressing. Then, you might get an audition, but even if you want the job badly, you might not get it. So, actors often don't talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of auditions and possible rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Remember, from the moment you start auditioning, you are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. It's partly up to you because if you don't care enough, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our special selection of top cookbook titles currently available.

**A. Delia Smith**

When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and show her love for exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. Her book, *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, is now a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple yet expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of excellent recipes. Recently updated, it remains the go-to book for anyone asking, "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

**B. Raymond Blanc**

Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur, untrained chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His first TV series, *Blanc Mange*, now has a companion book. Raymond aims to make us better cooks by showing how and why ingredients behave as they do. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what's happening in the pan. The book includes over 80 impressive recipes and explains why some dishes might fail, using basic food chemistry to clarify. Raymond loves cooking to entertain, and this book shows he's excellent at it.

**C. Le Cordon Bleu**

Le Cordon Bleu is synonymous with the best in classical French cooking. For over 100 years, this renowned cooking school has trained students to achieve perfection. To celebrate its centenary, the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook* presents 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While these recipes are classics, they remain fresh and have adapted to modern tastes by reducing rich, creamy sauces. The book starts with kitchen basics and moves on to Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have contributed their famous recipes and shared their secrets.

**D. Nigel Slater**

Fast food often gets a bad reputation, but Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, disagrees. His new book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to deliver a pizza. This book offers over 200 enticing recipes from around the world, all ready in just 30 minutes. Written in his lively and enjoyable style, Nigel proves that fast food can also be great food. If you're skeptical, try his recipes—they're simply delicious.
