**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He spent 14 years in the business world, but over time, he found it less exciting and more of a routine. He didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but he was suddenly made redundant. Although he didn't receive a large payout, it was enough to start his farm. His big opportunity came when he met the head chef of a local hotel with a top-rated restaurant. By supplying them, his reputation grew, and now he also sells meat through mail order. He is happy not to be in an office anymore, but he still works long hours and sells a product.

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. Painting started as a hobby, but he found it more exciting than his job. Choosing to take redundancy and become an artist seemed logical. A career counselor helped him, and he was unique in saying, "I don't want to go back to where I've been." Most people in their mid-forties need to return to work for financial reasons, but Ron and his wife married young, and their children were independent. They moved to the north of England, leaving friends behind, but their friendships have lasted, and many friends visit them now.

**The Hatmaker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned a lot, but the hours were long. She realized she didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so she left. Some people thought she would get bored, but that hasn't happened. The key is having deadlines, as the fashion business is always busy with collections and seasons. She feels happier and less stressed now, although she misses socializing with colleagues. She loves being fully responsible for her work, and if something goes wrong, it's her responsibility.

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. He liked the excitement but didn't find the work fulfilling. In 1989, he almost lost his job, but he resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what he wanted to do. Interested in health, he visited top gymnasiums and talked to their owners. To change careers, he knew he needed qualifications, so he took massage courses. He was then offered part-time work at the Life Centre. He has no regrets and now feels in control of his life, which he values most.

Title: A Childhood Game Turns into a Business Success

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, have turned a childhood game into a successful business. In their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, they often play pichenotte, a game their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought from Quebec, Canada. The family played it regularly, and it became a cherished tradition.

Years later, Dave noticed their old pichenotte board was worn out and decided to make a new one. This new board caught the attention of family and friends, who wanted their own. Curious about the game's appeal, the brothers took a board to a local sports bar. Initially, people were skeptical, but once they tried it, they couldn't stop playing.

Dave researched the game's history and found it likely originated in India as 'carroms,' which evolved into 'squails' in Britain. British immigrants brought it to Canada, where it became known as pichenotte in Quebec.

Pichenotte is a skill-based game for two to four players. Each player has 12 pieces, or 'pucks,' which they flick across a board to score points. The goal is to flick pucks into a small hole for 20 points, with additional points for landing in concentric rings around the hole. The game is fast-paced, usually lasting about two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity grow, the brothers started making more boards and selling them at markets and craft fairs. They even organized championships with a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup.' As demand increased, they decided to focus on making pichenotte boards full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and have produced over 450 boards so far. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and costs $595.

Although there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, the brothers are optimistic. They hope their business will continue to grow and eventually allow them to enjoy the fruits of their labor. Until then, they are happy to keep playing the game they love.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was a piece of unused land, flat and covered with wild plants. For a long time, people thought it was worthless. However, with careful planning and hard work, one man, with the constant support of his wife, transformed this land into the beautiful place you see today. During the construction, many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the shaped landscape you see now. Although machines like bulldozers helped, a lot of hard work was still needed. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens.

In creating the Model Village, hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted. These plants had to be chosen carefully because they needed to survive the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds in this open area. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole village was the idea of Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting from when the village first opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics to withstand all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to understand how different materials would last in changing weather, but he soon became an expert himself. You will notice that a consistent scale is used, and even the smallest details are carefully included in the models. This was achieved through patience and unique construction techniques.

The Model Village has become a popular attraction, known for its high-quality workmanship and maintenance. The techniques used here have been applied in other model villages around England and are even taught in some college courses on modeling. All the model buildings in the village show traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any specific place or structure. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition to the village.

We ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models; a small mistake can lead to hours of repair work for us. You can take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press these to see the models in action.

At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your thoughts. New models are always being planned, and your ideas can help us create a more varied and interesting display. We also want to know if there are any models you think do not meet the high standards of the rest of the village. We are always updating and replacing models, so your feedback is important. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about us.

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish photos that invade people's privacy and break the editors' code of practice. Although pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not common. Usually, these photos cause a lot of harm to public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization set up to handle such issues. These photos rarely serve the public interest. Do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a photo of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where privacy is expected, she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't take any action. It's shocking that the PCC didn't investigate on its own. They should also look into the recent scandalous story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star hasn't made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other shameful attacks? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers, which would be reported by their competitors and on TV and radio. The public wouldn't support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it wouldn't be profitable to hide and take photos of celebrities. If the PCC decided to act like a 'police officer', which it technically could, there would be several issues. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it encourage the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Also, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. Above all, the task is too big. How could the PCC realistically monitor all British press: national, regional, and magazines? Then there's the embarrassment factor. No matter how seriously someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the further embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story they managed to keep from the press, and they fear it could become public if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might seem like an enemy. A British comedian also suffered when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor when he and his family were photographed during a family holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the photos again with a new story about his 'anger', claiming it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People believe they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It's hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

There is a lot of advice for college graduates starting their first job. In this article, we focus on moving to a second job. We are not talking about those looking for another temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those leaving a bad job within the first few weeks. Instead, we are discussing those who are taking a real step in their career, choosing a job that matches their ambitions after gaining some experience and skills. 

What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to decide if you want to specialize in a specific area, move up to higher levels of responsibility, or switch to a different field. Whatever you choose, pick your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow and give you more responsibility.

If you feel like traveling, now is a good time to do it. You can do temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are ready to focus on your career.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a great first job because they were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her skills. However, there was no room for advancement. So, she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years, I have become more capable, and my job has really grown,' she says. 'From the start, my boss wanted to help me develop. My job title is the same, but my duties have changed. I have moved from mainly typing and phone work to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. I also deal with various questions, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves me in all her work and gives me specific projects and events to organize.'

Confident people: What's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were always this way, but many say it's a skill they learned because they needed to. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

A. Jenny: When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At 25, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I didn't think I could do it, but I surprised myself. Someone there suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school was a turning point in my life.

B. Michaela: Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive and impatient. I thought that's how confident people acted, but I learned that true confidence means believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don't feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with challenges, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I often talk to myself to overcome it.

C. Lisa: People think I'm confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. In TV, looking confident is crucial. Interviewing people taught me that everyone gets nervous in important situations, and we feel better when talking to someone friendly. My mother once told me, "Who's looking at you? Everyone's worried about themselves." This advice helps me. You gain confidence by facing your fears. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I could handle anything.

D. Barbara: My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I've built it over time. By learning from mistakes, you become more confident. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let that bother me. You need to like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses that boost my self-esteem. They also encourage setting achievable goals. It's better to achieve small, tangible things than aim too high and get nothing.

E. Kim: After college, I worked as a secretary and often disagreed in meetings but was too scared to speak up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I started in politics, I had never spoken in public and was very nervous. I told myself, "People do this every day, so you can too." Writing down a few notes helped me feel more secure. Everyone feels a bit nervous speaking in public. The key to confidence is telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

Paul Forster visits Malaysia for a kite-flying festival and experiences an adventurous night in the forest. Adnan Ali, a local, smiled as I returned his broken kite. "You should keep it," he said, "it's a tradition here—if the line breaks, the finder keeps the kite. Plus, I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. Each kite was exactly 120cm wide and long, made from tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat in the shade of the trees near the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, watching Malaysia's largest kite festival. 

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A row of competitors stood ready, holding their kite lines, waiting for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites soared into the sky. Over 500 men and boys had entered the competition, which lasts five days each year. They submitted four different kite designs, judged on decoration, stability, and flying ability. "Flying kites isn't hard," said Adnan, "but making them requires real skill. Come to my home, and I'll show you how it's done." I accepted his invitation, one of five I received that day.

At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, polished room. As night approached, he invited me to return the next day to help rebuild his kite, but my plans didn't allow it. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur through granite mountains covered in lush rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A narrow boat was there to ferry people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my attention. It pointed up a path into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km."

I didn't realize that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the path, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay, trying not to worry about insects under my thin mattress. The night was pitch black, filled with various sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and countless creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, I enjoyed a stunning view of five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained heavily. First came the wind, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. As I slid downhill, I wondered how the large butterflies avoided the heavy raindrops. I also worried about my car being swept away, which sometimes happens, and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track.

In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people were curious and friendly, asking me questions like "Where are you from?" and "How old are you?" Kelantan is famous for its kites, but I remember it more for the kindness of its people.

**What Kind of Shopper Are You?**

Everyone shops, whether they like it or not. But people shop in different ways. Do you know what type of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits:

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**  
I'm a shopping addict—I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it makes me happy. I find it hard to ignore sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple!

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**  
I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he wants. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't often spend money on myself, so when I do, I feel guilty and rarely tell my husband the real amount—I always say I spent less because the real price sounds shocking.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really have to. When I shop, I know exactly what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and would rather be doing something else.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**  
I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and shop quickly. I do have some mistakes hidden in my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes wrong choices!

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
I don't enjoy shopping at all. I dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and disorganized, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely need to shop for clothes because most of mine are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish quickly.

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**  
I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my girlfriends just to look around, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
I'm a careful shopper—I like shopping, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and rarely go overboard. Sometimes I shop to cheer myself up, but I often feel worse because I've spent too much!

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it's too busy. I'm a careful shopper. I usually know what I want and never buy things immediately. I check other shops to find a better deal, which takes a long time!

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
I'm an unwilling shopper. Maybe because I work in the city center, shops have lost their appeal for me. When I have to shop, I do it reluctantly. I don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of effort shopping!

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE The Open University offers degrees just like any other university. However, you can continue working while you study. It also allows you to explore a wide range of interests. If you have never studied before, you will experience the joy of learning new things. You will meet many different people and make new friends. Your qualification might also lead to new career opportunities. Instead of attending lectures in person, you study at home using television, radio, and computer software. You can choose to attend one class a month at an Open University center if you want. Like any university, there are exams to pass. If you want more information, simply fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will explore 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch 18th-century artist Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist painted flowers in different seasons. Miss Violet Churchman donated it in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently bought works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
A series of lectures related to the special exhibition happens every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will focus on Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery restaurant now has better and more varied services. With new kitchens, it offers a wide range of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm, except Sundays. These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest paintings and cover the collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Little Chefs

Every Saturday, a group of children aged ten to fifteen learn how to cook seriously. These classes are so popular that 30 children are waiting to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where their children can have fun and learn to cook well. Bill, who is ten, says, "I love my mum's cooking, but now I can cook better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we've made together." Flora, who is twelve, finds cutting onions difficult. She says, "I love cooking. I once cooked a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I liked staying at home, so I wasn't interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we keep learning about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will know how to cook for themselves when they leave home."

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. If there are more than four people, each extra person costs 50p. You need to pay the fees at the main office. The centre is open to everyone and aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation for the public. If you are visiting as a group, please let the centre know in advance.

Windsurfing - One-day Course
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable, and the thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. The course costs £32.50, which includes all equipment.

One-day Adventure Course
This is a great chance to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. The course is designed to introduce adults to outdoor activities in a fun and relaxed way. You don’t need to be very fit or have any previous experience. Just bring your interest! The course costs £22.50.

Play Park
The Play Park is perfect for children aged two to ten. It is one of the best in the country, with sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group Day and Residential Courses
We offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us regularly. We have three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14)
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that all children participate in activities suitable for their age and abilities. Children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health to join this program.

Stamp Collecting - A Hobby That Keeps Growing

Millions of people, young and old, enjoy stamp collecting. It's a hobby that is both interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections and find a passion that can last a lifetime. 

Starting a stamp collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can find them on holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from relatives, and letters from pen pals. These can give you stamps from all over the world. 

Once you get serious about collecting, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You have three options for receiving them: 

1. We can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope addressed to you.
2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts.
3. We can send you individual stamps for you to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join too, with a two-year membership costing just £5. If a group of you join at the same time, you can get a discount. This is great value for money. 

When you join, the Club sends you a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also get a helpful 4-page guide to collecting, with tips on how to add to your collection and addresses of shops and businesses that sell stamps. 

Every two months, you'll receive the club magazine. It's full of competitions and quizzes, and it gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members around the world. 

Why not start an adventure that will give you years of pleasure? You'll spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for rare ones. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun and excitement of stamp collecting. 

To join the Club, simply fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will be sent within 28 days of receiving your application.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, the farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Enter our story competition! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other winners will receive a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write great stories. The judges, including novelist Mary Littlejohn, TV reporter Michael Brown, and Keep Writing's editor Susan Hitchins, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective stories were very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like, but here are some tips to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most people who entered followed this advice. Love, family, and friendship problems were common themes. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read them. Make the reader want to keep reading by writing about everyday things in a new and surprising way. Get your facts right Don't describe a town or explain how something works if you are not sure about it. Only write about things you know well. Hold the reader's attention Make the beginning interesting and the ending surprising. A bad ending can ruin a story. Develop your story carefully and think of something unusual for the ending. Think about the characters Make the people in your story come alive for the reader by using the right words to make them seem real. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. Even if you are close to missing the deadline, we cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, and the story must not have appeared in print or on radio or TV anywhere in the world. Your £5 entry fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that his daughter received the best education possible. This was rare because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia went back to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we don't have any copies of her books, we know she wrote several important works on mathematics. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created several scientific tools to assist her work. During that period, many rulers were afraid of science, and people involved in it were at risk. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked on the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough in the east and ends at Wansford, where the Railway's main office is located, near the main road. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, which is the current western end of the line. Ticket prices are £10.00 for adults, £5.00 for children, and £25.00 for a family (up to 2 adults and 3 children). Special prices might be available on public holidays.

**Nene Park**

Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site, making it a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**

Wansford Station has a unique collection of historic trains from all over Europe. This includes famous trains like the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can also see '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower', which were built in Britain. These engines are on display all year, even when the Nene Valley Railway is not running. However, the buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. For example, the James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.

**Services for Schools**

From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or back in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train called 'Teddy Bear' with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Bookings should be made one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. For more information, call 01780 784444.

**Private Hire of Trains**

The Railway is a popular place for family events or company visits. It can provide an interesting afternoon or evening out. Special programs can be arranged to include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, and more. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 different types of grasses, and they can be found everywhere on Earth. Grasses are the only flowering plants that can survive in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way. Grass can quickly grow back after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, grass grows new leaves from below the ground, not from the top. This allows large groups of animals to live in one area because, after they eat the grass, it soon grows back, providing a fresh meal.

Kal Kaur Rai, who has always loved fashion, recently won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She believed they wanted her to pursue a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She needed to attend industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she liked, so she started making her own skirts and tops. Her friends admired her creations and asked her to make clothes for them too. Kal found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes sold well, and nothing was returned. This success gave her the confidence to leave her advertising job, take a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear brand. Her parents were supportive of her decision, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal's business has grown significantly, and she feels very fortunate. She says, "What I do is my hobby—and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

SUNNINGDALE HOTEL

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has been known for its excellent service, welcoming guests from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here.

The hotel is located on a main road leading to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes by bus to reach the center, and buses to various parts of the town stop outside the hotel. However, avoid buses with the blue "Express" sign, as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of all corridors. The hotel offers a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and laundry facilities. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. Parking is available in the hotel drive. Free daily newspapers are provided, and stamps can be bought at the office.

Guests staying for long periods must pay weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9.30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5.30 pm to 7 pm. During the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by signing the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires (for heating food or rooms) are allowed. Guests should respect others' comfort. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If arriving by train, it is recommended to take a taxi to the hotel, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. But his life wasn't always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved acting in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and took drama classes at the same time. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in films and remains very popular with his many fans worldwide.

Title: "Little Cat, Little Cat, Where Have You Been?"

When Bo, the cat, decided to explore a furniture van, she ended up on a bigger adventure than she had planned. The van driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. He gave her some milk and started looking for her owner. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. Since it was late, he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he brought her to an animal hospital.

Meanwhile, Bo's owner was also trying to find her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered something to a neighbor. Luckily, he recalled the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin in northern Australia to Adelaide in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia from the warm north coast through endless desert to the cooler Southern Ocean. It's often called the 'famous Ghan', but it's mostly known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan doesn't offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally meant to carry goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship around the continent, would save time and money. The Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south transcontinental railway. As I waited to board, everyone seemed excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners eager to get on. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan waited for four hours. Some passengers took a boat trip up the gorge. I didn't leave the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop here. The view from the train after Alice Springs isn't very interesting. It's mostly flat land with cattle. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train didn't meet all the promises of the advertisements, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

Climbing to the Top of Britain

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is so far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time climbing Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is 600 meters high and is probably the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are large bowl-shaped areas halfway up the mountain. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. These spikes are necessary because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. Even though some of us were very experienced, we packed all kinds of safety gear, like lights to signal for help, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The path soon became steep, and my legs felt tired. I was the least strong in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would always train properly before a climb in the future. After climbing 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on each step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and all the way to the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. However, we weren't so lucky because a mist had come down. On Ben Nevis, getting back down to camp can be as challenging as climbing up. You need to be able to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to slopes that are too dangerous to go down in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns doing that job. That first time, I only felt I really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we moved into our new school building! It's an amazing place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. But this new school is special because it's one of the first in our country to be very environmentally friendly. It took months to build, so we watched the whole process. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, although it meant losing some nice open space. The noise from the machines was very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think it would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are huge—much bigger than in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town when they need it for meetings. There's also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and big changing rooms that we can't wait to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you'll notice there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from us—the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep all the heat inside, and it keeps the sound in too. So, when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we're in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is the tree on the school roof! The builders put it there because it's a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It's so big that you can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on our website.

Even though we're already using the new school, some parts are still being added. For example, we're putting on a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall for it. The new hall will be ready next year. We're so happy with our new school, and our teachers say we'll learn much faster here!

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never imagined that I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground on a Saturday afternoon in November and actually enjoying it. As I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be away from the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and didn't know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us spent the morning caving, while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but felt happy and excited about what we had done.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, purse with about £50 in cash, and some credit cards. When I realized my mistake, it was too late. I felt lost because I'm 72 years old, far from home, and quite worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. After I explained, he kindly gave me money for the bus fare home. When I told the bus driver my story, he let me keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He told me they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. I got my handbag back with everything still inside. I want to express how grateful I am to everyone who helped me that day and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Text: 'Sharks Sharks are some of the most feared animals in the ocean. They are excellent hunters because they have very good eyesight and can sense movement through special lines on their bodies. This makes them very dangerous to smaller sea animals, which they eat. While sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For instance, unlike most fish, sharks need to keep swimming to breathe and stay alive, so they rarely sleep. Additionally, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can stop moving entirely. This is helpful for researchers who need to study sharks, as it allows them to learn more about these interesting creatures.'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov Ballet School in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around me, asking questions in Russian. I tried to speak a little Russian, and then they started speaking in English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I can understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad and even called home late at night once because I felt lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are very challenging, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This makes me confident that I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when I couldn't believe how cold it was. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy. Right now, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

THE ICEHOTEL

For many years, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. In winter, only a few people lived there, enjoying the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, people thought the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an art show in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, some foreign guests decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, it is famous worldwide.

When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As soon as one part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is complete. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the completion date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts.

Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the cost of staying at the hotel. Guests should also bring sweaters, a scarf, and plenty of wool socks. It's a good idea to wear shoes that are larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store for special deals, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). Normally, the store will be open from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had announced it would stay open for 24 hours straight on its first day. However, it had to close just 30 minutes after opening. A police officer at the scene said: 'We knew a big crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store filled up quickly, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. People outside got upset because they thought everything would be sold out before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly. Another issue was the long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. Many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked to the store, which blocked the road completely.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got inside, said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were calm and explained the situation. They had no choice because it wasn't safe. I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

Membership  
The Short Story Society supports writers in Britain today. Founded in 1899, it is now one of Britain's most active arts organizations.

Society Magazines  
We publish several great magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine features short stories by top British writers and offers new writers a chance to get published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing scene. You can read some articles from recent issues by following the links on our website.

National Short Story Competition  
We organize the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and stories on any topic are welcome. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Society members enter for free, while non-members pay a £5 entry fee. The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The top ten entries are published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner receives a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.

Education  
For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, giving children and teachers new ideas and boosting their writing confidence. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, for writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and can attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

The Writers' Cafe  
The Writers' Cafe is the Society's social hub. It is relaxed and stylish, offering freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. Located in central London, it is open from 11.00 am to 10.00 pm Monday to Friday and 11.00 am to 8.00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events.

Becoming a Member  
We have members worldwide, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

Tanya Streeter is a world record holder in free-diving, a sport where divers go deep underwater on a single breath. In 2003, she made history by diving 120 meters without any help, holding her breath for over three and a half minutes. This achievement made her the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. A team of fourteen safety divers monitored her dive at various depths. Despite concerns about the dangers of free-diving, Tanya believes that safety and training are crucial.

Most free-divers focus on specific events, but Tanya's training routine is consistent. She spends two-thirds of her time training on land, mainly in the gym, and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees, preferring fast walking instead. When practicing dives, she usually travels and aims to complete fourteen dives over four weeks, resting between each dive to avoid fatigue.

Outside of training, Tanya often appears in public to promote sports products and supports environmental causes through research and films. Growing up on Grand Cayman in the Caribbean, she loved swimming and exploring rock pools, which she says is like living her childhood dreams. Known in some countries, she uses her fame to raise awareness about environmental issues. In her thirties now, Tanya plans to continue breaking her own records and has no intention of retiring from free-diving anytime soon, having started the sport at twenty-five.

CARTOON FILMS

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, people thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, a few directors came up with original new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was a success. For example, The Black Cauldron did not do well because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.

Title: Caroline Benson's Journey to Her First TV Role

Caroline Benson, a new TV star, shares her experience of landing her first TV role. She never thought she would spend part of her first year at university filming "The Finnegans." Caroline had only acted in school plays before, but she loved the book since she was eleven. Her grandmother always said she was like Polly Finnegan, and Caroline dreamed of playing her.

Before starting university, Caroline took a year off to travel. While in Chile, her mother emailed her about plans to make the book into a TV drama. Caroline knew she had to try for the role. Her mother was surprised but sent Caroline's photo to the director and convinced him to meet her. Caroline flew back home and got the part.

Filming started a week after university began, so she got permission to be away for three weeks. When she returned, she woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on her essays. She didn't tell her university friends about the filming, but they found out and were excited for her. It was an incredible experience, and she feels very lucky.

Caroline wants to pursue acting as a career after university. Although her family isn't in the acting business, her grandfather was an opera singer. She has tried for other TV roles but hasn't received any offers yet. Despite her busy schedule, she managed to have a full social life. When filming ended, she wasn't sure what to do next. She has since acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, she hasn't been home much, and now that her first year at university is over, she's going to Greece for the summer with friends.

When I started the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to make enough money to support my children. Now, 'The Body Shop' has become a global company that is growing quickly. Over the years, I have learned many things, and I share these lessons in this book. I believe our company has valuable insights on how to run a successful business while staying true to our values. This book is not a typical business guide, nor is it just about my personal story. The key message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can have a positive impact. In both business and life, I need to have fun, feel a sense of family, and be excited by new challenges. I have always wanted the people who work at 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. This book shares my ideas with the world and makes them known. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

Title: A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River

Jules Verne offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The ship, MV Lady Ivy May, can host 160 guests in double cabins, each with an outside view, private shower, and toilet. The ship is air-conditioned and includes a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

Itinerary:

Day 1: Depart from London Heathrow in the early evening and fly to Oporto. Upon arrival, a guide will take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

Day 2: Spend the morning sightseeing in Oporto. Return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios, a four-hour journey up the river.

Day 3: Continue traveling up the river. In the early evening, stop at Peso da Regua, known for port wine. Enjoy local food and drink at dinner.

Day 4: After breakfast, take a bus to the ancient town of Lamego. Visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum, which was once a palace and now has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua.

Day 5: The Douro River becomes narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. Return to Tua by coach, enjoying the sights along the way.

Day 6: In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for stunning views of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take a scenic train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.

Day 7: Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, travel down the river back to Oporto. Spend the night on the Lady Ivy May.

Day 8: Arrive in Oporto with time for independent sightseeing and shopping before flying back to London Heathrow.

HONEY

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made up of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to 75,000 kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than 300 types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweetener because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who even used it as money. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that it can help prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. But honey is not just food - it can also be used for sore throats and is an ingredient in many skin and hair-care products.
