The Albuquerque Balloon Festival

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a desert city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is because of the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival happened in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. Back then, there were only about a dozen hot-air balloons, and they took off from a parking lot in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at the current site outside the city.

What to See

The balloon pilots stay in radio contact and light up their balloons' burners at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. To see these 'glows,' you need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it. In the afternoon, you can even take a balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies offering flights. Another option is to take a cable car ride from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere and offers a great view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box

This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

Practical Advice

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long lines at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing. It can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you will need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you are not using a digital camera, you will need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

The Eden Project Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular places to visit. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the connection between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many everyday products come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always humid because of a large waterfall. Another zone mimics the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone soon.

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Isn't 500 pages of original writing of this quality, for just £6.99, quite impressive? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by well-known writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less famous writers seem to focus mainly on food. Be cautious with Jane Harris's Those Nails - it's best not to read it right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset your stomach! The collection also features excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are excerpts from novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, including a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers, and an extraordinary piece by Ursula Owen about herself. This is an outstanding collection, and I am eager to see what next year's selection will include.'

The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when children are learning about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to start teaching children at ages three and four, but she sometimes makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first students were her children's five-year-old school friends. 

Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts an hour, happening once every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents must also attend the classes because it is important for them to be actively involved in the lessons. 

From the very first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years. For a long time, there is a big difference between their ability to play and their ability to read music. Margaret says her method is not meant to create great violinists. She often suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Moonshine, the band, released their third CD last week called 'Here Again', which follows their previous album 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee who left the band last year, and Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance track, it's clear that the band is moving away from focusing only on slow songs. The second song is also a dance track and is even louder and more intense. Most of the later songs on the CD are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans, but they are excellent and could easily become hit singles. Singer Rob Letchford performs exceptionally well, hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded these songs before he had throat problems, which have caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets shouldn't worry, as all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create great music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the upbeat ones that make you want to dance. However, I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks weren't as strong. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

San Francisco is a city on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was discovered from the land, not from the sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. But it wasn't the gold seekers who became rich. The wealthiest people made their money by owning banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS Samuel Pepys wrote the most famous diary in English. His diary gives a detailed and interesting view of everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys talks about important events of the time, like disease outbreaks, an enemy navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, including his flaws - he often fell asleep in church or admired pretty girls. He describes his home life, such as arguments with his wife and how they made up, and his worries about her health. Besides books, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and lots of fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important roles - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also known for his work with the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, people didn't care much if shoes were comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins that people wrapped around their ankles when it was cold. We still use leather today, but other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton are also popular, depending on fashion trends. It was only about 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could fit either the left or right foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, even though some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are made by machines in big factories. The invention of sewing machines helped the shoe industry make lots of cheaper shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to stop my running career for a while. I wanted to help more women discover running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to boost their confidence to start running. So, I decided to create a running club for women in my area. I was frustrated with many race organizers who complain about the low number of women in the sport but don't provide separate changing rooms for them. I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were of all ages and fitness levels. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had considered running before. If they did, they probably imagined it as hard and painful training. They didn't think about running while chatting and smiling in beautiful places, like along a river. At first, they could only run for a minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They've also learned from other runners about healthy eating and staying fit. I wanted to support women's running, and I've really enjoyed watching their progress—almost as much as they have.'

The History of the Iditarod - The Last Great Race on Earth

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people moved there, hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built, including one called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. During the summer, boats could bring supplies to these towns, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making travel impossible. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for dog sled teams to deliver mail, food, and clothes to gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to cross Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers and dogs could rest and eat. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams for transport.

However, in 1925, the dogs were needed again when a disease called diphtheria broke out in Nome. The medicine to cure it was in Anchorage, far across Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold weather. Also, the only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to complete the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to guide him through the blinding snow, and Togo proved to be a dependable leader. The last part of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, who had been driving dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to move forward, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of the 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjärvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit every year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made entirely of ice. You can even have a wedding there if you wish. The bar is also made of ice, so it's not a good idea to put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are kept at around -4°C, but guests are given special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, suitable outdoor clothing is also available. The hotel is rebuilt every winter because it melts in the summer. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one minded that I was a girl, but then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who had supported other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and found her playing football outside the club. He quickly noticed she was very fast. "He talked to me about athletics, but I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was really hard work, and my legs hurt a lot." Jose visited her parents and convinced them that Maria could succeed in athletics and help lift them out of poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an offer to train in the United States. She had refused before because she would miss her family. Her life was very different from the girls she met in the US. She says, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot." Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year living happily in South Africa with her mother.

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Many people visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1,219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and a glass floor, allowing you to see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You need to wear special shoe covers to protect the glass from scratches. Walking on the Skywalk feels like you are a bird flying high in the sky.

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest and extend to areas just a few hundred miles from the center in the south. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are equally impressive. There are many roads that cross the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. You start your journey in Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful big cities. This city is unique because it is close to both the ocean and the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey is still an exciting adventure. You sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but you pass through some of the most beautiful scenery during the night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. The rulers of China created a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the early zoos, animals were often trained to perform for visitors. This is no longer the case, as zoos now focus on letting people see animals in their natural behavior. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. Supporters of zoos argue that they allow us to learn about nature and see wild animals up close, which would not be possible otherwise. On the other hand, critics say it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also point out that in poorly managed zoos, animals may live in dirty conditions and eat the wrong food.'

**Jazz by Katie Atkins, Age 14**

I play the trumpet in my school's jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from other local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions. The quality of playing was amazing, especially since everyone was so young. Musicians from each band even made up new tunes right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even more exciting when my band played!

We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets in—only about half do. However, anyone who is eager to play can join jazz practice before school. We also spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are trips to jazz summer camps across the country, and I've been to a couple where I learned a lot.

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for serious music students like me. I find jazz exciting because it's both new and old. You can create your own music, but you also feel connected to its history, playing on stage like the great jazz performers before you.

My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we wouldn't get far with our music!

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, it doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. Recently, many winters have been dry, so when it rains, the local people are happy. Marrakesh's parks and gardens don't rely on rain. Instead, they get water from a network of underground channels, built in the 11th century, that bring water from the mountains all year. Places like this, which are usually dry but get water this way, are called oases. If you travel further south from Marrakesh, you reach Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas Mountains, covered in snow during winter, provide a beautiful backdrop.'

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old and the youngest child of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to try and find full-time jobs with a circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go back home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." "People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And what about the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. Our members gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to major newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites for publication. You can read or listen to the accepted stories on our website. We have three centers across the country where young people can meet and work on projects, and we plan to open more centers nationwide. Since we started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have joined us. 

Sophie, a former member, shares her experience: "I first learned about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article on young people's views on hip hop music. I was impressed by the young journalists and the opportunities they had. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to handle stories independently. I joined the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and stayed until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I imagined. With the skills I gained, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they go online."

When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll receive training and attend monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. We encourage members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over who teach new members basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some trainers present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These trainers are supported by older staff on these trips. We hold training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next session is in February. If you're interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.

**Flight Overview**

During the short Antarctic summer, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back in a Boeing 747. Flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be transferred if we need to change the date.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**

The flight lasts about 12 hours. After four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica, and the rest of the time is for the return trip. During the flight, experts who have lived in Antarctica give talks about the environment and history and answer questions. A camera near the pilot shows you the view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a window seat?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you will switch seats. Business and first-class passengers have a window seat for half the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window or next-to-window seat for half the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While over Antarctica, you can move around the plane to enjoy the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' so everyone can see the sights from both sides of the plane.

**What if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different flight plans. On the morning of the flight, the captain checks the satellite cloud images and chooses the route with the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife is at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica to protect the environment. To see wildlife, you would need to take a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes, you can take photos. All cameras are welcome. We also offer some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Little Chefs

Every Saturday, a group of children aged ten to fifteen learn how to cook seriously. These classes are so popular that 30 children are waiting to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where their children can have fun and learn to cook well. Bill, who is ten, says, "I love my mum's cooking, but now I can cook even better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we've made together." Flora, who is twelve, finds cutting onions difficult. She says, "I love cooking. I once cooked a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum then suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I liked staying at home, so I wasn't interested at first. But now I'm really glad I joined." Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen can get messy when they're cooking! As adults, we keep learning about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they're young, they'll know how to cook for themselves when they leave home."

Winter Driving

Winter driving is dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly as you go over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. A car coming towards you might unexpectedly slide across the road. 

Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make your car hard to control. So, whenever you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it.

Rule Number Two is to be aware of what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently pressing the brakes. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, triple the distance on snow, and even more on ice. 

Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law but ended up going to art school. He found traditional drawing classes hard but continued painting. In his late twenties, he received a scholarship from the Italian government to study art. This experience made him interested in early Italian artists, which influenced some of his work. He admired the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the clear light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. To achieve this, he painted colors in thin layers from light to dark, but he admits he never knows exactly how the painting will turn out. He says, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Aitchison makes it sound simple, saying, 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just notice what colors go well together.' Unlike some artists, he doesn't make sketches before starting a painting because he thinks he might lose interest and not finish the painting. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why he prefers models who don't ask to see their portraits while he's working. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he hasn't felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He says he doesn't follow any tradition and just paints in his own way. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we didn't want to get it because of the noise. Ben said, "It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. "Okay," we said, "but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, the other members of Ben's band began coming to our house with their guitars and other electric equipment. So, for several hours a week, our house is filled with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practicing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. 

I must admit that, even though their music sounds a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I can't really judge their musical talent—after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music I did when I was a teenager—but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main concern is that they might not spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain—Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble, and he is never bored.

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a top private school in Wales. This school is special because it gives students important life experiences outside the classroom, along with preparing them for exams. The students, aged 16 to 18, come from all over the world. They study in the mornings and spend the afternoons doing useful activities. These activities include helping on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is its diverse student body. Students come from different social backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are PS20,000 for two years, many students need financial help. Scholarships are available, and a quarter of the students are British, with many receiving government support to attend.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people. You learn to live with and respect others, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides an excellent education using methods that truly work.

Being an Older Student

At 32, I have just completed my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a decent salary, but I was bored because the job didn't challenge me mentally. I felt stuck and became more and more unhappy. I envied the students at the local university because they seemed happy, carefree, and hopeful. I wanted to be part of that world.

Now that I am a student, I find it difficult to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask me questions I can't answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. Despite these challenges, I am grateful for the chance to study. I know that having a qualification is important for getting a fulfilling job, which matters a lot to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending weekends with my books rather than going out to parties. There are also typical student perks like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I sometimes worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this stage in life has been a good decision.

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he didn't enjoy farming. At fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he created the first Ford Model T, which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Dear Sir, I saw your ad for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more details. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next one start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez

Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course begins in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. It lasts for 6 weeks and costs £150. If you want to start in June, we have another course that lasts 10 weeks and costs £200. I hope this answers your questions. Yours, David May

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before this achievement, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca decided to leave her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is very challenging. "You have to carry everything on your back," she said, "so you can only bring what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and eventually, I didn't even bring a toothbrush. I usually like to stay clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only bring enough to drink!" When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now, she has written a book about her journey, and people often invite her to talk about it. She also has a new job on a science TV program. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in her small apartment in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains.

Dear Mike,

I'm sorry you couldn't make it to my party yesterday. Jon mentioned that you had a bad cold and chose to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? The party was great, the best I've ever had! Many of my friends came, and they gave me some wonderful gifts. I'll tell you more about it when you come to school on Monday.

Love,  
Lorenzo

CANADA GEESE

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places because the winters in Canada are too cold for them to survive. Last spring, a man named Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents, and Bill thought, "These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn."

Bill had a small airplane, and he decided to teach the birds to follow him. Throughout the summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese flew behind him. When autumn's cold weather came, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way there. Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home.

This spring, Bill expected the birds to come back, but they didn't show up. So, he flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't locate them. When he got back home, he discovered the geese were already there, waiting for him. They had managed to find their way home without his help!

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. While most of her friends chose to go to college, Esther used the money from her aunt to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold each jar for £1 to her friends and quickly doubled the £500. Initially, her parents wanted her to focus on studying because they hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. She also started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked. After two years, her business grew significantly, and her parents were proud of her. She made various foods and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She became so busy that she needed to hire people to help her.

Dear Jacqueline,

Would you like to join me at the cinema after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The movie begins at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema?

Love,  
Isabella

---

Dear Isabella,

I'm really sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has some work to do, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go with you? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow.

Love,  
Jacqueline

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler run the farm, where they have cows and chickens, selling milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She owns 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the sheep to keep them cool. 

Five years ago, Jenny decided to make sweaters from the wool and sell them at country markets. Unfortunately, it was summer, and the hot weather meant people weren't interested in buying sweaters. So, she started making socks instead. The socks became very popular because they were affordable, durable, and easy to wash. This marked the beginning of Jenny's business. Initially, she made the socks at home, but as her customer base grew to thousands, she had to send the wool to a factory. Now, the socks are produced by machines.

Jenny's socks come in six colors and five sizes, suitable for all ages. There are also different types of socks for walkers, sports enthusiasts, and skiers. Christmas is Jenny's busiest time because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In Jenny's office, the walls are covered with letters from satisfied customers from around the world.

28 Long Road  
Brighton  
22nd March  

Dear Pat,

I arrived in Brighton three weeks ago. I'm studying at a language school here. The students come from many different countries, and I've made a lot of new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I really like our teacher. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I'm going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon.

Best wishes,  
Maria

Text: 'BURGLARS LOVE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also mentioned that 67% of burglaries occur when people leave home and forget to close a door or window. He added that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually at home. However, winter afternoons are ideal for burglars because it is dark, making it easier for them to go unnoticed. Many houses are empty during this time because people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday to deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to watch over each other's houses when people are away and to call the police if they notice anything unusual. 'We can also advise you on how to make your house safe,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This kind of help is free.''

Dear Lynne and Tony,

I just wanted to say thank you for letting me stay at your lovely home for two nights. It was great to see you both again. I've attached the photos of your children that you wanted. They turned out well, don't you think? I hope you like them. I'm really enjoying my new camera.

Next week, I'm going to visit my sister in New York. I'll take many photos there as well. It's been a long time since I last saw her.

Thanks again.

Love,  
Roy

Text: 'The History of Farming Before farming, people searched forests for plants and fruits to eat. This meant they had to move constantly to find food. However, around 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people started growing their own food. These were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to settle in one place, and their villages gradually expanded. Some villagers could focus on other tasks, like making clothes, because farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was challenging during bad weather, leading to food shortages. Today, farmers can produce more food, and it is transported thousands of kilometers to reach our homes.'

WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE

Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then started working at a local airport. After nine months, she got a job with Saudi Arabian Airlines and later joined British Airways as a flight attendant. Four years after that, she became a manager, which is her current job. Here’s what she says about her work:

"My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I train flight attendants and help them with any issues they have. I also attend many meetings. My usual working hours are from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At the start of my day, I check flight schedules on my computer and then talk to some of the flight attendants. Occasionally, I go on long flights to see how the flight attendants are doing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I also enjoy the office work. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I want to do is eat something and then go to bed! I don't make a lot of money, but I'm happy working for British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling."

Dear Maria,

It's nice to be back in my home country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon.

Love,  
Sophie

Dear Sir,  
  
I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on May 10th. It is a large blue bag with my name written on the outside. Have you found this bag?  
  
Yours faithfully,  
Mary Johnson  
  
Dear Ms. Johnson,  
  
I am happy to inform you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can return it to you. The office is open from 9 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. every day.  
  
Yours sincerely,  
J. Wilson

People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for various jobs. For instance, the weather greatly affects farmers. In the past, farmers would spend a lot of time observing the sky, animals, and plants to understand the weather better. Nowadays, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even check the weather on their mobile phones. Despite modern technology, many people still believe in traditional weather sayings. For example, they say that if the sky is red in the evening, the next day will be sunny. Some also believe that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They have been friends and classmates for a long time. Like their other friends, they usually enjoy fishing or swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have been spending their weekends in Peter's room working on his laptop. This isn't because they have a lot of homework. Instead, they have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who has trouble with reading. Kevin finds it easier to learn words by seeing pictures and hearing information rather than just reading. Frazer wanted to help his brother, so he and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to create a computer game. Now, the game is ready to use. It is a speaking and picture game. For example, when you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their computer game, and it will soon be available for sale worldwide. Many schools are interested in buying it.

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Getting enough sleep is very important. When I visit my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, it's hard for me to sleep because my mind is full of music. Exercise is also important. Before my car accident, I used to spend two and a half hours a day, five days a week, at the sports center. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well and drink a lot of water because it's healthy. I aim for about eight glasses a day, but I don't always manage that. It's important not to work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's beneficial to relax sometimes. I don't feel tired anymore since my doctor advised me to eat better. Now, I eat a lot of vegetables like carrots and spinach every day. But I still enjoy burgers occasionally!'

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It produces nearly 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films, which is more than any other country, including the USA. This makes it the largest film industry in the world. Watching films is the favorite pastime for most Indians, with ten million people going to the cinema daily. Bollywood films often feature romantic love stories, with singing and dancing as key elements. These films are also popular outside India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling films internationally. Indian actors make more films each year than their Hollywood counterparts, but they earn less money. As a result, most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to produce, while Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan is an exception; he is considered one of India's greatest actors and has starred in over 140 films during a career spanning almost 40 years.

I was born in the United States, but I have written several travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. However, for the past three years, we have been living in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the U.S. I believe they will be happier because they have experienced living in two countries. I like Britain and want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so we will stay for another four years. I recently spent six weeks in England to work on a radio program about the English language and to discuss my new book. Many writers don't enjoy traveling around to promote their books, but I don't mind. I like visiting new places and meeting people. It's very different from my life in the U.S. when I'm writing. In England, people drove me around in big cars, and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was nice because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me, and I had a lot of fun.

Schnauzer Dogs

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs: Miniature, Standard, and Giant. The Miniature and Standard Schnauzers came to England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer arrived more recently. The name "Giant" fits well because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs regular trimming. Most Miniature and Standard Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers originally come from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep. They are also used by the police because they are very intelligent. Schnauzers are great family pets. They are friendly and very good with young children.

Mary Daniels is a student in England. This summer, she had an exciting holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two large towns. Mary said, "It was very hard because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food." She also mentioned that it was very cold and wet in the mountains, as it is one of the wettest places in the world. Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. Although it was tough work, she says it was the best experience she has ever had. She hopes to go back next year to do more work there.

Dear Keira,

Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me find the classrooms. She is very nice, and I plan to visit her this weekend. My favorite class today was Maths, and I was pleased because I knew more than the other girls. I also tried playing hockey for the first time and really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework.

Hester

New Books This Month

The Long Night  
This is the first book by David Reilly. David started writing after teaching English for several years. The story is about Maha, a nurse in northern Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, and Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to the nearest big city. They face many challenges on their journey.

Hard Work  
This is the twentieth book by Joanna Jones. The story is about Sombat, who works with his father as a carpenter in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they don't have much money. One day, a man dressed in black buys the most beautiful table in their shop.

Hospital or Cinema?  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. The story is about Tina, a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine. One day, she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star. What will Tina decide to do?

Horse racing has been an important sport throughout history. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing started when Arab horses came to Europe in the 12th century. Initially, races were long and involved only two horses. However, in the early 18th century, races became shorter and included several horses competing at once. Today, horse racing is very popular in the USA, second only to baseball, and is also enjoyed in many other countries.

Nick Barlow is a British actor who loves his job because it allows him to travel the world making TV shows. He feels welcomed everywhere he goes and enjoys remembering the amazing experiences from each country when he returns home. Although he has visited many places, Nick still dreams of traveling to South America and revisiting Australia. 

When Nick travels, he is accompanied by a team that handles the cameras and filming equipment. He packs lightly for himself, bringing only a few shirts and trousers, but he always includes some books in his suitcase. 

Nick's wife, Helen, is supportive of his travels. She has many friends and stays busy while he is away. She enjoys hearing his travel stories when he returns. However, there can be challenges. For example, when Nick was in the Malaysian rainforest, he learned that Helen was ill in the hospital. He felt awful because he couldn't be there to help, but she insisted he stay. He was relieved when he found out she had recovered.

Parrots

You might have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in large groups. Because they like to eat fruit, they can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet, which they use for climbing and holding food. The largest parrots can live up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart birds and can easily be taught to talk. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch the birds perform tricks they have learned.

Howard Bonnier

Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant there called The Palace about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written about almost all the best restaurants in France for French magazines. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend his money on clothes and CDs. Instead, he used it to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks—he says he has more than 250! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Was it easy to do? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant, and it's much harder to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he made the right choice.

John Pickering works in a park in a small town in central England, where he cuts the grass and waters the flowers. However, last week he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television. This is because John, who is 35 years old, is currently the most popular singer in Japan. A few months ago, he went to Japan to sing in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people called the radio station to request his songs again. In Japan, John uses the stage name Jon Otis. Despite his success, he plans to continue working in the park in England because he is unsure how much money he will make from his music. He says, "I must keep my job in the park. I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This will not change the way we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

Memo To: D Brown  
Subject: Holidays  
From: J Green

Could I take a two-week holiday in July? I prefer the first two weeks, but if that is not possible, the last two weeks are fine. Also, can I have three extra days off in the first week of December?  
John

Line Dancing

In Britain, many people have taken up a new hobby: line dancing. You can find clubs and classes for line dancing in almost every town. According to Fiona Lever, a teacher, "Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" You don't need a partner because you dance in groups, which makes it a great way to meet new people. In Fiona's classes, both young and old people join in. Boys especially enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

Text: 'The Rhino There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open areas of Africa, while the others live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. A rhino's big body stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat only grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos when it is born, after being inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live up to 50 years.'

The History of the London Police

Today, you can see policemen everywhere, but back in 1700, London didn't have any policemen. At that time, a few old men would watch over the city streets at night, but they didn't earn much money. Around 300 years ago, London began to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people preferred to stay at home.

In 1750, Henry Fielding started paying a group of people to catch thieves. They were similar to policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown a lot and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan Police Force was created with 3000 officers. Most of them walked on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are paid quite well, and those who still ride horses earn even more than the others.

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Are you interested in joining a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest using the school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite offers hot showers and has a small shop. You can also rent bicycles there. The trip costs £25. Please remember that it gets very cold at night, so bring warm clothes and wear sturdy shoes. If you want to join, please let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to join the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are lively with music and dance from early morning until late at night. You can even watch artists painting on the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues like halls and cafes. Many tourists come to see new films and plays and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it's often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding a room can be hard, so consider booking your hotel now!

ICE-FISHING

If you drive three hours north from Toronto, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and thousands of Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they fish for the fish swimming under the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here every year for twenty-five years. He says, "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then, you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet some nice people here!"

Subject: Tough Week

Hi Anna,

I'm having a rough week. Yesterday, my volleyball team lost our match because the other team played much better. Then, my friend Jeff from Australia called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he got a summer job, so we can't go camping together anymore. 

This morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without asking me. I'm really upset with her. 

I hope you have some good news to share. Please write back today if you can.

Greg

Madame Tussaud's

One very popular tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. At this museum, visitors can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures of people and opened a museum for them in Paris. Marie helped her uncle with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was put in prison. While there, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud. In 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures and opened a museum. Her wax figures are still on display there today.

BICYCLES

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, so only wealthy people could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we see today. As bicycles became more affordable, many people started buying them. People began using bicycles to commute to work and for leisure activities. Nowadays, cars are more commonly used than bicycles because they are faster and protect you from the rain. However, some people still choose to cycle to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making it hard to find parking spaces.

Last summer, I went to Thailand with my family for a beach holiday. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were most excited about the elephant show. We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their trainers and stood in front of big white cards. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started painting on its card. The trainers helped by giving them new brushes with paint and taking the old ones away. Slowly, the elephants painted pictures by following their trainers' instructions. I was amazed! One elephant painted a river, another painted a tree, and the third painted a bunch of flowers. When the trainers showed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they don't work there anymore, but the smartest ones live in special centers where visitors can watch them.

Text: 'Big Cats There are many types of big cats, and they differ in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest of all cats. They can be as long as 3.7 meters from head to tail. Unlike most cats, tigers enjoy water and often cool off in pools when it's hot. Lions are unique because they live in large family groups called prides. In these groups, several lions work together to hunt for food. Lions usually live in flat, open areas where they can see far and easily track other animals. All big cats need excellent eyesight to hunt smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.'

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I am sorry, but I can't attend your class anymore because I need to go back to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to help her choose a dress. My parents are also preparing a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work to do in the kitchen. I am sad to leave the English class. You are an excellent teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me.

Thank you again.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

14 Sheffield Road  
Rotherham  
20th May 2002  

Dear Mary,

I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please let me know when you are free and where I can meet you. I hope to see you then.

Best wishes,  
Joan

Dear Joan,

Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a good Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please try to be on time!

Best,  
Mary

Dear Lorna,

How are you? I'm excited because I recently started a new job in the city center. I work at a Tourist Information Office, and it's very interesting. I begin work every morning at 7:30, so I have to wake up quite early! I enjoy this job because I get to meet people from many different countries. I like sharing information about our city with them. Here is a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it?

Love,  
Gloria

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh over 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. Ostriches have wings like all birds, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them change direction when running. Ostriches can run very fast, between 65 and 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the size of chickens and take about 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can survive for many days without water.'

Victoria Jamieson from Britain began snowboarding at the age of 20. Now, at 23, she has won many competitions in this sport. We talked to her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked why she started snowboarding. She said, "I've always enjoyed all kinds of sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It doesn't take long to learn, and you can become really good in just a few months." 

We asked if she practices a lot. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and go biking. But I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because it's so beautiful. But free-riding, which is doing whatever you want when you're not competing, is the best thing in the world for me."

We also asked what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also important to have the right clothes so you don't get wet because, at first, you spend a lot of time falling down!"

23 Oak Avenue  
Manchester  

Dear Sir or Madam,

I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights, from September 15th to 17th. I need a single room with a shower and a telephone. Could you please provide a quiet room on the ground floor? I will be driving to the hotel, so I would like to know if there is a car park available. I expect to arrive at around 10:30 p.m. Could you tell me what time the restaurant closes in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal when I arrive.

Thank you for your assistance.

Yours faithfully,  
Mark Jones

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. People of all ages have climbed it, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man. There are different routes to reach the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It usually takes about five days to complete and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers manage to reach the top. This is often because the weather can change very quickly. At the start, it might be hot and wet, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and the temperature can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can move through the water at speeds of over 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. Otters can close their ears and nose, allowing them to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very polluted, which caused many fish and insects to die, leaving otters with little to eat. However, today the rivers are clean again, providing plenty of food for otters.'

Dear Deshini,

I'm happy to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write to me and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there someday. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school that you could send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family, and I'll send more next time I write. I hope to hear from you soon.

Tom

17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002

Dear John,

Thank you for helping me with my English. You are an excellent teacher. I really enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying medicine to become a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks before returning home to Greece. I like London a lot. Yesterday, we took a bus to Regents Park. The weather was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a movie with my brother and some of his friends. I will write to you again from Greece.

Best wishes,  
Kostas

Dear David, I will visit your country next month with two friends. We are unsure about where to stay. Are there any affordable hotels in your town? We would prefer to stay in the center. Can you assist us? Carlos

Dear Carlos, Hotels in the center are costly, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she says you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? David

People have always constructed buildings. We need houses to stay warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football games and concerts. We also use buildings like museums to store beautiful things. Many people work together to create a building. The architect plans how the building will look and draws designs to show their ideas. Engineers ensure the building will be strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it. The Sydney Opera House is a well-known modern building with a beautiful roof. However, the building is attractive from every angle, not just from above. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This unique building resembles a tent made of glass.

Text: 'Indre, I need your help with a problem. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The issue is I don't have anything to wear. I've grown a lot, and now all my trousers are too short! I want to buy some new trousers and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have much money, but I think it will be enough. Would you prefer to meet in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large figure of a man. This figure is called the Cerne Giant because it is near the village of Cerne. No one knows exactly when the Cerne Giant was created, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the figure. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the top runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she aims to compete in the 10,000 meters and possibly the 5,000 meters at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in major races. However, she was always cheerful, and people in her hometown admire her for that. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long-distance road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest that year for any British woman. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop due to an injury to his right leg. He can still run a bit and sometimes trains with Gail, but it's tough for Mike when Gail overtakes him, and he can't keep up. Gail trains diligently. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. However, she always takes a break from running on Sundays. "I am with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually about cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From ages twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. Ivan's mother started teaching him piano when he was six. By the age of ten, he wanted to write music and soon composed his first song.

Oleg Gagarin was the youngest of five children. His father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him traditional Russian music when Oleg was four. At six, he began lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning piano competitions. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

Josef Heptmann's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano a year later. He performed his first concert at six. At ten, he played fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England. Josef always loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. Although he is very busy now, he hopes to write his own music someday.

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he started writing children's books at 60. Now, 13 years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he writes in his office and in the evening, his wife reads his work. "She tells me if she doesn't like something," Bill says. His ten grandchildren, who live far away, also read his stories and give their opinions. This feedback helps Bill understand what young children enjoy reading.

Bill writes about life in his village and nearby farms. His favorite book is his fifth one, "The Sheepdog," which is about a farmer and his helpful dog. "I have always liked animals," Bill says, "and dogs are very smart; they learn quickly." Last year, "The Sheepdog" was turned into a film using real animals and actors. The filmmakers used advanced computer technology to make it look like the animals are talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film," he says.

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often better than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the 19th century. It featured a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards showed pictures of news events from that week, like an accident or a visit from an important person. People liked these because newspapers didn't have pictures at that time.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur because they became extinct about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are considered the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs varied greatly in appearance. There were over 5000 different species. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and was a plant-eater. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as large, but it was more powerful. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast due to its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they use their noses to find food. There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. Not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Everyone loves the black and white panda bear, which is from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard for them to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in warm areas of the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can move quickly in water and on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat anything they can catch, like fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat large animals or people. There are more than ten different types of crocodiles. All of them have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but new ones grow back quickly. Most crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much bigger. Crocodiles can live for many years. The oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

Text: 'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers created the first hot air balloon that could carry people. Then, 120 years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers in the United States built the first airplane with an engine and flew it. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service using airplanes. Over the next thirty years, airplanes changed a lot. In the 1950s, they became much faster because of jet engines. In 1976, the Concorde was built in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world, flying at 2500 kilometers per hour, which makes the trip from London to New York only four hours long. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.'

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round and had no roof, so people got cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to watch plays by William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, talk to their friends, walk around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same area near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water there is so warm, and I love swimming. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home!

See you at the end of September.

Sue
